text: #dnd tip: Build some background into your magic items. Where did that sword come from? How did it get to the dragons hoard?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't always have to use wet erase mats or dwarven forge or dungeon tiles separately. Mix them together. Be a kid again!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Gnoll minis can make decent Rakshasa minis when you don't want to spend a mint on the Rakshasa minis. Cat warriors too.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A black cloth tablecloth works well to hold dungeon tiles in place and doesn't distract from the map. Nice for bottomless chasms.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A few short skill challenges can show the players progress through a long journey. "Remember that time back at the Lake of Fire?"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't underestimate a good ad-hoc skill challenge. What's the situation? What's the goal? What happens on success or failure?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't burn paper, soak it, and then microwave it. It will catch fire again and burn your house down. Learned the hard way. #dnd
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A cut up black t-shirt can make a great fog of war for your dwarven forge layout.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: reskin one of your big bad evil guys with stats from a Monster Manual 2 beast to see how it plays out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to get your warped D&D miniatures straightened? Put them in boiling water, straighten them, and put them in bowl of ice water
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Game going long? Distribute loot and exp in email between games. Add some good background or flavor text too.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make skill challenge failure interesting and an opportunity for something new.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sudoku puzzles with runes or sigils instead of numbers can make for fun arcanic puzzles provided you have a player good at sudoku.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's hard to keep a villain reoccurring. Don't overuse one way. Have them become an ally, resurrect, flee,  or fight from shadows
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: try having minions at paragon and above deal their level in damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a card for each of your players with their playstyle, goals, and your plans to keep them engaged.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be creative and run a battle or two without maps or minis for a random encounter or two.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Combat is a poor failure condition for a skill challenge. It can add an extra hour to your normal game. Take surges instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: bring out minions in waves of four to reduce the effectiveness of blasts. The cleric's Solar Wrath is devastating to minions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep Dungeon Tiles separated by set to make it easy to find the pieces you need.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: want a movie with a great D&D-style storyline? Try Carpenter's "Prince of Darkness". The scariest villains are often unseen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Playing a high-level one-shot? Consider eliminating paragon paths and epic destinies to streamline and balance the character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always try to run your party through four or five combats before they get a full rest or they'll power through things too often.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: use sticky notes to post elite templates or modified hp / damage house rules right next to the stat block in your MM or adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: consider offering to update the character sheets of your players using the Character Builder. Gives you am idea of their powers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget that monsters can take minor actions instead of move actions. Solos and Elites may make up to three attacks a round.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Players Handbook 2 character backgrounds are a great way for non-roleplayers to get into their characters past.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: use roleplaying and theatrics to lighten up dull moments in battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: from @chattyDM; run eight session "Seasonal Campaigns" to let your players try out new classes and races.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: from reader Luke; maximize player and monster damage to speed up combat quite a bit with fewer rounds and fewer rolls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be a slave to a creature's published hit points. If a battle is dragging, give the party a critical kill.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep careful track of your monsters' immediate abilities, especially death-based instants. Write a note where you track their HPs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: don't be shy to talk in voices. Have fun with it. There us no ego in D&D (except those dwarves).
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use house rules you can enforce on the DM side of the screen so players aren't jerked around by your new strange rules.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix your dungeon tiles and dwarven forge together. Place the flat tiles within dwarven forge rooms for added detail.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good tips for challenging your powergamer / tactical players:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read up on future modules and Introduce major npcs from those modules early in your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: tweak your boss monster to challenge your party by replacing powers or adding alternate abilities. Check Open Grave, page 220.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need some quick PCs for a one shot or dungeon delve? Use the DMG rules for NPC creation for limited PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The PHB2 and Forgotten Realms "backgrounds" work well for NPCs and bad guys as well as PCs. Use them for a quick NPC seed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: soak notes in coffee to give them an aged look.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember that monsters can use multiple minor powers in a round - even the same power - if it isn't a "once per round" ability.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: watch your players to get a feel for their excitement and boredom. Figure out what they like and hate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: set up your battles and try a few rounds out solo to get a feel for the battlefield before the big game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: have your players tell you one "secret" that their PCs are keeping from the rest. Sometimes you need to add a little drama.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dwarven Forge's strength is in 3D environments. Use platforms and multi-levels. Build upwards!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Screen grab and paste monster statblocks from the compendium into a horizontal Word document to build your own encounter sheet.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bax the Dragonborn in the Thunderspire adventure can make for a great redemption story arc. Use him but not for combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: sometimes you might tell a NPC's backstory even after their dead. Maybe thinking with a shield bash was a hasty choice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: *trollhaunt spoiler* Let players plan their defense of Moonstair. Make it their Helm's Deep.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: use the backgrounds in the Eberron PHB as story seeds for your campaign or backgrounds for your npcs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to speed up a game or miss the 3.5 swing? Add a "double damage on critical" house rule.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: watch your players to get a feel for their excitement and boredom. Figure out what they like and hate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use house rules you can enforce on the DM side of the screen so players aren't jerked around by your new strange rules.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want more roleplaying in your combat-focused 4e game? Add it TO the combat! Banter between combatants, skill challenges, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give physical props to your players as a larping gateway drug.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can scale Dungeon Delves up to 4 levels above or below your party's level. That's nine adventures for nearly any level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players spending too much time twittering or texting at the table? Ask yourself what you can do to draw them back into the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: catagorize and store minis based on the numbers you have. Mix orcs and gnolls if they aren't that numerous.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: set up your battles and try a few rounds out solo to get a feel for the battlefield before the big game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a rules lawyer at the table? Make his or position official as a rules moderator. Make sure they are objective, though.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember that power gamers are a legitimate player type. Make the game exciting for them with detaled and interesting encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw your power gamer in with an intelligent item that grants nice bonuses with the right roleplaying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write your own flavor text. Keep it short and make it heroic or epic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: turn your character into a deck by using hard card sleeves with the character and power cards from the Builder.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: add some normal skirmishers two or three rounds into your big solo battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: tape or paste the errata update to difficulty check scores per level to your DM screen. It's a valuable aid.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: try running random encounters without a battle map. Just use descriptions. Mix them with skill challenges.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: little cut out circles of red construction paper make great pools of blood to decorate the battlefield during an encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dungeoncraft essays by Ray Winninger recommended by Mike Mearls:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: send email to specific players to give them info only their character knows. Be careful not to drive a wedge between them, though.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: awesome tip of using a double dog dish as a dice roller from @unclebear :
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run some encounters as flashbacks or dream sequences to show instead of tell the background of the story. Don't overdo it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run some encounters as flashbacks or dream sequences to show instead of tell the background of the story. Don't overdo it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run some encounters as flashbacks or dream sequences to show instead of tell the background of the story. Don't overdo it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run some encounters as flashbacks or dream sequences to show instead of tell the background of the story. Don't overdo it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: for a powerful party, use terrain effects that don't affect monsters. It's an experience-budget-free way to increase challenge.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Everyone in Eberron has been affected by the Last War. Everyone knows someone who died. How will that play into your PCs and NPCs?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Why do your bad guys think they are right? What makes them heroes in their own eyes?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a minute to review the monsters in your next encounter just before running it. Any auras or immediates to remember?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Precision dice may sound cool and the Col sure is a great salesman, but the ink runs and round-edged dice play just fine.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use changing environments to really spice up a battle. Did that fire elemental open a pool of molten rock? Will the walls burn?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch Indiana Jones or Maltise Falcon to get in your Eberron mind-set. Think high adventure!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bosses dying too fast? What if they are immortal except if their orbs of power are broken?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The gargantuan blue dragon mini works well as a Tarrasque.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stunning a paladin is a good way to break off his or her divine challenge. This can be critical for solo creatures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reuse old battle maps from published adventures by changing the monsters and the environmental effects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The straight dracolich in MM1 is probably too stun-heavy for a good time. Consider the dracolich alts in Open Grave instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: War devil minis can stand in for many other demon and devil minis. They're a good universal winged red nasty.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write out your treasure parcels on sticky notes you can paste right into your adventure books.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you're too shy or embarrassed to "use the voices", try roleplaying in the third person. It's not quite as odd.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: think early about where each character's epic destiny may lie. Where is their path taking them?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Who will be the Belloq (of Raiders of the Lost Ark fame) in your Eberron campaign. Nothing builds a good story like a good rival.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: always consider what environmental effect you can add to an encounter room.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: not everything needs to be a skill challenge. Sometimes all you need is a series of skill checks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Everything in Eberron is fantastic. Towers so vast they have weather within them. Bridges that span drops beyond sight. Fantastic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What motivations guide the drive of a thousand year old lich? What would such a creature want? Consider age with motive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Asmor's treasure parcel generator to build out a level's worth of treasure ahead of time:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every battle has to be in wide open rooms. Consider a series of cramped hallways as a single encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build encounters based on your favorite action scenes. Think "House of Blue Leaves" from Kill Bill.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always ask your players if they're having a good time but also watch their body language during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of ways to run your game like a three-ring circus. Give them more to see than they can handle and they'll stay engaged.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good list of retired heroes called back to action - great background ideas for NPC heroes or villains:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add statues, gargoyles, columns, mirrors, and other objects that don't actually do anything just to throw off your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The key to keeping a beholder dangerous is keeping everyone within 5 for the aura. Have him float four squares above the party.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: found a great zombie tile graphic to use for zombie hordes like those found in Demon Queen's Enclave:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For storing Dwarven Forge pieces, try the Sterlite 7 Drawer craft cart for $30. Holds 6 sets per cart.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The gargantuan ancient black dragon miniature works well as the main boss Nightwyrm Fortress.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Print monsters on 5x8 cards using the Monster Builder. They look far better than the scaled images. It's like a monster deck!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What interesting plot motives do each of Demogorgon's heads have? Surely they conflict. He's a one-character plot twist!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix slaughter wights and bodaks for a devastating weaken to death gaze attack combination. Take that, powergamers!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use magic items and treasure as keys or other plot hooks into the rest of your story. Who will hunt the party down for that loot?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You only get one chance to do a particular scene right. Blow it and you can never try it again. Prepare, prepare, prepare!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary of high level soldiers. Missing all the time steals the fun away from players. High level brutes are more rewarding.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Boneclaws work best when they're using their substantial OA effects on ranged and  casters. Against defenders, they're not useful.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even for your two or three encounter nightly game, think about the story hook for that game. Think of it as a TV episode.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Here's my current favorite initiative and condition tracking system. It's almost free!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hazardous zones are only useful to your monsters if they can push and pull. PCs have lots of ways to move enemies. Monsters don't.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players not paying attention at the game? Find ways to draw them back in without being pushy or confrontational. It's all for fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie back to a character's background at least once every five games. Ask yourself how you can tie to the player's creative work.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: from @chattydm. Stop being self consious and just go for it. Apparently alcohol can help.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choose and suggest movies for your players to watch to get into the mood of your campaign. Is yours Harry Potter or The Fountain?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Rolling attacks and damage isn't always faster. Sometimes it's easier and faster for a player to take a step at a time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have trouble beginning your game? Write down a short, strong, and powerful introductory sentence: "Your friend, Hodar, is dead"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Create a Diablo-style loot pinata by crying out loud and throwing 3x5 treasure item cards into the air when your boss dies.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always be on the lookout for a good prop. Antique shops, party stores, and dollar stores have great selections of crazy things.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Skim through the DMG every month or so to refresh your ideas and get you thinking about how to improve your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: modify the traps on page 87-93 of the DMG by changing targets, elements, or effects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider your villain's dialog carefully. A misplaced word can mean the difference between being sinister and being silly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running an encounter on a ship or airship? Have the rocking of the boat push and pull the combatants as an environmental effect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a good word processing program to make good-looking quest cards with pictures and clear quest motivations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clear quest goals help tie your players to the story. Don't put too many twists into them. Players want to feel in control.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is your adventure's soundtrack? Listen to your old tunes while dreaming your adventure like Tarrantino:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When using +1 tokens as motivators for fast rounds, let them trade them to another player when needed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Three battles taking too much time? Drop it to two battles with some leisure time for skill challenges and roleplaying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Order food and have it ready before the game begins. Interrupting a game for food can take up valuable time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customize your skill challenges to make them personal for the characters. Use them to aid in background creation and char plots.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give bosses a way to control environments. Fire elementals may leave trails of molten rock or giants may crush walls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful of making the black dragon's dark cloud too cheesy. Think of it as an offensive tool, not a defensive one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use elemental miniatures as flame effects for your battle maps. They look great.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a buck, the cultist miniature in Legendary Evils is a great generic spellcaster.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players play dominated characters. Just ensure they act as their master wishes. Some players really love this chance.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add two monsters for every character you have in an encounter above five. One monster isn't enough to push the battle difficulty.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: On a Mac, Shift Control Command 4 lets you screengrab the monster stat block from the monster builder or the D&D compendium.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use twine to tie scroll props. It makes them look authentic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use authentic images from the internet for handouts. Aztec sacrifical artwork makes for great creepy findings in an ancient tomb.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Travel lite to your game. You probably only need your character sheet and a PHB. Don't bother grabbing all those books.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A subscription to D&D Insider can save you a lot of money if you don't buy all the books. Who really needs every "power" book?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure your players are paying attention during the character's turn right before them. Let them preroll their attack and damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Buy cheap $2 whiteboards for your players. Have them write attack and damage for the DM on the board and hold it up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep 3x5 cards handy to give secret notes to players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Secretly let a player know they're dominated. Hand out multiple notes to make it impossible to tell who.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Work on your dynamic voice projection. Nothing can steal a game's energy than a mumbling DM.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a few minutes at the beginning of some sessions to talk about the player group and what bonds them together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be like @wilw. Come up with your own Oath of Enmity whether it be authentic elven or a cutting dwarven insult.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: think about the forked decisions you'll offer in upcoming games. Forks are the middle ground between sandboxes and rails.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll for skill checks often, even if you have a story element you plan on just  telling to the party. Don't just give it to them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid in the epic tier to make big changes or as quoted from the high level talk "Go ahead and blow up Vulcan."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a few 3x5 cards, one for each scene, with talking points and decision trees for your night's adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't always put all your monsters out at once. Put them out in waves. Don't hesitate to attack from behind or ambush a campfire.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Firegiant miniatures work very well for enlarged Duergar.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: it's a good time to find props for your game at the local party store with Halloween coming. Prices are best after Oct 31 however.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to maintain a relaxed and neutral DM style. Save your emotion for your NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remind players that immediate actions of their PCs require their attention off of their turn. Don't remind them if they miss it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to call a battle early, but do so in game terms. Turn them into minions or have them flee or escape.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't tell players  if you make something easier or harder on the fly. Don't tell them you did it even afterwards.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: give your party a nice tricky riddle-based puzzle when you have to go pee.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get your game table fully prepped before your players show up to save time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let people take a quick break before your third encounter. We call it the "second encounter stretch". yaaawwwnnn.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't need a million dice at your table. Four or five of each type is enough. Mix the colors for multiple attacks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Outline minor quests for each of your players to keep them engaged in the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make sure to have significant choices for your players every two or three games. Make them big ones without clear outcomes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider the game "Mass Effect" for meaningful NPC dialog. It's rare to see a game with such a widespread plotline.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running a Demilich, remember the Soul Drain is the primary attack. Damage almost doesn't matter. Keep Soul Draining! #dnd
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix open map and dungeon encounters to give your players a variety of battlefields.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use minions for your battles without battle maps. They're easier to run without seeing it on the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have you reviewed your player goal chart today?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch "Fifth Element" to get yourself into the mood and steal some details for Sharn, the City of Towers in Eberron.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid zone effects that immobilize or stun. They're very sticky and players will often remain stuck for a long time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stagger your action and storytelling in your game. Like "Walker, Texas Ranger", always have a fist fight every 12 minutes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stand up to keep yourself and your players full of energy. Move around and be dynamic at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write 3x5 "situational motivator" cards for your players ala "Syndoche, New York". "Your intelligent sword speaks of your death".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Update your minions with increased damage from the DMG2.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let some ongoing damage stack to break through PC resistances. Use sparingly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in monsters with varying elemental damage types to avoid complete negation due to resistances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running an epic-level one-shot game, plan for 2 hour battles. It's fun, but the battles are looong.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players a +1 roleplaying bonus for creative insults against your monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let PCs and NPCs wrest control of a huge construct or elemental monster with in-combat skill challenges.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write out your treasure parcels on a 3x5 card and check them off as you run your adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the "Greater Good" motivation for a PC decision tree. Will they commit a clearly evil act for a greater good?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the "Needs of the Many" decision tree: Will your players save the city or the one NPC they've grown to love?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need to make your players cry? Try puppies, deer, penguins, and unicorns. Disney's been exploiting this for 50 years.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the "self sacrifice" decision tree. Will your PCs sacrifice something they love to prevent a great evil?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: On your game table, use a black tablecloth and stick boxes underneath to create a non-level playing area.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Now is your last chance this season to load up on halloween props and models for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask for your players Epic Destiny choices in the middle of the paragon tier so you can build your story around their choices.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: use these wedding decor lights to light up your Dwarven Forge. From Michael's.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have other players choose a PC's surname or nickname. Try to steer away from out-of-character silliness.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every adventuring party needs a good party name. Let the group play a few adventures before choosing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always consider what possible terrain powers your encounter might provide. Use the powers on p. 63 of DMG2 as examples.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a change, have a monster that can switch between statues of itself placed throughout an encounter area.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider adding a terrain effect when a solo creature becomes bloodied. For example, a red dragon creates lava pits when bloodied.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember that daze, blind, stun, and knocked prone grants combat advantage. Optimize creature mixes to take advantage of this.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember, a good DM is a facilitator for group storytelling. Don't laugh maniacally when a PC turns to stone.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Legos as an alternative to tiles and figures for #DnD.   (via @4E_DnD_DM)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up a buddy system to pair up ADD players with players who pay attention so they can work as a team.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Promote the adoption of pets but ensure the pet doesn't take up a turn. How about a squirrel familiar that grants +1 perception?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players for their character's theme song. A theme song can go a long way to define a character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A Shadar-kai bard would definitely look like Iggy Pop. "Search and Destroy" is a good theme song for this character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Michael's, the hobby store, has some good miniature accessories during halloween. Look for spider webs and small piles of skulls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A level+8 single non-elite makes for an interesting and fast solo battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Buy some spare costume jewelry to act as a lich's phylactery or other magical items. Props are always good.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the "Now or Future?" decision tree: Will your players take an advantage now or take it later?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build out a detailed room but don't stage a battle in it. Use it for clues or a skill challenge to make your players paranoid.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build your encounter design checklist: monsters, setting, terrain, environmental effects, flavor text, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't push your game beyond your planned time if you finish early. Leave your group hungry for more.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Finish in the middle of an exciting battle or right at the beginning. Leave your players excited to return.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you're going to run a D&D one-shot adventure, seriously consider running it in the heroic tier. Ideally level 3 to 6.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players a battle or two with lower-level creatures so they can feel truly powerful.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask yourself if you've given each player character a chance to shine recently. Add in encounters focused on each PC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Establish and post clear table rules for your D&D game like the rules they have for Craps in Vegas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Encourage your players to take camera-phone pics of your game and post them to the net. It helps all of us get better.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to mess with the math a bit in your game. Just try it out behind the screen first.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay special attention to monster auras, immediates, and bloodied reactions. They're very easy to forget.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a black poster board and blue sticky tack for your poster maps so you can just lay them down when needed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Buy some tea-lights and wedding chime LED lights at Michael's to light up your Dwarven Forge. They work well with fake cobwebs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the PCs reputation in their primary city or town as a motivator. Will they hurt their reputation for some quick gains?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read a few modules ahead so you can drop seeds in for future plot-lines.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players a battle where they get to coordinate a defense or attack of a stronghold.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Encourage the use of a dice-rolling box to prevent d20s from flying all over the room and getting eaten by dogs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down a dozen or so NPC names from a baby name book to keep on hand. You don't need a huge list all the time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget about diseases. They're good to keep your players on their toes outside of combat and for failed skill challenges.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Page 42 DMG limited high damage can make for a suitable end to a failed skill challenge. It's less hated than taking surges.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try using a single initiative roll and order for an entire night's worth of encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: not every battle has to be against a perfectly sized group of monsters. Throw out a single elite or pack of roaming minions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use 5x8 cards to print from the Monster Builder and print your room descriptions. They're handy at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pick out a theme, even a minor one, for every night's worth of adventure. What is their immediate goal?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Catch up on your Hitchcock before running an Eberron game: "Man Who Knew too Much" and "North by Northwest" are classics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Switch a dracolich's stuns to dazes for most of its attacks except the roar. Players hate stuns. Give him a bloodied nec aura.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stop reading so many forums, blogs, and tweets. Go work on making your adventure more fun for your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For fast and furious battles, average out monster damage instead of rolling dice for normal monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't get too caught up in your own storyline - remember this is your players' story, not yours!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't fall to deus-ex machina when your group is captured and held prisoner. Work with the players to find an escape they control.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't plan your campaign further out than the next two adventures. Let the story grow organically from the actions of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't bore your friends with tales of your D&D adventure. It's like talking about your child's poopie diapers. No one cares.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't run a solo creature by itself above level 10. At paragon and above, a single solo creature will get destroyed quickly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid running skill challenges at the end of your nightly game. Most players want a big battle and quick conclusion.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Come up with your campaign's "elevator pitch" - a single sentence that describes your story. If you can't it's too complicated.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Losing the attention of one of your players? Come up with an on-the-spot character hook to reel them back in. Why do THEY care?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Having trouble bringing your players into your world? Find pop culture references that get them excited or entertain them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find out what fiction your players enjoy reading or watching. Find ways to bring that into the story you're running.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the components of a trap and let your player talk about how they're going to screw with it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Starting your PCs out as agents of an Eberron noble house is a great break from the "you all meet in a bar" PC origin.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always check your monsters' aura powers. For some, like Draconic Wraiths, they are the bulk of the monster's cool factor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A great character naming resource (via @unclebear)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always be careful with betrayal in your game. Some might think its cool, but some may really hate it. Especially PC betrayal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: DMG2 p 202-203 has a great list of Sigil's notable NPCs with many built in hooks. Use it for character driven Sigil adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the number of new NPCs you introduce to five or less. Too many and your players will never remember them. Three is preferred.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Print out Quest and NPC cheat-sheets for your players to make it easy for them to remember who is who and what they need to do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Mega-Mini's "Dungeon Decor" to spice up your Dwarven Forge setups. Good dungeons are in the details.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use household items as physical props in your dungeon. A flower vase with some lights in it quickly becomes a soul-well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on developing NPCs rather than stories. Let the story build out from the collisions of your PCs and NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a PC skill-matrix spreadsheet to keep track of your PCs and their skills and develop challenges based on their choices.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider Stephen King's favorite 10 villains as models for your nastiest NPCs:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Learn to love page 42 in the DMG and on your DM screen. Use it for ad-hoc challenges or random damage done to or by the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put a dot in your rulebooks next to rules changed with the  WOTC errata. A red dot can tell you which rules are out of date.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Come up with a theme song for your arch-villains. Get your players used to it so they recognize it before the villain shows up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider the physical mechanics of traps. How would an ancient spike-trap still work after 10,000 years of neglect?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep track of diseases. They are one of the few mechanics that last after extended rests. Don't forget about them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Print monsters from the Monster builder on 5x8 index cards. They print perfectly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Treat your artifacts and intelligent items like NPCs. Give them goals, backgrounds, and character arcs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider all of the character choices in Dragon Age and how they still manage to fit into a linear story. Mimic this in your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all game music needs to be instrumental. Don't be afraid to have a bar scene with Lady Gaga's "Poker Face".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: give your players a familiar home base they can return to. It should be comfortable and relaxing like an old pair of shoes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: James Bond shootouts show great ways to shake up an battle's environment. Consider the sinking building shootout in Casino Royale.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: trading card wallet pages for ring binders can store up to 54 small (1x1, to 4x1) dungeon tiles per page! (via @prax3des)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give powerful dragons and other memorable solos the "heroslayer" trait from the Heroslaying Hydra: +2 att, +5 dam vs markers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give dragons a ranged breath weapon that shares their breath refresh. Make it burst 2 within 10. Scare your ranged attackers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get over the idea that you're game is Shakespeare. Think Roadhouse, not Gone with the Wind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When putting together adventures or one-shots, farm the encounters in Open grave, Draconomicon 1 & 2, and Dungeon Delve for ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your PCs a home base and return to it often. It gives them a familiar place to put up their feet after their adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to give your players at least one meaningful choice in an adventure with no pre-determined conclusion.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Too many choices can make the game less enjoyable. Don't overburden your PCs with too many decisions to make.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to get a hold of the D&D Game Day character cards. They're absolutely fabulous for one-shot games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always try to keep beholders within 5 squares of the main force of the PCs. Beholders in small rooms make for formidable allies.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Storming an evil bar and then defending that bar from an attack can be a good change of pace from dungeon delving.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Save pictures of fantasy art you really like so you can use it as a handout in future games. Keep a D&D scrap book.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good silver or iron dragon miniature can stand-in for many of the metallic dragons. Likewise with bronze dragon minis.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There are too many powers for any DM to verify. Institute an "audit thy neighbor" policy to ensure people aren't overstepping.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Skeleton, ghoul, and vampire spawn minis make for great foes from level 1 to 30. Buy a bunch of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time every so often to  consider what the evil masterminds in your campaign are doing right now.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The excellent Fantastic Terrain in The Planes Below can work well anywhere. It also scales at the heroic, paragon, and epic tiers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always gauge your players' interest in a skill challenge. If they get bored - end it!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to email descriptions of what else is going on in your campaign world. It doesn't all need to be first person.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: round glass candle holders make for great props for crystal balls and other strange artifacts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to add 20 levels onto a heroic creature you really enjoyed. The monster builder makes it easy to scale monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to run a single battle on your gaming night. It doesn't always need to be two or three. Leave some time to relax.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read or plan ahead and think of some ways to foreshadow the coming of a great evil or a new campaign setting. Foreshadow Dark Sun!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Design a protective shield around your big elite boss NPC broken only with a skill challenge to slow down his or her death.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Look for fun moments of cooperative storytelling at all times. If a player blurts out a shift in story, consider working with it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin fantastic terrain from the DMG and Planes Below to fit the theme of your encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your epic-level players their own airship or floating island in the Elemental Chaos as a base of operations. Think fantastic!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have your players come up with names and backgrounds for their own new weapons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a mix of player-selected items, story-focused items, random items, and item tokens for loot in your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Does a PC have a big moment coming? Try using a music playlist based on that PC selected by that player.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players a lot of different quests, each with a well-designed quest card so they can keep track of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When using published adventures, don't be afraid to replace NPCs with those already known and loved (or hated) by your PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try out a Stephen King style and foretell coming events: "That was the last time you saw your home town before it burned."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Cross-train your RPG reading with King's "On Writing", Tharps "Creative Habit", and Edwards' "Drawing on the Right Side o/t Brain"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take time to customize encounters from published adventures around your players and their strengths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make it easy for players to flank opponents when not using a battle map so they don't feel cheated and want the grid back.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful of monsters with stun effects. Players hate to miss an entire round of combat. Consider bonus damage, weaken, or daze.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a spymaster NPC on your PC's side that delivers them dossiers on key villains. Helps your players keep track.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have you checked and updated your Robin Laws player motivation spreadsheet this month?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to make every battle important. Don't have a battle that's just filler especially if time is limited.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make it easy for absent players to come back or they won't come back at all. Give them some exp while they were away.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Game cancelled because of snow? Email your players for short RP stories on their character's activities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running in a set gameworld, make sure that world's key differentiators are often seen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Encourage the use of ad-hoc terrain powers by using DMG p. 42 high-limited damage and only requiring a minor action to use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hitchcock movies make great seeds for adventures. Check out The Birds, Notorious, Man Who Knew Too Much, and Rear Window.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your narration short. Mix it up with skill checks and combat whenever possible to keep people involved.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Google Image Search, Elfwood, and Deviantart are all great places to dig up fantasy artwork for your campaign and characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give solos an extra standard action each turn to make them even more threatening.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Check out @newbieDM's awesome video for building 3d terrain with dungeon tiles:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a great campaign idea ask yourself, "What if Galadriel had taken the ring of power?"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the Nycademon's grab and fly power to drag tasty soft-armored wizards and strikers high up into the air - and them drop them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The battle at Balin's Tomb in Lord of the Rings makes a great two-battle encounter: dozens of minions and then a solo cave troll.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players build out their own fortress of solitude. Change it or upgrade it each tier.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In RPGs, Rule of Cool trumps all rules. If a player wants to do something awesome, make the rules work (via @chattydm)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give quests to your villains. It makes them come to life in your story when they have motion and motivation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remain open minded when running skill challenges. Default to letting your players DO things rather than limiting them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a brutal battle? Set up an encounter under the effect of the Weeping Lady (Underdark pg. 64) +1/2 level damage, 1/2 healing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask yourself if you're being biased at all towards one of your players or another. Try to remain even headed at all times.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give surprise rounds as rewards for successful skill challenges. Give them to monsters on failures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be specific when roleplaying. Write down key notes for any NPC you're going to step into. Goals and attitudes are key.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The soundtracks to Battlestar Galactica make for some great heart-racing D&D music. Check it out on iTunes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players plenty of opportunities to use the character features they like the best. Don't eliminate them very often.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The perception of choice is often as fun as a real choice itself. Just don't tip your hand.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players fill out their fortress of solitude with cool "Wonderous Lair" items from the Adventurer's Vault 2.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask yourself if the environment you set up for an encounter is fun for the players. It shouldn't just be a detriment to them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players decide their PC's fate at the end of a campaign. You might even promote play-by-email continuations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time making sure your bosses will work the way you want. Don't just grab them from the Monster Manual without tuning.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a nasty undead beast like the old level-drainers? Give them a disease on hit that stacks -2s to attack each failure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use email as a method to run quests for individual PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you can find them, Deathcap and Arcane Ballista miniatures can make for some great environmentals / terrain power pieces.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to force your game to be a certain way. If you're group is out for a laughing good time, make it so.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't have to use D&D minis. Wacraft minis and McFarlane Toys can work just fine in many circumstances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every magic weapon should have a cool name and at least a sentence or two of background. Where did it come from?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Powerful Solos should have some interesting effect when they become bloodied. Earthquakes, avalanches, or tidal waves of fire!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Making an enounter more WoW-like isn't always a bad thing. A lot of designers spent time on those battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about conversation trees in your roleplaying ala Mass Effect 2. How can conversations fork your storyline?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force skill challenges and roleplaying. Sometimes your group just wants to fight!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stay on your feet to keep your game energetic. It will keep you awake and keep your roleplaying interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spread status effect attacks across your players. Don't "immobilize" the same player over and over even if it makes sense.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always add something exciting to your terrain that your players will WANT to mess with. Don't make it all bad for them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try using Living Forgotten Realms cards in your home campaign as extra rewards.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did your monsters hear the PCs coming? Give them a round of readied actions!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use room positioning as a reward for a skill challenge. Give your PCs the high ground if they succeed or at a disadvantage if not.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your beholder a swiss-cheese room where they can travel through tunnels in any direction. Got this from @davethegame.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give battles alternative objectives to simple killing. Assassinations, number of rounds before exploding, rescues, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For some wacky fun, make combats more like skill challenges and skill challenges more like combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes it helps to write your own unseen background stories. What actually happened 500,000 years ago in that tomb? #dnd
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce your campaign villain at level one. Have Orcus show up in a town and wreak havoc! Revenge is a great motivator.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give certain monsters a penetration ability to burrow through resistances once they've seen it in action. Reverse "variable" res.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give solos a lot of environmental effects they can manipulate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try an encounter with invulnerable minions until a challenge has been passed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give a monster a grab-and-toss ability to make use of interesting environmental effects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try giving a +3 bonus when four PCs have a single creature flanked. It makes them fight hard for positioning.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to choke points in your battle space. They can be challenging or totally boring if mis-used.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget - D&D isn't about fun, this is about killing PCs. If you haven't killed at least three PCs last month, you failed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Promote ad-hoc environmental powers using page 42. Make env powers trigger with minor actions so players will use them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have fun with surprise burrowing creatures popping up in the middle of a party, sending them scrambling.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ranged minions can be far more dangerous than melee minions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a player comes up with a plot twist, try to jump on it and make it part of the story. Let the story grow organically.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change minion elemental damage with normal damage or it will often be fully resisted.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the Death Dealer critical hit tables (or make your own) as an environmental effect similar to Blood Rock.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a quick skirmish battle that goes fast? Use fewer monsters but up their damage by +5 per tier.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a quick skirmish battle that goes fast? Use fewer monsters but up their damage by +5 per tier.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about how your monsters got into the environment. Can a pack of kobolds live sealed in a dungeon for 1000 years? How?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Inverse of yesterday's tip, ignore how monsters got into a place and have fun with a true Gygaxian dungeon experience!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about how the mechanics of your trap skill challenges work. Sit down and design it, don't just hand-wave it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Defeat doesn't always mean death. Have defeated monsters turn into conversational NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up some achievements for your gaming group. Who did the most total damage? Most single-target damage? Who took the most?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a really challenging battle, don't allow a short rest between two fights. Put your PCs against the wall!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus your creative time on making your next session really cool. Don't spend too much on the long range plan of your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your adventures with a bit of action. Too much storytelling and skill challenging up front might put people to sleep.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Come up with an environmental power to do high damage to solos at a cost if you want to speed up a solo battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get your NPC character models from everywhere. Sons of Anarchy, Deadwood, Breaking Bad, Dexter, they can all work!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The chase can make for a great fun skill challenge. Just ensure you make the details clear.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have each player pick a theme song. When  that song comes up on your playlist, they get a free standard action on their next turn.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a cool movie clip that sets the stage or atmosphere for your campaign or adventure? Show it but keep it short.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For an extra challenge, put unholy relics in a room that prevent the use of healing surges until defeated with a skill challenge.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you're playing an old module or adventure, double-check those DCs to ensure they're in line with recent errata.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use @newbiedm's list of @wizards_dnd #dndenc effects in your own game with a random roll:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget about lightning effects. Make darkness an effect that matters!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write up and email some short flash fiction to show what happened to minor NPCs the party encountered.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: use plastic sheet protectors for your one-shot char sheets so you can use them again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: keep a dungeon delve, tiles, pregens, and minis ready in case you have a spontaneous game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: keep your one-shots below level ten to keep the game a little simpler.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: run a one-shot game with PHB3 classes so your players can try out the new classes -
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch out for solos more than 2 levels higher than the party. They're going to be a slogfest unless you prepare for it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The huge Chain Golem makes a great mini for Codricuhn, the Blood Storm:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your D&D Dungeon Tiles (in separate ziploc bags so you can pull from each set independently.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your adventures with a bit of action. Too much storytelling and skill challenging up front might put people to sleep.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Today's errata didn't nerf a minion's ability to aid an attack. Stack four minions on someone to give a boss +8 to attack!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: take a red marker and mark anything in your books that's been errata'd in the updates.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to beef up your powerful solo? Turn all of its actions into minor actions to give them more powerful attacks per round.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you're having trouble getting people excited about skill challenges, try using them during combat to change the encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Small poker chips can work as monster tokens in a pinch. Get three colors and write on them with a marker.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use random #dndenc encounter alterations in your own home game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try using the detective-show crime investigative trope as a campaign path.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Playing Eberron? Give your PCs a choice of being mercenaries, investigators, or artifact hunters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Here's an awesome story title generator, great for adventure ideas:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Defending an area can make for a fun multi-battle encounter. Give the PCs a chance to build up their defenses.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a ballroom battle? Use a crashing chandelier as an encounter power: level+3 vs reflex; medium limited damage and knock prone.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have players roll skill checks off of their turn to discover bits of information during a battle and keep them involved.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a more dangerous beholder, don't count the eyestalk aura as an attack when determining mark penalties.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get the required components for your next game done early so you have time for your creative juices to flow into it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: avoid the "destiny" plot motivator. It's no fun to think you have no control over the outcome.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: avoid deus ex machina when introducing gods into your game. The players should still be the center of the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Save the ink and use a computer or tablet to display DDI adventures. The ink cost alone  makes an adventure about $10.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to modify a monster to fit your party's experience level. Avoid making epic beasts too easy though.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dig into your Lovecraft to pick up strange and interesting ways to describe the Far Realm:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: things going slow during your RP \ skill challenge? Keep things moving by throwing out items of interest.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use psionic powers from PHB3 as monster abilities to recreate the psionic abilities of old-school D&D monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give some off-camera background stories in email to give your players a wider view of their story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write and keep a checklist of the things you need to put together a night's game. Check it two days before your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When making an NPC or villain, sit back, close your eyes, and imagine what he or she is seeing and feeling.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scale environmental effect damage by 5 damage per tier. An epic pool of lava should do 15 damage when someone steps in it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write short stories in email showing your players the unseen worldly and NPC reactions of their actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes your villain think they're actually a good guy? What good do they believe they are doing?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Model your fantasy towns and cities after the economics of real medieval castles and cities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your Eberron campaign off right by making your PCs choose one of three houses to ally with.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fire giant minis work well for death giants, animated statues, and enlarged Duergar in a pinch.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: McFarlane toys and WoW minis work well for monstrous D&D miniatures:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget to have loot and experience ready to hand out at the end of your game. It's sadly easy to forget.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Forget experience points. Level PCs on the adventures met, the quests completed, and the encounters defeated.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of random one-shots, build one-shots that fill out a piece of the main campaign story as yet untold.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Treat Demogorgon as two different and often competing NPCs instead of as a single entity.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: War devils can be used as Pit Fiends if you don't want to pay the high price:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Designate your table's rules lawyer as the official rules arbiter, but only if he or she is fair as well as annoying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Damaging auras are a great way to power up weaksause Solos. Try 5 dam per tier scaling  to 10 per tier when bloodied.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Philip Seymour Hoffman's character in Mission Impossible 3 makes for a great sinister villain archetype.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider James Bond-style introductions - prefaces full of action that might only be superfluously related to the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always give the players a chance for success even if a villainous NPC succeeds in a plot. Players hate losing and wasting time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if you dont use the card-over-the-screen trick, 3x5 cards folded in half work well for a fully-visible initiative order.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch the show Breaking Bad for ideas in character development, organic plotlines, and off-stage storytelling.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember that skill challenges fall between using regular skill checks and full-roleplaying sessions. Don't overuse them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a specific approach when building skill challenges. Disarming an doomsday trap is more specific than exploring caverns.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When characters fall off of high places, consider different repercussions than falling to their death. Catch footing after 5d10?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember not to run a monster more than 4 levels higher than your PCs. They might still win but it will take hours.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When customizing monsters, think about what makes that monster unique. Example; vampires have dominate, enervate, transformations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch out for too many dazes and weakens - they generally just slow down a battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a player looks bored, ask them to roll a skill check to learn something interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if monster identification skills take an action, have the players roll them off-turn while someone else is up. Saves time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stuck trying to make a map? Use one of the delve maps from Dungeon Delve, Planes Below, or Planes Above with different monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pipe cleaners and Alea Tools magnets don't play nice together. Stick to bottle rings for marks and conditions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Githyanki are all about the psionics. Find lots of ways to show how this type of power is different from arcane magic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The purple worm mini can work well for the Hundred-Hands abhorrant from Plane Above ( )
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Copy and hand out the last two pages of the #dnd Players Strategy Guide entitled "Don't Be A Jerk" to all of your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you want a status effect penalty that won't slow the game down, give PCs -4 to defenses instead of -4 to attacks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: cut-up dark pillow cases work well to cover up your 3D battle maps before the battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Resking Forsaken from the Monster Manual 3 ( ) into high-level vampires.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The time to worry about how long your game is running is during the first battle, not the last battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Thunderblast Cyclone miniature can be useful for environmental effects too:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The white gargantuan dragon works well for a wraith dragon or a dracolich.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let two of your players roll their attacks at the same time to speed things along.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use statistics from equally leveled Monster Manual 3 creatures to recalculate stats for older monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have players write action types and triggers with a big marker at the top of their power cards so they don't forget.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use unhallowed ground as Fantastic Terrain that removes undead radiant vulnerability until it is blessed with religion checks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players a status effect choice: Shake off stuns but take 20 damage? Break immobilize but take ongoing 15? Hard choices!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a minion with some survivability? Try making minion swarms immune to everything but bursts or blasts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Opposite from yesterday: Try making an armored minion that can ONLY be hit by direct attacks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: use MM3 solos as a model for older ones. What do they do differently when they're bloodied?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 5 damage per tier is a good basic building block for damaging terrain effects. Keep it with your page 42 charts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need a fictional character archetype for your crazy drunken dwarf? Try Calamity Jane from Deadwood.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider the comic book or movie Planet Hulk as a mini campaign idea for Dark Sun:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a monster tougher than the PCs can handle? Double damage output on creatures 5 levels above to show they hit too hard.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't run the standard Dracolich as written. Too much necrotic to resist and too many stuns. Modify or run a later variant.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not sure how to end your campaign? You could do far worse than a montage like Six Feet Under:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a player looks bored, ask them to roll a skill check to learn something interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Oreos make great action points but your players will end up using them pretty quick.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful at level 1. Level 1 characters are very fragile. Don't attempt to challenge them too much too early.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: challenge is inversely proportional to level. Go easy below level 10 and get tough above level 10 to keep the pace right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Come up with creative ways to build 3D terrain. You don't HAVE to have dwarven forge. Put tiles up on blocks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always watch your players' reactions to the battle. Are they angry and stressed for the right reasons or the wrong ones?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of your favorite fantastic terrain from the various sourcebooks. The right terrain makes a battle unique.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Watchmen soundtrack makes for some great #dnd music. Spice it up with some Dylan if you dare.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put one big decision in front of your group each session. Make it matter and don't favor one answer over the other.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Oldie but goodie: Use sticky tack and black poster boards to build dungeon tile rooms ahead of time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have players roll the recharges on monster powers so the others will blame someone other than you when Orcus kills them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Push your players to say when they're "done" at the end of their turn to keep things moving along.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid for a powerful monster to cast bursts or blasts on his own guys in order to hit a lot of players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't put TOO many environmental effects, fantastic terrain, or environmental powers into one encounter. Three is about the max.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch out for wraiths. Players can really hate them. Use them sparingly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Heroslayer mechanic from the Heroslayer Hydra works well for other monsters. Great way to deal with marks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to write in the new errata damage amounts into your books and modules. Small-point Sharpies work well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never run a solo alone in a Paragon or Epic game. It will just get ganged up on and destroyed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have your minions explode in a poisonous, acidic, necrotic, blinding gas. Now your players don't really WANT to kill them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Above paragon, start asking whether your player is going to interrupt monster actions rather than having to retrofit them in.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Channel your inner 14 year old when building out your adventures. What sort of stuff did you like back then?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give out quests to your group to defeat major villains. Write these up like wanted posters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add fewer bigger dice to make an attack more swingy and lots of little dice to make the cut more accurate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: With the new monster damage charts, worry less about temp hit points, free healing, or player resists trivializing your monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just because all of your monsters are statistically the same doesn't mean your players need to know that. Pretend one's a boss.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: find ways to make the mechanics of your traps clear. Describe how the massive pump draws a torrent of blood into the room.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Speed up combat with an angry gas. Any creature within it grants combat advantage and vulnerable 5 but gains +1d6 dam per tier.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need to challenge your epic-tier party? Send three waves of encounters with no short rests. Change the environment to keep it fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: People arguing about the rules of your monsters or environments? Bring them back with in-game flavorful descriptions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't just call a battle over when it gets long. Have a plan to finish a battle early that makes sense in the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The power of an extra PC above five grows stronger every level. An extra level 26 PC is much more powerful than an extra level 6.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running skill challenges, stay loose and relaxed. Gauge the table and modify as needed to keep them fun. Make them yours.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: We all make mistakes when running a D&D game. Relax and move on - we'll all get better every game we run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep an online "hook journal" for your group so they can keep track of what possible directions they can go as a group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players meaningful choices: they can kill the big bad guy or save the maiden but not both. (from @chattydm)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about defining hooks as hooks for your group. Sometimes people want a clearer idea where they can go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the story guide your skill challenge, not some X / 3 mechanic. Story leads mechanics, not the other way (from @chrisssims)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a dungeon room like Legend of Zelda. Don't be afraid to steal a room DIRECTLY from Zelda. (from @davethegame)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You could do worse than building your villain or NPC off of the character Godric from True Blood. 2000 year-old vampire loses self
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add degrees of success and failure on your DC check rolls. You can use the low / med / high chart as degrees of success.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Adventure seed: PCs investigate a derelict Chaos Ship that has been buried under a town for 100,000 years. Think Tommyknockers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use brothers or twins or a coven of three witches instead of a single boss to avoid a single boss getting ganged up on in combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Halloween stores are beginning to show up. Load up on cheap props and fake spider webbing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be nice to your PCs in Heroic, be even handed with them at Paragon, be a bastard to them in Epic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: One thing my article on solo monsters forgot: Every solo monster should change somehow when bloodied.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Inanimate objects that radiate death make great powerful bosses. You can't stun a pillar!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build in mechanics and monster powers to scale your encounter difficulty up or down as a battle progresses.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want an alternate skill challenge system? Take a look at the Obsidian system:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you give your elite or solo a way to shake conditions, make sure it's a "no action" action. This works with stunned and uncon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have dragons use the Chamber of Vulnerability ritual to create vulnerable environmental sections:
