author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: At higher levels, award experience based on effort, not the encounter budget.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to have at least one meaningful choice in every game you run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As @davethegame proved, even getting screwed by your HOA can make for a good adventure seed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider limiting character generation to specific published sources that fit your campaign theme to avoid game-breaking combos.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep your DM cheat sheet handy at your game:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: All solos above level 11 should have a no-action way to remove status effects or they'll be paralyzed for an entire fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider limiting a high-level one-shot game to D&D Essentials only.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a break, have your players run a group of your NPCs as they have an adventure related to your main story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Orcus mini also makes for an awesome cultist statue:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry too much about tracking status effects on monsters. Players keep very good track of them on their own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Design environments that match your heroes's status. Level 15 PCs shouldn't still be hunting down lost farm maids.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider limiting sources for character building in one-shot high level games. Essentials only for example.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about the mechanics of a trap. How does it work and how does it reset itself? How does it still work after 10,000 years?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use superhero comic storylines as seeds for epic-tier games. PCs are more like the Justice Leage than the Fellowship now.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every monster above level 11 published before the MM3 needs its damage updated using the July update:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try having both puzzle and skill-challenge ways to get around a trap. Let players choose the way they get around the trap.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Surge stealing can get old. Try custom diseases or other penalties to mimic life-draining. 1/2 healing, vulnerable 5, -2 to defs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In-battle skill challenges that require PCs be adjacent can help bring them into a room they might be apprehensive of.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember, most of my desires to drop the hammer on PCs comes at paragon and above. Heroic PCs are much more easily killed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give older solos some sort of effect when bloodied. Doubling aura damage is an easy way if not too creative.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Strimko puzzles with symbols replacing numbers  can make for fun in-game puzzles:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a notebook on you and jot down ideas for NPCs, encounter areas, story seeds, etc. Good ideas come from everywhere.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: To scare your powergamers, hit them with fearsome status effects: 1/2 healing,  vulnerability 20, scaling ongoing damage
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: With Halloween over, it's time to go pick up your fake spider webbing and other props at your local party store!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When restrained and teleported, the restrain goes away if it was physical but stays on you if it was mental. Rules Comp p 214
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider using Essentials-only characters for higher level one-shot adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Re-skin environmental effects from the Dark Sun Creature Catalog for use in any campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal stories, encounters, and puzzles liberally from your favorite games including Final Fantasy or Dragon Age.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players roll for their treasure using the new treasure rewards in the Rule Compendium.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the old-school feel of Essentials characters to convince your group to try an Essentials-only mini-campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Stone Giant miniature in Lords of Madness (an inexpensive uncommon mini) makes a great statue or stone golem as well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Do you have your adventure builder checklist in hand before you start building adventures?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The heroslayer hydra mini might stand in well for a Tiamat aspect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running a high-level one-shot adventure? Try sticking to just #dnd Essentials characters to keep it balanced.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customizing a monster? Make sure to add in some choice mechanics. Take 30 damage to remove stun as a free action for example.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get your NPC ideas from everywhere. Don't overuse fantasy characters, steal from Mad Men or Sons of Anarchy if you want.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to do too much at once in a game. Run fewer awesome encounters instead of many mediocre ones.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a companion char or two ready at your PC's level in your game just in case @matt_james_rpg doesn't show.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When designing ancient mechanical traps, remember that big components would last longer than small components.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Three things to consider with traps: For whom was it originally intended? How did it last all this time? How does it reset?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your magic item vendors a couple of random uncommon items to spice things up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have players group powers by standards, minors, moves, and immediates. Fewer choices = faster turns.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can still combine multiple treasure hoards together when using the random treasure tables in the Rules Compendium or DMK.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Monsters don't scale up too well against level 1 characters. Go easy on them and use monsters no higher than level 2.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Auras are the best friend of epic-tier solos. Auras ignore status effects completely and rarely require a hit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Houserule the beholder's triggered eye attack so that it doesn't trigger defender marks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running E3, Prince of Undeath? Dig up a copy of Throne of Bloodstone and consider thematics from that Orcus focused adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try running #gammaworld as a ten session one-level-per-session mini campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Ravenloft board game has lots of cool minis to use in your campaign. The wraiths make awesome ice liches.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always seek opportunites to add theatric descriptions to fun random events. Describe returns from near death or wild combo attacks
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pick up the Monster Manual 3 and the Demonomicon for epic-level updated monsters to go along with your Monster Vault.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Demonomicon is probably the best book for planning out your epic-tier campaign. It's full of all sorts of nasty stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When your whole group is doing a bunch of damage at once, assign a player the job of tallying it together and giving the total.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add choices to your nastier status effects: Stunned or take ongoing 10 psychic per tier. Immobilized or 2d8+12 dam to rip free.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Flame snakes and fiendish snakes make for a variety of great monsters. Pick up four of each.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need a powerful level 33 Dracolich ? Use the "Dragon of Tyr" stats from the Dark Sun Creature Catalog.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Can't explain the layers of the Abyss? Watch the multiple-dream layers of Inception for an idea:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never fall in love with your monsters and always accept that their destiny is to die.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always have a lifeline prepared in case of a TPK. Make failure as interesting as success and you will not fear their deaths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get creative with weapons. "short sword" can be as abstract as the Gamma World "one hand melee" weapon type.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: At level 15+ there's no such thing as a tough boss monster. Protect them with minions and skill challenges.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: After 100 sessions the two biggest speed boosts I found are fully-visible initiative cards and visible monster defenses.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Planning for two runs against your big boss lets you feel out his or her stats in one battle so you can prep for the other.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In Gamma World, you can steal NPC types from anywhere. Just roll up their origins to see how weird they might be.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always try to give every PC a chance to really shine every couple of adventures or so.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Of all my adventures, the one people remember the most was the city defense where they got to set up the defenses. Try it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your minis are looking a little warped or weapons are a little bent, use hot and cold water to soften and re-harden them right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of your game and encounters as a way for players to show off their PCs instead of a way to thwart them. 4e is about the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use published adventures as a loose theme. You don't have to run them rigidly, make them your own and use what works for you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin Monster Vault creatures by changing the flavor of their attacks rather than redesigning MM1 and 2 creatures from scratch.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In case you missed it, use @saveversusdeath's Dungeon Trick Generator to add spice to your encounters:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a sheet of 20x by 30x acrylic from Home Depot to place over your poster maps. It makes a huge difference.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tiny amounts of fake spider web you bought last Halloween can also dress up your undead miniatures to make them ghostly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Break up large battles into phases that change environmental effects, monster powers, or adds waves of minions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every solo above level 11 should have a way to get past daze and stun effects. Check out the dragons in the Monster Vault.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stuck in a boring meeting? Use the time by imagining and jotting down notes for some story seeds or NPC backgrounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use small in-battle skill challenges to get folks moving and protect your elite or solo bosses from getting killed too quickly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time before your players arrive to arrange all the materials you need to get right down to playing when they arrive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always pick up the cheaper more generic miniatures to fill out your collection. A handfull of orcs goes a long way.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to be a great DM? Be born in 1973 like @chattydm, @newbiedm, and I!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Print out and prepare quest cards so you can keep your group focused on the directions they want to go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend less time worrying about @wizards_dnd's business and more time making your own game awesome.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pick up some $1 or less Star Wars minis to fill out your Gamma World PC races.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running a Gamma World game, assign one of the players the duty of Alpha Mutation and Omega Tech distribution.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good paper cutter makes it much easier and neater to cut initiative cards, monster knowledge cards, power cards, and quest cards
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scale monsters up or down easily by adding +1 per level to all rolls and increasing hitpoints by 10 per level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Belloc from Raiders of the Lost Arc is an excellent NPC archetype. He has clear motivation and he's smart! Use him.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Learn from internet sage @davethegame and re-skin Monster Vault creatures for your Gamma World game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the musings of your players and turn those musings into formal quests with quest cards.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Google Maps to get a map of your local area, print it, and write in your own fantastic Gamma World locations for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking for a couple of good inspirational movies? Check out Brotherhood of the Wolf and Name of the Rose.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try running an encounter on the back of a great beast. Perhaps a battle on the backs of two dueling dragons!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider giving your pre-Monster Vault solos a free action attack that can instead remove stuns, dazes, or dominates.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The knocked prone status effect is one of the better ones. It isn't too debilitating but it still makes life more difficult.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to make something totally unique every time. Sometimes people just want to fight a room full of orcs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ogremoch from MM3 makes for a great final doomsday sort of boss. Reskin him into whatever world-ending big bad you have in mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can't go wrong digging into Michael's craft store for all sorts of interesting terrain and props.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try giving your solo a terrain-altering effect when it becomes bloodied. Pour out minions or add lava pits or both!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add conspiracy groups to your campaign to keep things interesting. Good become evil, evil become good, and PCs in the middle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Gnolls and Eladrin from the Monster Vault make for great mid-level Gamma World humanoid monster templates.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hand out a list of classes, races, and allowed sourcebooks at the beginning of your campaign to limit complexity. #toomanypowers
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a mobile DM kit in a small ziploc bag like you're a bank robber and this is your emergency geeky walk-away bag.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A few hours before running a game, go through the whole game in your head step by step to see if anything's missing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep your group rolling. If people start to look bored, do some group history or insight checks to reveal story bits.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't take over control of dominated PCs. Let players run the PC in the best interests of the dominator.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Tron Legacy soundtrack works well for a Gamma World high-tech soundtrack:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you don't have a lot of time to prep an adventure, jot down the important details on 3x5 cards so you remember them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dark Sun is the perfect campaign setting to give characters difficult choices with clear consequences either way.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need some powerful Epic-tier dragons? Check out the excellent Prismatic Dragon by @rjschwalb:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Beholder Gauth in the Monster Vault can be reskinned into an awesome alien or robotic probe in Gamma World.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every good Dark Sun game should begin with blood spraying in the arena.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Professor Moriarty of Sherlock Holmes might be a perfect villain. Model yours after him:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The instance bosses from World of Warcraft can be scraped for some pretty fun D&D encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Powerful villains should have some protection mechanism that can be disabled with skill challenges. Think healing fonts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A bit heuristic but go take a 30 minute walk without headphones and just ponder your next great adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Interesting villains might turn sides and become powerful allies. Leave open the possibility.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running a sandbox game, prepare and force decisions at the end of the adventure so you can well prepare the next one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There's a gamma world adventure lurking in this Luxury Bomb Shelter infographic:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A MacGuffin is a great way to get your group focused around an object that, by itself, doesn't really matter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Space Hulk would make for a great Gamma World campaign. Explorers break into ancient derelict alien space ships.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Assign a note-taker to your game and have them offer a summary at the beginning of each game. See what they think is important.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a battle doesn't go exactly like you planned, look for the interesting opportunity to let the story move in a new direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From @gregbilsland, pay particular attention to the points of  tension in a battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Highlight or underline the names of NPCs in your notes so you can refer to them easily.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Assigning monster hit point tracking to a player helps remove the adversarial relationship between players and DMs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be like @gregbilsland and hide die rolls to give you the ability to change the pace and tension of an encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be like Chris Perkins and never fudge a die roll. Let the dice guide the story in an unknown direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Wise words from @rjschwalb: "Never tell the players they are in a skill challenge."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: I find the best skill challenges often have the least amount of prep. Don't over-engineer challenges; let them grow naturally.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Michael Mann's "The Keep" may not be a great movie, but it's a great story for a D&D or Gamma World game!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: try fitting your night's adventure onto a single page of paper. It forces you to stay simple and helps keep your game on track.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend an hour sitting at your table visualizing the game you are about to run. Imagine the game running to see what's missing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Standard kobold miniatures and tokens can work well for Dark Sun Gith creatures. Your players will likely be too drunk to tell.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have you built some monster knowledge cards for your next game? Add it to your prep checklist:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Check out the fantastic terrain in the back of the Dark Sun Creature Catalog. It's useful for any game and very well designed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider inflicting direct damage instead of taking healing surges away in skill challenges. Taking damage isn't as annoying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A player recording monster damage frees you up to worry about table management and monster tactics. Makes life much easier.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Paperclip your status-effect fold overs to a big card so you can easily pull out the right one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The sorcerer kings in the back of the Dark Sun Creature Catalog work very well for paragon and epic bosses. Reskin!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Whether to kill, capture, or release a defeated foe is always an easy and interesting choice to give players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Gang warfare is always an interesting story choice for a Dark Sun campaign set in Tyr. Which gangs are rivals and which allies?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sell off your old monster books and stick to the MM3, Monster Vault, Demonomicon, and Dark Sun Creature Catalog.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When rebuilding monsters, start with the traits that define the monster and build mechanics around those traits.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The new DM screen's experience reward table makes it very easy to reward effort-based experience.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: in Dark Sun, don't have a generic "cross the desert" challenge. Make it specific like lizard hordes or crossing silt challenges.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your DM screen handy when prepping adventures for the skill and damage table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reveal the DCs in a skill challenge so players will be more willing to try untrained skills to do things.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get yourself in the right mindset for Dark Sun by watching 300 and then picking up the soundtrack for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your secondary battles fast by using only one monster type and a simple yet powerful environmental effect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add an "out" to every encounter you design. How can the party finish the encounter besides just wiping out all the bad guys?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make heavy use of the DCs and Damage Per Level charts in the updated DM Screen. They're extremely valuable tools.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players choices for their next adventure at the end of your current session. Make them choose before they leave.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend a couple of minutes summarizing the current story at the beginning of your adventure. Use it to turn on "game mode".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: don't reveal your "out" too early. Give your players a chance to discover how a battle works before revealing the victory states.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A mix of Watchmen, Tron Legacy, 300, and the Social Network soundtracks makes for a great instrumental gaming playlist.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow @rjschwalb's ruling guideline: if it smells like poop, it is probably poop:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be like Perkins: Think of a campaign as a TV season, create an episode guide, write one-line future episode summaries.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider spelling out a few potential options for skill challenges to give players ideas of what they can do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget to assign a rules lawyer to the best potential candidate at your table. Knowledgeable and fair are required.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For fast Gamma World con games, consider writing up some pregen characters. Just do the basics, leave the details to the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try combining skill checks, combat, roleplaying, puzzles, and physical props into one uber-encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of just figuring out what your battle environment is, think about what it USED to be to add another layer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add big nasty environmental effects to a single high level elite monster for a nice fast battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In case you missed it, my Monster Makeover: Shademaw the 26th lvl black dragon, is on the #dnd website:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes your group just wants to beat the crap out of a bunch of stupid guys. Give them those opportunities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A few small focused skill challenges will run better than a big vague one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Inherent Bonuses instead of magic items work well for one-shot characters. Give them one awesome item instead of a big pile.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about ways to build your battle map in three dimensions instead of just two.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In case you missed it, my Monster Makeover: Shademaw the 26th lvl black dragon, is on the #dnd website:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to and mix up which players get hit with which status effects. Being dazed three rounds in a row is no fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Your villains shouldn't be sitting around waiting for your PC's to show up. What evil quests are they working on right now?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Playing hardcore or #fourthcore? Have players bring spare sheets and sub-in new PCs when old ones die.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try designing puzzle encounters that have set goals in set time limits such as "bloody all foes in 30 minutes".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try telling your players what the DCs are for skill checks and challenges so they're more willing to use untrained skills.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some written flavor text for your nightly adventure intro summary can work nicely for a summary stored in Obsidian Portal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lord Vizier from the Dark Sun Creature Catalog makes for an excellent 26th level Lich.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running a Dark Sun game, begin your night's adventure showing their place on the big poster map.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go back to the fundamentals. Read "Building Adventures" on page 169 of the Dungeon Master's Book.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give a +2 bonus to skill checks and attack rolls for good roleplaying or storytelling. Reinforce good behaviors.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to draw a good color map on 1" grid sheets of paper like gaming paper:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good humanoid miniatures are always useful in your game. Pick them up before they're all gone!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't stack up a lot of denial effects in a single battle like slows, difficult terrain, dazes, or obscurement. It's frustrating.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't house rule every small broken combo. Instead, find the root cause and house rule those.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget to try to keep your house rules over on the DM's side of things so you can tweak without changing PC rules.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Skill challenges, puzzles, and riddles within an encounter helps keep the attention of your players on the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did the PCs get routed or forced to run after fighting a foe? Give them a chance for revenge!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Perhaps its heresy but you might include bronze and iron in the base Dark Sun materials. I can't believe in a stone longsword.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up outdoor encounters with underground ones. Don't stick them in a dungeon for six months.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find out your players' birthdays so you can run a special adventure tuned around them that week.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Refresh your adventure music playlist every couple of months to keep things fresh. Keep it about 8 hours long for a good mix.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you really want to play a monster from the MM1 or MM2, just make sure you increase its damage using the new Damage charts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Michael Clayton plot seed: What valuable piece of information do the PCs possess that everyone would kill them to quiet?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Most solo bosses can be reskinned versions of Monster Vault dragons. Only the free action attack gives them away.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hand select appropriate classes and races for the campaign world you want to run based on the flavor of the campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes players just want a room full of orcs. Not every encounter has to be fully developed with environmentals, puzzles, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go easy on big battles and lots of terrain effects at low levels. Big rooms full of goblins is just fine at level 1.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In your dark sun campaign, use that awesome color map and show them their place in Tyr or Athas at the beginning of your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful with brute swarms if your group lacks burst and blast attacks. They can be deadly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix wide open encounter areas with smaller complicated claustrophobic areas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your terrain effects simple. It's hard enough remembering what your monsters are supposed to do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write up three solid directions your players can choose from at the end of an adventure. Have them ready on game night.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Hannibal Lecter villain seed: Give your villain a piece of information critical to the party to prevent instant killings.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan no more than three battles for a four hour game or two battles for a three hour game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid using more than one "permission" room in an adventure, rooms that severely limit player mobility or actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to give players a non-predetermined choice at the end of each adventure or even each battle. Kill or not to kill is easy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskinning and re-leveling monsters are great tricks to learn to speed up your game prep.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good hand-held white erase board and a dry-erase marker can work better than scraps of paper. Better for the earth too.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up dungeon, wilderness, and city encounters to give your group a variety of locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Imposing a house rule that limits PCs to one interrupt power per character can avoid chains of interrupts in your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't send your DM a tweet with a picture of your junk, even if it's covered in tighty whities. It won't get you any new gear.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build evil NPC parties from the humanoids in the Dark Sun Creature Catalog and Monster Vault.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry if your battle map isn't perfectly aligned with the encounter map in a published adventure. Mod it to suit your group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Named bad guys can be more real and more interesting than generic brutes. Try to come up with details for sub-bosses.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin monsters around the miniatures you have rather than the old " this human pig farmer is actually a wyrmling".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Cheap plastic shoe boxes work really well in storing miniatures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up your dungeon tiles, dry-erase maps, and 3d terrain to make things interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scale monster damage by starting at level + 8 and increasing or decreasing based on the number of targets or rarity of the attack.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your stories simple. You might love all the plot twists in your game but your players might have a hard time keeping track.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use between two and four different monsters in combat to keep things interesting without getting too complicated.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: To build some easy monster sheets, take screen grabs from the compendium and paste them into a word or pages document.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When designing monsters, keep standard monsters simple - one or two thematic powers will do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hand out disease cards to those afflicted to keep track of it across games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use damaging terrain effects to scale encounters up without making your battle take longer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes your group just wants to fight hordes of minions. Give them that chance.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up an assault or a defense of a small keep, noble house, or inn as a sandbox game with a purpose.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need a quick minion? AC = level + 15; Def = level + 13; attack = level + 5; damage = 4 + 1/2 level; init = 1/2 level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running an adventure in a location from a campaign guide? Try googling the name to see what else others have done with it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stephen King's The Stand (available on Netflix Streaming) is a great seed for a Gamma World campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have two groups of PCs? Consider splitting up simultaneous events, telling half of a single story one night and half the next.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down your last week's summary and post it to your Obsidian Portal adventure log to save yourself some time and energy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Too many NPCs filling up your campaign? Do what Stephen King did in The Stand and blow a few of them up to keep things focused.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players choose which NPCs have a big part in your campaign. Don't force the ones you like.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a good #gammaworld story about a derelict Martian space ship, check out Broken Angels:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need inspiration for a great Dark Sun big brawl scene? Check out the beginning of "Gangs of New York":
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good mastermind villain always has a good side-kick who is in the face of the PCs a lot. Think Grace Jones from View to a Kill.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal good scenes for your game from everywhere. Consider a mini-adventure based on the gang movie The Warriors.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Denzel Washington in Training Day makes for a great ally turned villain. Don't surprise your party, have them watch him turn slow.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make Revenge of the Giants and Tomb of Horrors useful again by updating monster damage with a sharpie.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The good cop gone too far is a great villain archetype. Consider Alonzo Harris from Training Day.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's easy to turn a normal encounter into a Dark Sun encounter. Grass turns to sand and water turns brackish.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hill giants with a Beast Giant leader makes for a great desert oasis encounter for paragon-tier Dark Sun PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Here's a good Dark Sun high-res map:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't have two NPCs with the same first letter of their name. No Zanthar and Zulamen and Zytheria. Old tip from Stephen King.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Monsters that burst when hit bring a great challenge to your paragon and epic PCs. See the Monster Vault Black Dragon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Quiz your players to figure out how many NPCs and plot twists they can actually keep track of.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to run faster combats? Try using average damage for PCs and monsters instead of rolling damage dice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A burning building about to collapse makes for a great encounter "out". Give the PCs five rounds before it collapses around them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make your "who's coming this week?" email exciting with some quick lore and sneak previews. Make them REALLY want to come.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time surfing the #dnd hashtag to meet new folks as into our hobby as we are.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make brutes the staple monster in your battles. They do tons of damage and are easy to hit. DMs and players both love them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's a lot easier to just play out of the Monster Vault book or the Dark Sun Creature Catalog. Don't think you have to tweak.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Misplaced your monster? Give him a ranged attack that matches his basic melee. No one will know the difference.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always give your monster stat blocks a full read-through before a game. It's easy to forget about auras or interrupts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have lots of monsters planned? Average out the damage of non-elites to make your battle a little faster.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have an elite boss you don't want to get stuck in a corner? Give him teleports and a way to shake off any status effect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't always have to completely retire your campaign. Take a year off and come back later in the PC's story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you run a single monster type in an encounter, give them both a melee and ranged attack.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In your Dark Sun game, always remember that the environment itself is an enemy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal some of the more detailed tiles from older Dungeon Tiles sets and throw them in your Master sets. Runes, sigils, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always give solos a way to shake off stuns, unconscious, and dominates. Give epic solos a way to shake any status effect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The recent Zhent Soldier miniature from Lords of Madness makes for a great generic bad guy miniature.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hard-hitting elemental effects are a great way to increase threat in an encounter without making it slower.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running an epic one-shot adventure? Stick to Essentials source material.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up easier and harder fights to give your PCs a chance to stretch all their cool abilities before you drop the hammer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful with too much slowing and difficult terrain. It can get annoying quick.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be like @chrisSSims and build your encounters beginning with the story you want to tell.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Character sheets can be printed two to a page and still be legible. Saves ink and makes it easier to see all options at once.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: think of creative ways to build 3D sets out of Dungeon Tiles:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep traps, terrain effects, and hazards simple. You have enough to worry about.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players a chance to shine with a lower difficulty encounter. Run only three monsters instead of five or six.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't need dwarven forge to have a 3d map. Use thread spools or toilet paper rolls to boost up dungeon tiles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give bored players a chance to roll a skill check to learn something interesting about an environment or monster.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The newer the monster book, the better the monster design. When selecting monsters, pick from newer books first.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you don't have it, invest in a good set of hero miniatures. While you can get away with monster tokens, PCs need minis.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From the immortal Chris Perkins, model your notable NPC after a movie character to help with the voices:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good heroes make choices. Give your players plenty of opportunities to make the hard calls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add excitement to your game by running it during a 5.9 earthquake...
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How is your villain changing his plans as your PCs move forward in their story?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hand select appropriate classes and races for the campaign world you want to run based on the flavor of the campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take screen shots of monster blocks from the compendium, paste them together in Paint, and send as Photos to your iPad.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From the @wizards_dnd podcast: the order of effects at the beginning of the turn is decided upon by the creature's player.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Acrylic sheets from Home Depot work very well over flat dungeon tile arrangements as well as poster maps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: To speed things up and still keep up the threat of a battle, change "-2 to attacks" auras on enemies to "-2 to defenses".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: With the Monster Vault, MV: Nentir Vale, MM3, and Dark Sun Creature Catalog, there's no reason to use outdated monster books.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't assume your group just loves combat. Try a single battle and some roleplaying before and after.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try Fiasco-style character interactions to get your PCs together in some way other than all showing up at a bar.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes acting like a Boggle (like an idiot) is all it takes to impress people like @katokatonian or @angrydm.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never ever "just end the fight here". Always come up with an in-game reason for a battle to end early.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tell your group the highest defense across all monsters as your "magic number" so they don't have to ask if they hit above it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use acrylic sheets from Home Depot to stack multiple maps on top of one another and peel back as your group goes through maps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Acrylic sheets work very well above dungeon tiles. You don't even need to use poster putty.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take Chris Perkins's advice and "under-prepare and improvise":
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you find yourself designing monsters, you can do a lot worse than picking up a copy of the 1st edition Fiend Folio.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a folio of poster maps and large tiles handy for those unplanned encounter areas that come up during your adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Auto-hit environmental effects are a lot easier to manage at the table than effects with attack rolls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep control of the magic items you give out in your campaign. Some of them can be quite a challenge to deal with later.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Missing some good hero miniatures? Check out the Reaper pre-painted miniature line:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What theme song does your campaign have? Play it often and use it to bring them into the mindset of your world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running a one-shot? Try to stick to level 1 PCs. It makes for a much faster game with lots of potential encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try out Mastermind as an interesting skill challenge puzzle for door traps or arcane locks:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running one-shot D&D or Gamma World games, start them at level 1 to keep things simple and fast.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tell your group what the highest AND lowest defenses are for all monsters so they know instantly if they hit or missed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Work with your group to come up with a party name. Don't simply pick it for them or leave it totally in their hands.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Head out to your local drug stores or party stores to pick up some awesome halloween props for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have more than five players? Have traps and hazards auto-hit instead of rolling attacks. Faster game and more damage output.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go over your poster map collection regularly so you can whip one out whenever the situation calls for it at your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Easy way to figure out damage dice: Level + 8 damage - (1 + max dice roll) for 2 dice. 15th lvl = 23 dam - 9 = 2d8+14.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pick up the Fantastic Locations map packs. For the money, you get four great poster maps:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus most of your preparation time time on the interactions of NPCs in your game world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A level + 5 elite can make for a great boss instead of a level +1 or +2 solo.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Combine two poster maps for a nice large encounter area worthy of two or three battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When designing monsters (and this should be rare - reskin instead), go back to original 1e sources for inspiration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scunci girl hair bands make great mini markers and only cost $3 at CVS.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In Gloomwrought, no one is pure and everyone has a hidden agenda.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have your characters build their backgrounds and relationships before you build your campaign's threads .
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember, bad villains always think they're the good guys.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to build up a set of generic miniatures that work well at all tiers and in many battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reuse poster maps by flipping them 180 degrees, starting the party at different spots, and changing the environmental effects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep traps and environmentals simple. To make it really easy, have them auto-hit if a character ends its turn within the aura.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Auras are an easy staple for solo monsters and epic-tier battles. They are easily over-used though.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep monster theme powers in your head that tie monsters together into a clear group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a list of 20 potential relationships between PCs based on the factions in your campaign world when starting a campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a big ziploc bag of all the table accessories you regularly need. Remove stuff you don't really use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Time to go look for that bargain-bin halloween props for your game!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try running your game without a DM screen to keep things more open and give you a better view of the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Speed up combat and keep things lethal: At beginning of turn, monsters gain vulnerability 5 per tier and +5 per tier in damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every encounter should teach the PCs more about the story of the adventure. What will they learn from your next one?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before you prep your game, go over your collection of poster maps to get ideas for cool encounter areas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think real hard about your game and then forget about it for a day. Let good ideas grow subconsiously.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running one-shot D&D or Gamma World games, start them at level 1 to keep things simple and fast.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you do nothing else, use updated damage expressions for monsters published before the Monster Manual 3.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set aside all the minis or tokens you might need for the general area your PCs explore. It opens up potential encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try building a whole encounter that's nothing but traps and hazards. Think the idol temple in Raiders of the Lost Ark.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fleeing as a "combat out" rarely works well. Players are determined to stop them from running. Let them get away in an instant.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For detriments, reduce defenses and add vulnerabilities rather than steal actions and reducing attack scores or damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Gloomwrought Despair deck can work well for any dismal adventure. Use it at the edge of (or within) the Far Realm.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Heavy and nasty environmental effects can help a solo stay a solo in an encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stick to gear rewards from the Dungeon Master Kit and Mordenkainen's Emporium. They have a good sense of what makes a rare item.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Designing a big solo? Make sure they have a way to break away from movement impairment zones and chained effects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: To give your dungeon some extra flavor and challenge, add a dungeon-wide effect like +5 to necrotic attacks or vul 5 to cold.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use vulnerability and "- X defenses" instead of action-stealing or "-X attack" status effects. Keeps up threat without boredom.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Replace complicated status effects with "knocking prone". It's easy to keep track of and doesn't bone the PC too much.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you write up anything, write up a read-aloud summary of your last game to get your players in the right mindset.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good villain thinks he's right. A great villain IS right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A static damage number for traps and hazards makes them run a lot faster at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use your Gloomwrought, Dark Sun, or Neverwinter maps to show your party where they ended the last session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A single high-level elite and a series of traps can make for a great non-standard encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "Restrain until the beginning of your next turn" works well for restraining hazards without making them too painful
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hang a white-board near your table to write monster defenses and common DCs during a game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry too much about monster size. Sometimes players with low level PCs should fight a huge or gargantuan dragon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes auto damage is the only way you'll actually threaten high-level PCs. Don't use it all the time but a dash will do ya!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go over your whole encounter setup to ensure it threatens the whole party. Enough artillery? Enough brutes?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In high level encounters, ensure at least one monster can hit each defense type.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of statting out full traps, just keep the theme in mind and use the DM Cheat Sheet for damage:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You might be tempted to run a high-level elite instead of a lower-level solo. Level + 5 is about as far as you'll want to go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random loot can be fun, but verify that your PCs have enough gold every so often by checking their ideal gold per level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lazy DMing can help you focus on story and NPC interactions, but don't skimp on designing some good pre-planned encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Environmental effects that strictly do damage can be boring, but they're a lot easier to design and implement. Ware complexity.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stick to rewarding magic items from the DM Kit and Mordenkainen's. You get a good wide variety and better balanced items.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running for 4 PCs, keep in mind that much synergy is lost. Go easy on them or you'll wipe them out accidentally.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: With four "Heroes" books in publication, consider limiting short-run games to PC classes and races from only those books.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every room in a dungeon needs monsters. Give them some interesting rooms to explore filled with story hooks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give challenging bosses environmental terrain that penetrates damage resistance, boosts damage, or boosts damage shields.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make sure your players have enough options to keep them interesting from level to level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players what they enjoy the most and the least in your games. Always seek to tweak and improve your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A small number of monsters at a higher level can be easier to manage and makes for a faster yet still challenging encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep some maps and tiles of generic rooms, inns, streets, and wilderness encounters for on-the-spot encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want some extra threat and a way to deal with so many multiple attacks? Give your monster a fire shield that hits back!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When building monsters, keep them to only the most important powers. Keep them lean and simple at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every boss needs to be a solo. Elites, and even normal monsters, can work well as humanoid bosses.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Turn a normal creature into an elite easily with twice the hit points and an extra standard action each round.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Poster maps and a 24" by 36" polycarbonate sheet are the best encounter props you can get.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix and match your mini collection and the D&D Adventure Board Game minis to make the most of both.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For an easy Combat Out, tie brutes or skirmishers to artillery or controllers. If either group dies, the others break down.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Granting combat advantage is a nice clean nasty status effect to give to a monster's attack or aura.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force a story. Think what the main NPCs in your campaign are doing right now as they react to the PCs' actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pull out some fun old adventures for inspiration into your current 4e game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For your more open-ended games, having about three possible paths the party might go and don't fall in love with any one of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of favorite supporting characters in movies you liked for ad-hoc NPC roleplaying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build out your story, then refine it to the most cool piece of it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: While you can get away with tokens for monsters, invest in a good set of PC miniatures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's easy to wipe people out in Gamma World. Plan accordingly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stick to two to three different kinds of monsters in an encounter. More than that gets too complicated to run easily.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember that being a DM is being a showman. Work on your dynamic voice and performance to keep the pace of the game right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a good personality template, think of a movie character and watch a film of theirs on Netflix to get the personality right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the advice of @theiddm and always keep an eye on the body-language of your players and yourself. Get into "the arena"!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Boss rooms should often contain some sort of damage resistance penetration so your boss's elemental damage isn't nullified.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think through the eyes of your NPCs instead of plotting out your story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use simple puzzles as potential mini-games instead of just rolling skill checks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to talk about your hobby with your coworkers. You never know who used to play and dreams of playing again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always ask for honest feedback on your game after it's done. Force them to come up with one thing you can make better.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Feedback from your players can tell you a lot about your game. Body language can tell you a lot more. Watch them both.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Romance in a game can be weird or fun. Keep it light hearted and funny most of time time and powerful once or twice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just because things got more complicated doesn't mean they have to. A single skill check or single-use trap is a fine way to go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider running 6 to 8 session mini-campaigns focused on a particular theme and source material.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When limiting source material, have players build their characters using the physical books and then put it in the CB after.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay special attention to environmental effects in your encounters. They are often the thing that makes encounters unique.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players spending a lot of time on cellphones? What can you do to draw their interest back to the game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't assume your players care as much for the story as you do. Your high nterest is probably why you're the DM.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Delegate things like initiative and monster damage tracking to other players when you get overwhelmed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Up and down-level monsters by adding a -X level sticky note in your monster book to remind you to do the math.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep solos and elites simple and powerful by letting them ignore daze, stuns, and dominates during their turns.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep elites and solos simple and powerful by letting them ignore daze, stuns, and dominates during their turn.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want an old-school feel with your existing 4e game? Try playing low level games with just Heroes of the Fallen Lands.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want the feeling of a simple old-school #dnd game? Try running low level adventures with just Heroes of the Fallen Lands.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your game ultra simple by only using the DM Cheat Sheet and coming up with everything on the fly:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep NPC portraits handy on your laptop or iPad and save yourself the cost of all that ink.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a single mini like the rat swarm or kobold to represent a pack of minions on your battle map.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use numbered tent cards in front of the player to run initiative at con-games or one-shots. Got this from @alphastream.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider layered traps. Maybe the pit trap has a falling pot of pitch trap right on the other side.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use minis like the kobold or rat swarm to represent a number of small or tiny minions on your battle map.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a handful of D6s to determine which player hordes of monsters might attack.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write up a seating chart on a note card in front of you to remember character names associated with each player oriented by seat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A quick and easy way to add flavor to an NPC is to associate them with a character in a movie or TV show you like.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: don't fight the knowledge your players bring to the game. Incorporate their knowledge into their PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep your game moving. If players can't decide what to do, call a vote on two or three options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't save up that good idea for later, use it as soon as you're able. From Perkins:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep an idea journal around for those adventure or story ideas you aren't quite able to use yet:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When developing your story, consider the wise words of Kurt Vonnegut and start close to the end:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go crazy at the dollar store for some gaming props and terrain: from @markmeredith
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mark and remember the map drawing tips of Chris Perkins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use flashbacks, maybe even a flashback encounter, to share a richer and deeper story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When building or running a monster, ensure your players get the true feeling of what makes that monster different.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Cathedral of Chaos tile set includes a sheet of tokens for conjurations, walls, and other useful things.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For your heavy tactical gamer players, incorporate roleplaying as a part of combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Learn to be comfortable with changes in your story based on the decisions of your players, the actions of the PCs, and the dice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Really ask yourself if you need to do all that monster tweaking. Just play from the Monster Vault and have fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When things slow down at the table, fall into character of the villains and bring things back to life with some flavor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend your time planning for a dynamic world instead of a static story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reinforce the aspects of your game world that tie closely to its theme. Buildings should hate the PCs in Gloomwrought.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good piece of 250 to 500 word flash fiction in an email can keep your game tied together between games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary of complicated dungeon crawls. Stacked on long combats, they can be a big slog.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a white-board on your wall to write up important all-visible notes like monster defenses.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write large 5x8 cards with monster defenses on them to post on your game-room white board when the time comes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember to be patient and build a game session that won't make you or your players feel rushed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be like Perkins (and Stephen King) and use "What If" as your motivator for adventures instead of long plots:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the Gloom deck from the Shadowfell boxed set as failure conditions to skill challenges or traps:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about where you spend your time prepping your game. Is that where you SHOULD be?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: writing good flavor text helps you stick to just the descriptions crucial to trigger the inner eyes of your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a small notebook to capture unexpected changes in the story during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build adventures around the personal quests of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reward meaningful personal quests with wish-list items.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't over think a short rest. Sometimes it is just a reinvigoration between the parts of a two-part battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: add seasons and holidays in your game world.

author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid using piles of monsters with the same status effect powers. Too many creatures that grab can be a drag instead of fun.

text: #dnd tip: A good forest flip mat can help a lot for off-the-cuff forest encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The movie 13 Assassins is full of great character, encounter, and story ideas for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave plenty of time to run your big climactic battles. Change things half-way through and make it memorable.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't pressure or cut your group off too short when they're spending a good deal of time discussing a potential decision.
author: Michael E. Shea
