author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep some random names around to name powerful memorable monsters in your battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a random loot list around to save yourself preparation time and embrace the lifestyle of the lazy DM:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always remember that published adventures are intended to be modified. Rework them to suit your style and your group's desires.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce key villains in your campaign at least two or three sessions before your group faces them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid of adding ad-hoc powers to your big monsters on the fly. Use the DM Cheat Sheet as a guide:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your players engaged in your campaign on off-weeks with weekly emailed flash-fiction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't plan out your campaign too far. Pick a general goal and let the story move naturally.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Group having trouble coming to a decision? Lay out the options and call for a vote. Go with the majority.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need a good villain? Look no further than Raven from the book "Snow Crash". Great background and awesome sinister motivations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan only what you need to plan and force yourself to improv at the table. It makes for a much more open-ended game in the end.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: One of my favorite tips: Put yourself to sleep daydreaming through the eyes of your NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 4e battles work best as large set-pieces and scenes. Build your adventures around these big scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try running Fiasco with your #dnd group to give them insight into a game focused on group storytelling.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Grab a set of re-usable maps to keep on hand. A lazy dungeon master focuses time on the RIGHT things!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider building sets of themes for your short campaign, letting PCs choose the set and then randomly determining the theme.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Preparing for improvisation means having the right tools available to you. What is your improvisation tool list?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understanding the motives of your NPCs and villains makes it easier to improvise their reactions to the PCs' actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of building your world or re-statting monsters, spend time understanding the backgrounds and motivations of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: During your #dndnext playtest, experiment with both Theater of the Mind and gridded combat experiences.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your notable NPC list short for your mini-campaign. It makes it easier for the players to remember who's important.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build your NPCs and their actions as stand-alone characters and events, not just how they react to the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your PCs a chance to parlay with defeated monsters instead of just always having them die off.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For powerful solos, let them convert debilitating status effects int damage, vulnerability, or combat advantage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For your mini-campaign, work with your player to choose a set of classes and races that makes sense for the campaign world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a random loot chart with your copy of the DM Kit to save yourself prep time:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the DM Cheat Sheet to make rulings instead of worrying about hard rules for DCs and damage:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to come up with terrain effects and powers on the fly. Maybe that slime patch grants CA!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What three things do you need to happen in your next game? Keep things simple.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tune your lazy DM powers. Force yourself to come up with a random on-the-spot NPC at your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Wrap three layers onto your encounter area: What did it used to be? What is it now? What happens to it during the battle?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to break stereotypes in your NPCs. Make the big brute an articulate poet or master of business.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let humor flow into your game but don't be afraid to make things serious. Think about how WoW handles humor and drama.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan ahead for creatures being dominated. Give boss monsters two sets of actions, one dominated and one not.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did your big boss monster get dominated? See where that takes the story!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need a dungeon and don't have one ready? Grab one from this huge map archive:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your rules lawyer the job of rules mediation to take some of the pressure off of you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on building an environment and interesting dynamic NPCs instead of telling a story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think your players know where the story is headed? Maybe it's time to reveal the TRUE villain.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Things getting too mainstream? Pull a Joss Whedon and kill off some folk.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The dungeon and overland poster map from the Starter Set has a great amount of versatility for the lazy DM:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes your locations familiar, fantastic, and functional?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In the prime of their life, what were all these tunnels, dungeons, or old ruins supposed to be?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always have a battle on hand to stir things up in the beginning of your adventure so it doesn't get too slow.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared to throw your encounter away if your group finds a creative way to get around it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared for the PCs to drop fast, all at once. Give them room to come back or be prepared for their defeat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of building encounters, prepare the tools you need to build encounters at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the book from the DM Kit handy to reskin traps and quickly pick some fantastic terrain:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the goals and quests of the PCs and review them before planning each game for tie-ins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep old dungeon maps handy in case your PCs go off the path.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the generic tiles in the Dungeon Tile Master Set instead of drawing featureless rooms:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep things running smooth at your table by putting out all the accessories beforehand: pencils, dice, paper, init cards, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is the battle losing steam but you still have a couple of monsters left? Give them extra standard actions each turn.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: #dndnext's "Advantage" and "Disadvantage" work very well for ad-hoc environmental effects. Add them to your lazy bag of tricks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a more even 4e skill experience? Houserule a free feat, Bard of All Trades, that gives a +3 bonus to untrained skills.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When building a soundtrack for your game, mix big hits with classical soundtracks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider using #dndnext's "advantage" as a terrain benefit. Unlike "disadvantage", it speeds up combat instead of slowing it down.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider a "boss" template that lets bosses remove status effects but grants "advantage" to all enemies instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sort your minis so you don't have to bother setting them aside for game day. Just grab your "orc" box and go!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep poster maps for roads, inns, dungeon rooms, castles, and overland forest areas handy for improvised encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running Gardmore, always consider what the NPC adventurers are up to as the PCs move forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Work with your players to find interesting ways to feed the PC's story into the game world. It isn't YOUR story, it's the group's.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Battles with a single monster type run much faster than with multiple monsters. Use them for in-between fights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: With the length of 4e battles in mind, make sure every battle has its own story to tell and a part in the big picture.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The 1e Dungeon Master's Guide contains a wealth of charts and tables useful for any D&D game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: when running gridless combat, favor the attacker.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: No leader in your group? Give everyone a once-per-encounter minor-action healing surge use they can use on themselves or...
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run a smaller multi-room dungeon as a single encounter with monsters running in at different times.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Short rests don't always need to be 5 minute breaks. Maybe the PCs drank some refreshing Fey-water for an instant recharge.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Where you can remotely justify it, give your melee-based monsters a ranged attack in case they get pinned down.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Convert monster dominates to "as a free action, take a move action and make a basic attack"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to have three choices available for your players to take at the beginning and ends of games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of encounters as part of the structure of your story. Make every one of them matter to the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your primary villains mobile. Ensure they're doing stuff while your PCs are on the move.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before planning a mini-campaign, run ideas past your group on what they might be interested in.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a full 1-30 experience in a short period, try @squach's 5 levels betwee sessions mini-campaign idea.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stick to lower-level characters for one-shot campaigns so players don't have too much trouble figuring out their capabilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the dungeon tiles in the Dungeon Command sets for some Dragon-Age-style random encounter maps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a nice 4 hour playlist of instrumental music and some rock music to keep your game's pace high.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a set of potential environmental and situational effects handy for improv. Ensure they all help keep the pace fast.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need to do some environmental damage to a PC? Use 2d6+level as your equation for normal damage. +1d6 per tier for higher damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Vary your encounter design so you don't get stuck in similar battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep your game table 30 minutes early so things go smooth at game time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to read through a pre-published adventure should you decide to run one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't start off an adventure with an apology. Just go with what you have.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add some old-world flavor to your handouts by printing them out on copper parchment paper:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: #dndnext characters have far fewer hit points and far fewer ways to get them back. Consider this in your dungeon designs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Throw some action into the middle of long periods of role playing with a good old fashioned bar brawl!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be like @alphastream and review the PC's motivations, goals, and backgrounds before each game to tie them in.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When improvising flavor of an area, describe all the senses.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In sandbox games, always have an idea what adventure locations are near by. Ancient dungeons, old caves, slavers keeps, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The #dnd adventure novels can give you a lot of good background and inspiration for your adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want your traps to feel real? Describe the sounds of counter-weights moving behind the walls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Practice the fine art of not writing down great ideas. If they're really great, they'll come back.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider running the old Ravenloft module with your #dndnext playtest on Halloween!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking to build your own Perkins-style map archive? Here's a link to the WOTC Map Archive:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For those on a budget, the Monster Vault is worth it just for the tokens, adventure, and map.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Star Trek as a model for island adventures just like Chris Perkins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tap into the imagination of your players to fuel your game's story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From Perkins: if you're going to rip off someone's idea, rip off @montecook. He's a master.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend prep time on hand-outs and other table gimmicks to make your game interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Play tons of other games and steal the mechanics and stories that work for you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always be ready for PCs to throw your primary quest-giving NPC off a cliff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Skill as a roleplayer and as a DM comes with practice. Get out there and do it - a lot.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a queue from Borderlands 2 and have your villain interacting with your PCs often, even very early on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want an example of a sandbox story? Check out True Blood.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get over the fear of failure. Recognize this fear and allow yourself to make mistakes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Convey a new piece of information with each piece of improvised dialog.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Imitate voices from TV and movie characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you use "theater of the mind" take the opportunity to go big. Vast rooms, huge statues - things you can't do with a map.

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't save your great ideas, use them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave big wide gaps in your game's story and let the players fill them in.

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on tone and pace when imitating voices.

text: #dnd tip: Steal characters and seeds from three Kurt Russel movies: Escape from New York, The Thing, and Soldier
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A great DM comes from skills in improvisation. How will you improve your improv skills?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Everybody poops. Consider the daily habits of your monsters when building out their lair.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A single monster type in an encounter makes for a much faster battle. Use a single type of monster for a quick skirmish.
author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Old 1st edition modules convert very easily over to #dndnext. Give them a try!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use well-known stories as a template for adventure, but add a twist!

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Force yourself to improvise by leaving big open choices for your players' at your next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't correct your players as they noodle a story through out loud. Instead, try to change your story to fit their ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a player who just jumped into your game? Ask the group to figure out how his or her PC arrived.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random encounters don't have to be boring. How do those random encounters lead to more interesting story threads?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How is ending a #dnd campaign similar to leaving a patient? @theiddm tells us!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down hooks your players come up with during the game so you can wire them back into the story as it unfolds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't need a thousand monsters. A couple of hundred well-designed ones can be re-skinned forever.
author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force your players back into the rails if they go off track in your published adventure. Go with it!

text: #dnd tip: What's the winter holiday in your game world?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Experiment using Theater of the Mind for smaller fights against single monsters without crazy terrain features.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't fall too much in love with roleplaying an NPC. Sometimes your players just want things to move along.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember the roots of our games as a group of people telling a story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Like Pope in Sons of Anarchy, what time bomb has your villain set up to go off when he or she dies?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For one-shot campaigns, focus character backgrounds around the general seed or primary location of the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use flashbacks as a way to drive interest in a game's world without forcing a direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The first scene in Prometheus is actually a pretty interesting story seed for a lot of campaigns.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players name their magic weapons when they acquire them. Take note of it and mention it later.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't go too hard on the "damned if you do, damned if you don't" choices. Sometimes people don't want the extra stress.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let stories evolve and digest in your mind for a while before you sprint to the word processor and solidify them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave yourself unanswered questions in your thoughts about your campaign ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to pull back the curtain and let players see what's going on in the background with flash fiction or a montage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try putting the DM screen away and removing the physical barrier between you and the rest of the group. Be one of them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your group options on directions to take the game. Let them vote on the game's future.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget to use the three Fs when describing an area: Functional, Familiar, and Fantastic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running "Isle of Dread", use the random encounter chart to describe tracks found by the PCs or mix two groups together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players discuss their options, then summarize them, and have them choose. Move things forward without forcing directions.

text: #dnd tip: As you begin your mini-campaign, sit with your players and understand their expectations:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Here's a great article on DM pitfalls recommended by Chris Perkins:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Develop your story from the ideas your players generate during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What one word describes you as a DM?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Heed the wise words of @theshedm when considering betrayal in your game:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the wise even-toned words of @theangrydm and keep your background stories brief and focused:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random encounters don't have to be throw-aways. Let them evolve into the story or become the seed for a new one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What will the legacy of your PCs and your campaign be?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Gather all the minis for a single adventure location and let the PCs face dynamic pacs of bad guys as they go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pick up a copy of Dungeon World. The advice in the book is outstanding for any version of D&D:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about mixing up a battle with waves of enemies. You never know who will stumble through the door.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Story Cubes to give a quick origin flashback on that orc the PCs just killed:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to mash up game worlds with different systems. There's no reason Dark Sun can't work with Gamma World PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have another player track monster damage. You have enough to worry about.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before you start going crazy with your game world, sit with your players and get an idea for what they want out of it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seek every opportunity to learn from the experiences of other DMs. Listen and understand before you judge them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What are the eccentricities of your nobles like?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read some of the original fiction Gygax read to learn a bit more on the origin of our hobby:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hidden Cults = Known Cults + 1
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a look at this good practical article on running a Lazy #dnd campaign by @SnarkKnight1:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have your players guess what trope you have prepared that begins their adventure. Then pick the best choice! Zing!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How does love play a part (or not) in your games? Comedy? A mirror of real-life romance?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dungeon World, Fiasco, 13th Age, Fate; all of these systems have interesting ways to bring PCs together. Steal the ones you like.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to give villains interesting effects PCs might not have seen before. No reason they can't research unique magic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always stick some sort of PC-available terrain effect to a big battle area. Give them something unique to do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down a few principles by which an NPC acts in situations. Let them react to PCs as they would in real life.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your Pathfinder Face Cards handy during your game. You never know if a minor NPC will become major.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the wise words of Dungeon World: Be a fan of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Organize your minis in a way that makes it easy to reference during a game. Save time by storing them the way you use them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Quit all this boring RPG shit and get back to some core table top gaming experiences:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to steal fluffy campaign books from any setting to use in your #dnd game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use published adventures as inspiration for the stories you and your group share at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a member of your group goes off on a wacky direction, don't shut it down, try going with it!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Who are the three big forces moving things in your campaign? How are these forces rubbing up against the PCs?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need some templates for royalty? Use the aristocrats in Downton Abbey!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Closer Precursor by NiN makes for some awesome creepy dungeon music:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't build out your campaign arcs until you've seen what sorts of characters your group brings to the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is this prep activity you're spending so much time on really bringing more enjoyment to your group?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make frequent use of large geographic poster maps to keep your group's imagination on the world their PCs inhabit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As you hang on loose to your story, remind your players to do the same. Let them build their story during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: After each session, think of was to refactor stories towards the actions of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find out what drives each character and work that into your next game's outline.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pour yourself into the setting material for your game instead of writing up your own story. How will the world react to the PCs?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The most useful published setting material usually sits between game worlds and adventures. Gloomwrought, Neverwinter, Magnimar.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Of all your purchases, world and geographic sourcebooks will probably last the longest and remain system independent.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use 3x5 cards to write out the quests and leads your players discover as the story unfolds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Managing the various drives and personalities of the members of your group can be the hardest part of being a good DM.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your group runs into an encounter well above their capabilities, ensure you give them enough clues to know when to run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use published adventures and sourcebooks as seeds and material for the stories you and your group come up with during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "Describe your killing blow" is an easy way to draw your slayer player types into the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players discover their own quests, then write the goal clearly on a 3x5 card and give it to them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to save major villains if they die early. Maybe they become minor ones and some other beast becomes the boss.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always have an idea what roaming band of bad guys might spring on the party if the players start getting bored.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to mark up your sourcebooks. Your not a museum curator. Give them some character and add to them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always look for ways to tie the PCs together.  Get them working as a group. Nothing focuses like a murder!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use journals and letters as both hand-outs and story seed organizational aids.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the wise path of @aquelajames and build a campaign around a pack of adventures:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up story hook land mines throughout your lazy mini-campaign to propel the PCs forward:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build story hooks from character backgrounds during PC creation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dealing with and managing the different personalities at the table is probably the hardest job a DM has.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep rules arguments down to ninety seconds then make a judgement and move on. Let people look it up between games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When in doubt of a rule, have them roll a skill or ability check and move on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you happen to be playing Pathfinder, here's an excellent treasure generator for the Lazy DM:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Do something really nice for your DM on his or her birthday! Especially if he just turned 40 =(
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Group having trouble understanding the game's current structure? Have core NPCs outline the potential paths the PCs might take.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use physical things like notes or objects to clarify the tying up of loose ends in a mystery campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Forgot a NPC's name? Change it and when your players correct you, tell them their PC heard it wrong.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make your life easy and give everyone the same amount of total experience points.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players chances and opportunities to rebuild their characters if they aren't having fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: This is my number one single-word tip to run a great D&D game: "relax".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stealing from @dungeonworld, play to find out what happens instead of building out a pre-fab story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The "DM's Friend", a +2 bonus, works across just about any d20 game. Don't be afraid to use it to reinforce awesome ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a battle starts to feel stale, don't be afraid to set the room on fire.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to use random encounters, the chaos might add quite a bit to the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understand both the intention and approach when adjudicating actions. Thanks @theangrydm!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dig deep into Ed Greenwood's treatise on the shit hauling trade and add the stinky details to your own game
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As you think up cool ideas for dungeon chambers, jot them down and save them for later!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The best minis to invest in are the ones you can use most often at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a good idea for an encounter? Keep it handy and drop it into the right point in your improvised game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When writing flash fiction or handouts, make sure to make the essential information clear.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prioritize your miniature painting around the minis you plan to use at the table the most.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The red priestess from Game of Thrones makes for a perfect evil wizard or cleric villain.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Nothing says you can't limit your game worlds to give it a clear flavor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The random tables in the Pathfinder GameMastery Guide make the whole cost of the book worth while:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The most important miniatures are those of the PCs. Sometimes it's the best way for a player to connect to a character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't let the rules get in the way of a good time. Make a ruling and move on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a lesson from @dungeon_world; if a PC does something, they do it, unless there is a distinct danger associated to failure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of pre-building encounters, keep a set of potential monsters for a larger area. Choose from the set at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always use character names to address your players. It keeps the sense of immersion going.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In dungeons, give players useful information to help with choices. "Great heat on the left, smell of death on the right"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get a feeling for your players' desire for fluffy stories and crunchy simulations. Adjust accordingly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build your own campaign cheat sheet with the tables, names, and other things to help you run your specific game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a few easy skill and encounter ideas in your head to use in the most appropriate situation in your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End your game with an open decision tree to force you to improvise at your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use notes and letters you hand out as an organizational aid for your game. Tie your characters, NPCs, and villains together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't punish your group for coming up with fun "cheating" spell combinations. Give them the avenue to use them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Your most dangerous villain may never actually show up in an encounter. They're too smart to scrap it out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't need to plan everything, but prepare your game's opening scene and opening lines. Let it grow from there.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Harvest locations and flavor-text from your favorite published adventures. Use them how they best fit your group's story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Capitalize on the flexibility of your dry-erase maps by sketching diagrams and larger maps in addition to encounter maps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Save your creative energy and use published flavor-text as much as it suits you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Foxgrove Manor in the Rise of the Runelords adventure book makes for an excellent haunted house adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players spend time exploring a city, restocking supplies, and gathering info. Throw in an encounter if it gets too quiet.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be mindful of your game's ending time. It's better to end with your players hungry than it is to leave with them tired and bored.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did one of your players miss the previous game? Ask them how they got back to the PCs. Let players drive their return.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A series of small two sentence handouts leads the story better than pages of background material. Expose the story gradually.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If skills are cumbersome in your game, add a set of generic attribute DC checks. 10, 15, 20 works well for easy to hard.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify what makes your campaign unique among campaigns. Make it simple for your players to understand these ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't need much more than a good book of monsters to run a #dnd game with just about any campaign world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on one particular small area in your campaign. Don't go too big in the beginning.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Missing a week? Write up some flash fiction and send it around to keep your players thinking about the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch, read, and listen. Steal ideas from everywhere to incorporate into your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend time immersing yourself in medieval art, armor, and architecture to build a fertile bed for #dnd improv.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of interesting characters from your favorite books, movies, and shows to keep in mind during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if you don't get to play them all, digging through other RPG rule books can give you some great ideas for your own game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use your favorite action scenes as models for your own encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep descriptions as brief and focused as you can. Impact = message / words.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before you drop a monster on the table, take the time to review it's stat block to look for any oddities you might miss.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even PC death can lead to interesting story paths. Revenge is a great motivation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful giving monsters too many surprise rounds. Ensure the PCs get the drop on the monsters once in a while.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to find a stat-block you can reskin instead of spending your time building a monster from scratch.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The substitution cypher are a great puzzle mechanic that's really easy to set up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As long as the threat of a major villain is clear, it doesn't matter if the PCs wipe it out in the first round.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Simple substitution cyphers can make for interesting ancient wall scrawlings.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build some musical playlists that fit the general themes of your campaign. Play when appropriate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Turn the Pathfinder ghost monster into a solo by spreading its attack dice across multiple targets.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Battle getting stale? Make sure to throw in some visual imagery or story hooks to remind players you're in a story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have your players summarize the last session so you know what they remembered and what is important to them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players about the details and background of their new fancy magic weapons. Put storytelling in their hands!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to steer players away from their character concepts. Try to change your campaign to fit their ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lay out city or region maps before your game to remind everyone how far they've come and how far they have to go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Like Fate Core, award action points when characters put themselves at a disadvantage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on a number of creatures instead of a big powerful one to avoid getting "save or sucked".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave journal notes on your dead bosses to teach the players a little big about the guy they just killed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is a scene starting to drag out? Kill an NPC! Blow something up! Open a gateway to hell! Fireball the village! Red dragon attacks!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of your larger encounter areas like big zones that resemble the levels in Dishonored with lots of different paths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pair your traps together to keep your PCs on their toes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always know the most important elements an NPC has to relay to a PC during an interaction. Jot them down in bullets.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to skip the boring travel parts of an adventure and get right to the meaty bits.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pair your traps together to keep your PCs on their toes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a set of rich location areas on hand as your players explore areas you hadn't prepared.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Skip the boring parts. Use cut scenes, montages, or groupings of skill checks to move to the interesting stuff quick.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down interesting and usable room, zone, or encounter effects on 3x5 cards so players stay aware of them. Thanks @mikemearls
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Fate Core zone aspect is a great way to think about encounter effects. Helps you focus on what matters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running Next, write enemy ACs on a visible 3x5 card so players know if they hit or not. Thanks @jasonmflow!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write enemy ACs on a visible 3x5 card so players know if they hit or not.  Thanks @jasonmflow!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Judge in favor of the players in descriptive combat. "Can I get around him without provoking?" "Sure!"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get your players to say "done" at the end of their turn to speed up rounds. This will speed up just about any game with turns.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add layers of history to the areas your PCs explore. Describe ancient statues lost in the forest.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The secret accounts and ledgers of your villains can make for excellent handouts containing valuable clues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare adventure locations that can be used for a variety of situations to keep your game flexible but well prepared.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There's no need to be negative about other game systems in order to be positive about the one you love.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Rewatch some of your favorite old movies to reinforce story seeds, adventure locations, and rich NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Include an appropriate set of treasure rewards in your lazy DM toolkit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even pre-gen characters should have some elements they can customize. Consider how 13th Age handles pregens.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a more open-ended game, keep your adventure locations abstract from the threats or villains they might find there.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep things exciting by describing the actions of your monsters in prose rather than just the math results.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always prepare a strong beginning for your game. No one likes to see a deer in the headlights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking for a good way to handle a travel scene? Try @hellcowkeith's Travel Montage:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you have the means, adding some 3d components to your encounter locations can really get players excited.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a clear "Game is starting" line to let your players know your game is beginning and side conversations should cool off.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Regardless of system, four to six players tends to be ideal to give players enough screen-time during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Another universal tip from @13thAge; ask your players what elements of the story they want to see return in the future.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the main points you need to get across in your starting scene for your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drive new story elements from the actions and interactions of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always consider what fantastic element is taking place.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal the idea of the "living dungeon" in @13thAge to make unrealistic PC-hating dungeons interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build your own campaign worksheet that focuses on the elements of your game most interesting and fun for the group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the true origin of your mysterious villains a secret - even from yourself! Let the truth come as the story expands:...
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add one environmental element usable by your PCs and NPCs in every battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Time to dust off your copy of Ravenloft and schedule your yearly halloween game!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to integrating new PCs into the group. It can be clumsy if you don't clear a good path to tie them together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force a fight over a parlay with a hostile enemy. Let the scene play out from the motivations of PCs and NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on preparing the stuff that most makes you feel comfortable improvising at the table. What you actually use is secondary.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When you can, try answering questions with questions to give players the agency to build out part of the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always know what makes any particular battle interesting. Figure out what part of the story you can tell.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try thinking about your settings and locations as their own sort of NPC. What does this dungeon actually WANT?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Exploding mushrooms are a great environmental effect for nasty swamps or damp natural caverns.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The search for lost magic is always a great motivation for PCs, NPCs, and villains.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get to a fight in the first hour of your game to keep things interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Come up with improvised interesting terrain effects for the terrain features found on pre-printed maps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a hand-full of pre-printed maps handy for your next session. Don't feel like you have to use them all.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Dungeon Command tiles for quick and flexible terrain setups with lots of little interesting details built in.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Knowing what to reveal and what to keep hidden is a big part of the art of Dungeon Mastering.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe individual character scenes while waiting for other players to show up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In 13th Age, on an icon roll of 6, give a PC a free skill success on a related skill check.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Monster trapped far away? Give it an improvised ranged attack based on the mechanics of its least powerful melee attack.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try out a Theater of the Mind battle in your next game just to stretch your wings a bit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep Theater of the Mind battles simple, fast, and flavorful. Go out of your way to describe the action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep in mind that a player's investment in their character is often greater than their investment in your story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If one PC seems to outshine the rest, ensure you design encounters that let others outshine just as much.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's not enough to write a 3x5 card to prepare for your game, you have to READ the stupid thing DURING the game to get the benefit
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Finding creative entrances for the PCs of part-time players is a great time to improve your improvisational techniques.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of interesting story bits to drop in throughout your adventure at opportune moments.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find ways for PCs to use environmental hazards to their advantage. Reward them for doing so.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the PCs find a way to circumvent a particularly dangerous threat, let them do so and applaud their ingenuity.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Finding the right balance between story and combat can be one of the hardest talents we DMs face.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The 13th Age Living Dungeon is a great way to justify your convoluted contrived dungeon tropes. The dungeon IS an NPC!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes your next battle unique among battles? What element of the story will it move forward?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you're stuck for ideas, go back to the PC's backgrounds and themes and build off of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Two-stage battles, with the second enemy or set of enemies coming in near the end, makes for a great epic fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the wise words of @rdonoghue and build some of your game off of the PCs' strengths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bad guys who surrender are great vehicles to give PCs useful information. It's commonly used but still great.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of character hooks your players care about on hand while pondering your next adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End your mini-campaign with a "what happens two years later?" montage. Let the players drive it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Listen to the discussion of players to each other to understand what they are really absorbing from your bullshit story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Published adventures make great guidelines but never feel like you have to run them word for word. Make them your own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find out what makes each player love their PC. Use that as a cornerstone for the expanding story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Everybody poops! Who is your Lord of Sewers?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A fast and easy way to tie a group to an adventure is to let them, as a group, choose a single faction to already align with.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Flash forwards are a great way to show your group the excitement that's about to come.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your players come up with a villain they want to hunt, replace the one you had come up with that they don't know about.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Location maps under a plexiglass sheet makes for a great table setting for your D&D game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the party splits up during an investigation scene, make sure to switch between the groups often to keep the players engaged.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Preparing interesting NPCs, their motivations, and interesting adventure locations is always worth while.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Refer back to a nice overland map as the PCs travel throughout the adventure. Give them a sense of place.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be a slave to canon. Your instance of a shared game world is yours to twist and change to keep your game fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes "majority rules" doesn't work for a group's decision. Sometimes it needs to be unanimous if the stakes are high.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus your preparation on interesting locations and rich NPCs. Let the story grow naturally at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's always worth reviewing what people enjoyed and didn't enjoy at your game. Don't take criticism personally.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How did your past year of #dnd go? How do you want your next year to go? Reflect!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always consider the variables that make scenes interesting: environment, NPCs, evolving circumstances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build opportunities for each character to shine. Give them a chance to be the best in a scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal your favorite adventure locations from any published adventure you can find. Aim for interesting and unique details.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can always steal NPC ideas from your favorite book, movie, or TV characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal NPC physical descriptions from one fictional character and the personality from another so players can't guess who it is.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of plotting out your campaign, set the pieces in place, push it forward with a story hook, and see where it goes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always remember, the PCs are the real heroes of the game. Not your favorite NPC, not your game world, and not your story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random encounters can sometimes lead your game's story into awesome new directions. Don't fear them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider adding Jarasson, Founder of Guilds, into your city for a bit of added NPC variety.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Railroading isn't always evil. Sometimes your group just wants to watch their PC mechanics work.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is your group taking some time off? Take the time to consider what they enjoy most and developing interesting adventure locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good video games can be an excellent source of inspiration for your tabletop game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always include a clear villain in your game. Moral ambiguity isn't always that much fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How are the three pillars of #dnd; exploration, roleplaying, and combat;  incorporated into your game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Incorporate in-game holidays to match real-world holidays to give some feeling of seasons into your world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Adventure seeds, fantastic locations, and interesting NPCs are the three cornerstones of a good #dnd adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all groups thrive on difficult choices. Don't overload your players with moral quandaries all the time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always get to the point with your flavor text or narratives. Know the important elements and get them out fast and back to action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take material from any game system. Don't worry about what brand goes with what system, steal from everywhere.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If level 1 and 2 feels too wimpy for your more advanced #dndnext players, don't fret starting at level 3.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When converting or running old modules, look for the seeds that made them unique and fantastic. Cut the boring shit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seek every chance to get feedback on your game. Always look for ways to improve it and make it more fun for the group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seize the opportunity to let your players grab the story and run. Don't shut them down to tell your own story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of trying to mold the PCs around your published adventure, mold the adventure around the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always favor changing the story to bring the PCs backgrounds into play.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seek to understand what interests each of your players in your game the most and try to give it to them often.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be ready to abbreviate sections of your adventure to fit the time you have allowed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a break to figure out how to make an unexpected success interesting:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Turn unexpected successes into interesting story turns like @mikemearls:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the wise words of @mikemearls and let your old campaign die to grow a new one:
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: With any encounter, what bit of information will the PCs learn that moves the story forward?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From @montecook, don't ever feel like you have to fill everything out. Leave blanks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Notes between NPCs are a great physical reminder to players of their potential paths, options, villains, and quests.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every clue needs to make sense at the time the PCs receive it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Combining traps is a great way to make every trap unique and deadly. A spiked pit filled with exploding fire pots? Whooyeaahhh!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reward players with +1 single-use bonuses when they remember NPC names or intricate plot threads.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget to use your handouts as a way to organize your game's threads.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never forget that your primary intent is cultivating a great time with good friends. That, and TPKs...Thanks @theangrydm!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How easy or hard it is for your group to uncover clues is an element of your game worth paying attention to.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before you put a lot of brain time into a new campaign, ensure it's the kind of campaign your players want to play.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time inserting treasure into your adventure. It's easily forgotten. Every sword has a name.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dungeon Command tiles make for quick random encounter maps including interesting terrain features.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's always worth having a few battle maps ready for the areas your PCs may choose to visit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choose a different spell or two to differentiate your spellcaster NPCs. Flavor them to the theme of the NPC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The random encounter charts in the original DMG work just as well today as they did 35 years ago.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For big events, spend the time to really plan out an interesting encounter. Railroading isn't always bad.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before you plan your campaign, let your players build PC backstories. Use what they build to generate ideas for the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think less of your game as a story arc and more as a free flowing and ongoing tale.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your PCs some piles of mooks to eat through so they can remember what it's like to be powerful
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players decide what limits you might incorporate into your game such as a limited set of 13th Age icons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Conventions are the perfect time to run that new game system you've always wanted to run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know where you might cut your material to get your game to end on time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: During your descriptions, don't worry about going from big to small details. Focus in and zoom out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A pile of one-hit bad guys who still can throw out damage make for a fast and threatening encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give Story Cubes to your players and have them describe the history of every bad guy they kill.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If pressed for time, replace monsters with nasty environmental effects like poison gas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When preparing a new campaign, write a short "five things about this campaign" guide to guide both you and your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't veto the backgrounds your players come up with, use them to enrich the campaign all of you build together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When starting a new campaign, pick one particular area and focus on it. Pour in fantastic locations and deep NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time coming up with interesting magic items based on the PCs to sprinkle throughout your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the keen advice of Dungeon World: ask questions and use the answers to build adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend time considering what tools you need to aid your ability to improvise during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What's your campaign about?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take @robheinsoo's advice and don't sweat the results of the @13thAge icon rolls too much.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to the dead spaces in your game so you know what to prep for your next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have an idea what your key NPCs are going to say when approached. Nothing's worse than uncomfortable PC / NPC silence.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always have three paths ready to offer in case your group doesn't really know where they want to head next.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Experiment with interesting house rules on the GM side of the table but let your players know what you're up to.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "What do you think?" and "you tell me!" are fine ways to skirt the issue that you don't know what the hell you're talking about.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes your player aren't looking for open-ended storytelling. Give them some plots and fights to keep them engaged.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players what they enjoyed and what they would have changed at the end of each game you run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: give your group at least one interesting NPC to roleplay with each game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get creative with your set-piece battlespaces. Use Legos, Lincoln Logs, whatever!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to add at least one interesting environmental effect to each battle you run that bit PCs and monsters can use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe powerful spellcasters as using magical forms of protection to give them such high hit points.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players 3 + infinite options. They can pick one of three clear paths or choose their own in a new direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the first cool scene and setting you want to describe at the beginning of your next adventure?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time after your game to review what worked, what didn't, and what areas you wish you had spent more time preparing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did your PCs turn 180 degrees away from that awesome dungeon you prepared? Maybe it should move 180 degrees as well!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Separate dungeons and encounter areas from monsters and villains to help you customize encounters based on PC decisions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force player participation in group storytelling if they don't want to do it. Some folks want to relax and enjoy the ride.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Improving improvisation skills takes practice and time. Be patient and persistent.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep three villains in mind and consider how their actions and motivations affect the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you can't remember the PC's names, you likely aren't paying enough attention to them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Awesome fiction spawns from mashed up ideas. Combine two traps, two characters, two dungeons, or two scenes into one awesome one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use skill checks to uncover parts of a puzzle when players have a hard time figuring it out. Fail forward with hard moves.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Split up battles with exploration, puzzles, investigation, and roleplaying to change up the pace of your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep battles interesting by mixing up monster types or adding an interesting dangerous terrain feature.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to start your game with action. What does the world do? What can the PCs do?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Group players together that are working on different parts of a scene so they're not yelling over one another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use skill checks or @13thAge icon rolls to give clues to puzzles when people are stuck.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Resist the urge to tell players what they missed or how the story could have gone but didn't based on their actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: @montecook's Return to the Temple of Elemental Evil has some fantastic maps to hack into your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: My most valuable tip: Relax, have fun, and go with what the players give you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "Theater of the mind" combat works well in simple rooms with a single type of monster.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use handouts to organize NPCs, locations, and motivations for both you and your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Check with each of your players independently face to face to see how they feel about the game and the atmosphere.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a player's assumption ends up being better than the truth, go with it. The truth is highly malleable in your #dnd game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill your "theater of the mind" battles with flavor and detail. Bulbous otherworldly spiders slick and dripping with black oil.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep track of your time and pacing of your game. Use a stopwatch or alarm to keep track. Thanks @JTGrummell!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get everyone's attention by starting your adventure with some action. Nothing gets a table's attention like "roll for initiative!"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Trim down exposition and narration. Stick to important details and turn the story back over to the players fast.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can hide some shoddy story work or poor sandboxing with a beautiful and interesting encounter area.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave open the party's next course of action until the beginning of your next game so there's no way to prep ahead of time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Assign a table auditor to check on those strange character abilities that just don't seem right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a few groups of monsters at your PC's power level on hand for improvised encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Immerse yourself in great fiction (books, movies, TV shows) and steal liberally for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to fix small errors in your story threads. Embrace the fun with an old sage named Lord Retcon who fixes truths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about ways to improvise the goals in battles where slaughter isn't the only choice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know when to call for a break during your game, both for yourself and for the group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What feature makes your town fantastic and memorable?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take adventure inspiration from interesting tactical maps, miniatures, and artwork you come across.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force the direction of a scene. Progress the scene on the actions of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Powerful monsters should mean something. Avoid low level lichs, death knights, and beholders.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't eclipse the actions of PCs with the actions of NPCs. The PCs are the heroes of your story, not your favorite NPC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Releasing a bound beast is a great potential "combat out" for an encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players to summarize the game to one another and use what they remember to steer its direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use @13thAge Icon rolls of 5 to determine which evil agenda moves forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have players describe the history behind weapons or magic items they find.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you stick in a large environmental effect into your encounter, make sure PCs have a way to screw with it. Don't just make it so
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you only have one type of monster in a fight, make the fight fast or it will get pretty boring.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Combine two encounters, a clear goal, and some interesting encounter effects into your own Lair Assault style scenario.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A plexiglass sheet over a blank gridded flip mat makes for excellent dry-erase battle map options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a mix of simple narrative combat with more detailed big-set battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put out interesting terrain into your battle space and let players improvise their use. Say yes!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Physical icon tokens in your @13thAge for 5 and 6 rolls gives players the ability to improvise their uses and saves you energy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Comb through old adventures, find interesting rooms, and skip the boring parts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even in an open improvised game, it's important that goals are clear for the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you have more than five PCs, you'll likely have to step up the number of monsters even more to make up for PC synergy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force improvised montages on players. Let them volunteer for it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Key location questions: Why is it interesting? What is it now? What did it used to be? What makes it fantastic?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bosses in boss fights almost always need a way to protect themselves from a PC nuclear strike.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Many players don't mind a railroaded story. Some are just happy to enjoy the ride.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There's room for interesting choices even in railroad campaigns. NPC interaction, kill or free villains, battle tactics, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players a choice to kill or capture villains on defeat. Dropping to zero hp doesn't have to mean death.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always consider how NPC's would react to the words or deeds of the PCs. Don't force their reaction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't presume how PCs or players will approach or follow through on a scene. Go with their direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a portfolio of interesting, relevant, fantastic, and detailed adventure locations always on hand.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write and keep an NPC dossier when building NPCs on the fly. It's easy to forget them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use each battle as a way to experiment with challenge and difficulty. Make small yet interesting changes to see how they work out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every battle needs to be a balanced challenge. Short and easy battles can reveal a deeper world not built around the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give clues into the origins of interesting NPCs to keep your players' guessing. If they guess right, reinforce their victory.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: break up exposition and narrative by turning the spotlight back to the PCs often, especially if they're split up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Experiment with other game systems and steal liberally to make your main game better.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Discovery is a huge draw in our games. What can the PCs discover in your next game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep note of the names and fates of NPCs the PCs let go. Where are they now? What are they doing?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players a regular recap of the major factions they face and the major decisions that lay ahead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When teaching someone new to #dnd, begin with the concept of cooperative storytelling and explain the idea of rolling d20 checks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Many of the techniques for protecting elite bosses work well in @13thAge as they did in 4th Edition.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use poster maps to give you ideas of the dungeons the PCs may explore.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Being distracted players back to the game with a calm "what does your character do?"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: New players can easily get lost in lingo and acronyms. Take the time to explain them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let new players reference popular examples (Aragorn, Hawkeye, the Hulk) when defining their characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go ahead and let your players know how many hit points a monster has. Save your mysteries for elsewhere.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take all advice, including these tips, at your peril. Most tips are hypotheses and experiments stated in the declarative.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep handy a list of monsters appropriate for the PCs to face based on power level or location. Improvise battles as they fit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the players decide what loot is in a treasure horde. Build their results into the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Vampires and their spawn make for great waves of monsters that mix into the PCs in mist form.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can railroad your encounters and locations but still give PCs lots of opportunities to make meaningful choices.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't bother doing much more than an outline beyond your next session. A lot can happen between now and then.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use story dice and face cards to help you avoid stereotypical storylines. Thanks @wamplify!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a good handle on the appropriate DCs for your potential improvised environmental effects or challenges.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good evening's adventure has four to six scenes: intro, encounter, exploration, encounter, ending is a solid model.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you see a pile of narrative coming on, ask yourself what meaningful choices the PCs can make as part of it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Staged multi-wave battles are a great way to build huge epic fights without wiping out the party with too many monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your adventures off with some action! Save the background and story for bits and pieces interleaved within action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Send emails to your players with narrative you don't want to bother describing at the table. Work off of what they remember.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix dungeon tiles, dwarven forge, and dry-erase maps for some really interesting 3d battlescapes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hit points represent whatever you and your group want them to represent. Quit worrying about what the pundits say.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can use @13thAge style distances to speed up your #dnd Next game with "near", "far", and "engaged" distances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can use #dnd's "inspiration" mechanic in just about any game that doesn't already have something like this.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: #dnd's "inspiration" can be used in ways outside of just gaining advantage. It can be a license to bend the rules or even the...
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you're nervous but curious about narrative combat, try it out on a small battle against a single type of monster in a simple...
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes a boss monster getting killed with a single powerful attack defines the Rule of Cool. Go with it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Video game soundtracks make for great background #dnd music. Try Assassins Creed 4, Borderlands 2, and Mass Effect 3.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always seek to add interesting choices into narrative scenes of exploration. How can the PCs make a difference?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Boss monsters should almost always have defending support monsters at their sides.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There are few game aids more useful than a Paizo flip mat and a dry-erase marker.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When adding a sixth player to a group, you'll likely need more than just an equal amount of additional monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players choose NPCs to lead charges in an epic battle. Make sure there's good reason to choose the right NPC for the right...
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of your adventure as a current situation with variables rather than a series of scenes one after another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When you have a boss monster, make sure it has minions who can put the threat on those the boss can't attack.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin monsters to create monster-behaving environmental effects like living fire or animated traps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a moment to restate the layout and situation of the scene to aid wandering minds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Study artwork from other RPGs to fuel your imagination for whatever game you play.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make it clear when it's OK to split the party up for multiple lines of investigation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Inattention between GMs and players can self propigate into a viscious cycle. Pay attention to the inattentive player.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask yourself why your players might be thinking that you're working against them instead of with them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The wild magic chart on the new #dnd PHB page 104 makes for an excellent wild magic area effect. @gsllcs was here!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is your world full of excitement and adventure or does it simply make the lives of the PCs difficult?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If players are gravitating towards PCs who act like obnoxious asses, remind them of the importance of fun over accurate RPing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your players struggle for threads of investigation, give them something to grab onto.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Its an easy trick to grab attention by starting your adventure off with a battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use @13thage style Icon rolls to keep track of the long-term motions of allies and villains.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Five players is really the sweet spot for a fun dynamic game. Keep your group between 4 and 6 players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's easy to pay attention to the charismatic player. Consciously steer yourself towards the quiet ones.
author: Michael E. Shea
