text: #dnd tip: Plot clues may not be nearly as easy for your players to figure out as you think.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared to improvise motivations for PCs to move forward. Why do they care?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running a group to the end of their ropes? Make the story reason's for their fatigue clear.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid repeatedly sending your group against an overpowered foe. Don't make your players feel weak too often.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build dungeons as actual working environments. If this were a real place, how would it work in daily life?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking for some interesting gang members? Use SAMCRO as your models!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are players choosing actions well outside of your plans? What has to change to go with their ideas?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Feel free to switch from abstract narrative combat to gridded combat depending on what would be most fun at the moment.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When teaching new players, focus on the core mechanic and dive into the story. The rest will come in time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the Wild Magic table from the player's handbook to make some fun chaos magic area effects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Feel free to break out of the perspective of the PCs to let them get a glimpse of the villains they face.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Throw a handful of random trinkets from the player's handbook into various loot hoards the PCs come across.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add your own villain or henchmen to a published adventure so you have one who is all your own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good DM plays in other peoples' games and takes notes on what works well and what doesn't.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Throw in one to two additional bad guys for each extra PC above five.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: With the extra room in your 5e game, relax and let players spend some time considering their options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even in published adventures there is room to add a fantastic element. You can't go wrong with ancient huge statues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't always have to have your players' attention all the time. Sometimes they just want to chill out and check Twitter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add some flavor to your random bad guys. What is the name of the mercenary company? What makes them special?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking for some great NPC templates for your random mercenary company? Look no further!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build out NPC details and implement them on whichever NPC the PC's attention focuses on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When heading into a location, give players the freedom to plan their course of action. Don't force or promote one particular path.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be ready to railroad an adventure if your players are becoming decision weary.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add in details for a few colorful NPCs in any group of random attackers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give ambushers with the high ground "advantage" on attacks to make them that much more dangerous.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When adding a new player with a new PC, go with whatever narrative gets them into the group quickly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running published adventures, change the gender of NPCs or villains to shake up outdated stereotypes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Telegraph gameplay styles into in-game choices. Head into the camp for combat, sneak in from the back for infiltration checks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Carefully balance spotlight time for each PC in interaction and RP scenes just as you do with initiative in combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in new monsters if you find PCs facing the same foes over and over again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give advantage on skill checks when players have a particularly good idea. Use advantage as a reward for creativity.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It can be hard to give each PC enough attention when you have more than five players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful not to pick on the one loud and powerful PC in combat all the time. It's easy to do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the dice decide who gets attacked when monsters don't have a super clear target.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try out different combat styles (narrative, loose, gridded) and ask your group what they think of them. Tune to suit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give #dnd PCs options to take short rests in dynamic dungeons. Hidden or defendable rooms for example.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give weary PCs a "battle surge" that acts as an immediate short rest before boss fights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan the main points or your narrative ahead of time so you don't spend an hour talking bullshit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players the hit that caves and dungeons may be well trapped so they know to watch out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give every major magic item a history, origin, and a name to make them unique and special.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Do you know the names of all the PCs in your game? That's more important than almost any other part of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: NPC wizards might have to rely on Shield to protect themselves. They're big targets.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Having trouble coming up with interesting loot for your 5e game while we wait for the DMG? Use the 1e DMG's random loot tables!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you have a lot of players, reveal the defenses of monsters to speed up combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just because an enemy dropped to zero doesn't mean it died. Maybe it's coughing blood saying "Wait! I have useful information!"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How would more vulnerable villains protect themselves from being the lightning rod of attacks?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take your time to read the spell lists so you can get ideas on spells NPCs and enemies would use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Re-flavor spells based on the background and theme of the enemies who cast them. "Tiamat's Wrath!" instead of Sacred Flame.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes the current location fantastic in the eyes of the PCs? You have a billion dollar effects budget. Use it!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of a random encounter, plan out a fun one-battle side adventure to throw into your game at the right moment.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all dungeons need to be giant sprawling complexes. Some might be only two or three rooms with a small story attached.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's ok to let your PCs steamroll over an encounter. Some of the most memorable battles are one-sided slaughterfests.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Adding PCs above four to your party may decrease the challenge of an encounter more than linearly. Add two beasts per PC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review your PCs' goals, backgrounds, motivations, and story hooks before you run your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players' interest determine which NPCs become the focus instead of you or your published adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read and enjoy #dnd fantasy novels and the Monster Manual to come up with interesting adventure ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: This is a big one. Make sure to reward inspiration to the quiet people at your table. Don't just give it to loudmouths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Look at your list of players and ask yourself who needs more spotlight at your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read published adventures until you can see the fantastic locations in your head. If you can see them, so will your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take note of the quiet gamers at your table and give them good attention.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Come up with a loot system that removes any potential bias you might have for one PC over another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In a linear adventure, ensure the players understand the clear mission that sits in front of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understand the proficiencies of the PCs so you know what challenges and rewards to put in front of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Protect boss villains by having them together in pairs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put out big poster maps of the game world to remind the players where they fit in the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Too many players? Create an "on call" list for those who can substitute in when a regular can't make it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get some one-on-one feedback on your game and really listen to what they have to say about it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Small props can make a big difference in your game. Get some model trees or covered wagons to make a scene pop.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try your hand at narrative combat with a small battle against a single type of foe in an uncomplicated environment.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A good play group takes careful cultivation. Learn how to bring them in and quit worrying about how it "should" work.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the current seasons and holidays as models for the seasons and holidays taking place in your fantasy RPG.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use @asmor's CR calculator before you rain Bugbears on your level 3 party.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give out inspiration to players who write the page numbers of their spells on their spell list sheets.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention PC factions and potential renown points when running @DnD_AdvLeague games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget the importance of quantitative rewards such as experience, levels, gold, loot, and other tangible rewards.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reading fiction set in your game's world is fun homework for adding depth and details to your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did one or more of your players figure out your secret super early? Don't continue to hide it, make it interesting some other way.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be ready for your players to say "nah, not interested" if they don't bite on one of your story hooks. What will you do then?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seasons and weather are great ways to make your adventure feel unique and part of a living world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Throw in side adventures that focus on one particular PC's background. Let one PC be THE hero once in a while.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give weapons fun names like "blacksong" and "vengeance" and "sky's end". They're not just +1 weapons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Old D&D Classic adventures and sourcebooks are a great way to pour yourself into Realmslore.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is your fantastic location? What did it used to be?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: let PCs upgrade weapons near and dear to their hearts instead of forcing them to switch to a better one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to make that bad boss last a little longer? Make it two partner bosses instead!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix limited wishlist rewards with random loot when distributing treasure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Base in-game weather on current real-world weather to help players sympathize with their PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give enemies a cool name even if they're only ever seen once. Everyone and everything has an identity.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the bare minimum you need to have on hand to run a good game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every magic weapon should have a cool name.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend time understanding the spells best used by enemy spell casters. Play them smart.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find opportunities to slide in personal quests for individual PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix individually-selected magic items with random items to mix balance with random interest.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Break up stories into specific clues or tweet-sized lore discoverable with PC skill checks and investigation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start out by digging right into the middle of the action rather than spewing flavor text for 20 minutes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never worry about going outside the bounds of a published adventure. It's YOUR adventure. Feel free to make it your own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up weapons on humanoid monsters to add some flavor with a touch of mechanics in an otherwise straightforward battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What are your villains up to right now?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dream sequences where Tiamat wipes out your level 5 party may seem like fun but not everyone will appreciate the nuance.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce campaign villains so your PCs can build their own Kill Bill style "Death List 5".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if your game is mostly investigation, exploration, and interaction, throw in a battle so the action folks have fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Work with great rolls for NPC interaction. Maybe that villain becomes the party's new toady with a well-placed charisma roll.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time to read over the spell lists so you know what options your players have at their disposal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Semi-intelligent weapons are a great way to give PCs a clue they might otherwise miss. It's the literal clue-stick.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use unique miniatures for villains and show them continually so players can remember them visually.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did an unnamed villain escape? What is their name? Where do they go next?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of having a secret cabal of NPC choose the storyline, put the PCs in the cabal itself! Give them political power.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the story clear but don't shy away from interesting complications. Let the PCs insert these complications as they play.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In a published adventure, always feel free to replace a new NPC with an old one that your players know already.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are assassins hunting down the PCs? What clues are they discovering? How are they hunting them down?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Large enemy organizations have the same communication problems as real ones. Often one side of an org doesn't know of the other.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running a 5e Mage? Shield, Misty Step, and Counterspell are lifesavers. Consider a quick gulp of a potion of invulnerability.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How does your 1,000 year history actually affect what the PCs are doing at your next game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the story threads between episodes of a published adventure. What HAS to happen to keep things on track?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Loose wish lists are a good way to know what treasure you might seed into your adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take inspiration from everywhere. Have a cool mini? Who is the villain it represents?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use miniatures or face cards to represent major villains and reinforce them with your players. Names alone are hard to remember.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When designing your own mini-systems to drop into your game, make sure they're easy to take back out if they suck.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Test out house rules by trying them in just a couple of scenes or battles rather than an all-or-nothing insertion.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down interesting character hooks that come from the PCs as you play. Review them often.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Rewire quest lines to fit the backgrounds of the PCs for built-in story investment.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is your published adventure heading to a boring location? Wrap it in your own ideas until you love it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your PCs a stake and vote at bureaucratic council meetings so they aren't jus waiting for orders.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In published adventures replace new NPCs with old ones your PCs already know and love.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When houseruling, ask yourself what you're REALLY trying to accomplish. Do you really need it?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write adventure summaries between sessions. If they're too long and complicated, that may be an indicator.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sidequests can be fun but give players indicators that it won't screw up main quests if followed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Design encounters so each PC has an opportunity to show off what they do best.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Two enemy spellcasters make it much harder to pin down the one big enemy damage dealer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If players stall in a scene, lay out the decisions and give each one a chance to choose.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When calling for a player vote, check with the minority voters to ensure their game isn't ruined because of the choice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players a chance to "flash back" to a city if they forgot to buy something they wish they had.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time to think about what sorts of magical things (if any) are available in small towns or big cities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Using a Mage from the 5e Monster Manual? Give it a 16 Con and +27 hit points to make it a bit more survivable.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Another tip for 5e Mages. Shield, Counterspell, and Misty Step are your best defensive spells. Mages also have Mage Armor precast
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build your own "random" encounter lists based on the direction and story of your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid random encounters that have no connection to the rest of the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use "random" encounters as a way to show players the details of the world and its history.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave open lots of options for PCs to navigate through sandboxed mysteries, heists, and investigations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always consider how you can incorporate the PCs' backgrounds into your next game session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Combat shouldn't always be a negotiation or stealth failure state. How can combat be a reward instead of a penalty?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spending ten minutes to write a summary of your last session forces you to consider the actions of the PCs rather than just story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the rules for "adjudicating area effects" on page 249 of the DMG to handle blasts, bursts, cones, and lines in narrative.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take your DM screen and lay it flat so you don't build a wall between you and the players. You're all on the same side.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use hoard treasure rewards pg. DMG page 137 every couple of game sessions to make your life easier and the game more interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't have to memorize everything. Know enough of the rules to be confident in moving the game forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes your next adventure interesting and exciting? What are the hooks per session and per encounter?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't like the battle you're seeing in a published adventure? What battle do you wish was there? Do that.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is your group a bit more powerful than expected? Max the monster's hit points from their hit dice instead of using the average.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When preparing your next game, start with a review of the PCs, their backgrounds, and motivations. Build off of those.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll on tables in the Dungeon Master's Guide to help break out of stereotypes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't like the way a boss battle played out? Maybe they were just a henchman for a silent overseer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use two interesting monsters in a battle so the PCs don't just focus fire on a single one and kill it in the first round.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to your reference material and DM screen. It's easy to overlook the stuff right in front of you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the main interesting things you want to get across in your next session. Reference it often during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Switch out NPC and monster weapons to make each one of them unique.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Turn maguffins into relics so those useless objects become things the PCs can use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dealing with overpowered PCs or a strong group? Increase encounter power by tuning around  one extra PC than you actually have.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use physical clues, skill checks, and NPC narratives to spell out the interesting history of the region.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up two or three ways the PCs can find a vital clue or required physical item.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go with what seems the most fun first and then what makes sense in the scene second.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep light: Where does your adventure start? What are the main scenes? What PC-driven seeds or clues exist? Wing the rest.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: PCs doing a bunch more damage than you expect? Max monster hit points instead of using the average.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your players know that flat DCs for skill checks means they don't have to focus just on high attribute skills.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some players don't resonate with open sandboxes, make their potential options clear with opportunities for other ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Attunement to only 3 magic items means you can give out a lot of interesting treasure without fear of overpowered PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down a list of ten or twenty clues PCs might discover anywhere in an adventure that reinforce the story or the background.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep track of the number of battles between short rests. If it's been more than 3, find a way to give them the equivalent.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are the players trying to find a non-traditional way to deal with a battle? Go with it! Find ways to make it work.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go big with the descriptions of the battle in narrative combat. Ask players to describe their actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even small battles should have something to draw in the players. What are they fighting for? What's the real pressure?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: No cleric in the party? Probably a good time for the PCs to find boxes of healing potions laying around!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: More than five PCs? Throw in two monsters per PC above 5.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What ten clues might your PCs learn in your next adventure?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 5e uses average hit points for monsters. There's no reason you can't raise or lower it depending on the power of your group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Aerial combat is a great way to shake up a traditional fight now and again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Speed up combat by ignoring the grid and saying what is "within a move action" or not.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill your encounter with objects and "toys" that could be used to improvise actions by either side.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: All good magic items have names and interesting descriptions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down a list of the magic items you'd like to give away across your whole campaign. Review it before every adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe weapons, armor, or notable physical features as a way to identify one monster from another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force a battle if your players find a creative way around it. Go with the flow of the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give boss monsters max hit points and a couple of 18 attributes to make them a little harder than the standard beastie.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Large enemy organizations have the same communication problems and internal politics. That's fun for PCs to navigate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop a few Fate-like "aspects" into your combat encounter that your PCs can "invoke" to make a battle more dynamic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Round dice pools bigger than six by removing a pair of dice and adding 1 + the max value of the die for each pair removed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running Hoard of the Dragon Queen and Rise of Tiamat? It's worth printing a poster of the Sword Coast map.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did your PCs just raid a Red Wizard's library? Write "Red Wizard Books and Scrolls" on a 3x5 card and let them learn from it later
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to let PCs negotiate their way out of a fight even if it wasn't what you planned.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Discuss the moral boundaries of the PCs early in your campaign to keep your players happy together at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use miniatures to represent key villains in a campaign. Bring them out regularly to remind the players who they're up against.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Fate-style "Aspects" to define interesting components in your encounter. Let players improvise how they work.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Initiative can have a huge effect on combat. What will you do if all the monsters go first? What if they all go last?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Speed up combat by skipping initiative, letting all the players go first around the table, and adding a few extra monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful having boss monsters flee from a fight. Players may rarely consider this a victory.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to prevent PCs from finding a creative way to circumvent a major enemy. Sometimes banishing a major demon is great fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players "what did you enjoy most about today's game" to get good, positive, and useful feedback.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 5e rule of thumb for building combat encounters: have one monster per PC with a CR of 1/3 the value of the PC's level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to loot rewards. Mix random loot with hand-picked items to give PCs both useful and interesting things.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Where does your game start? What are three interesting potential scenes or locations? That's about all you need to run a game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to remember the names of each of the PCs. It's the first step in making the game about them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reinforce the need to build well-rounded PCs that have something they can do in interaction, exploration, and combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: a single NPC mage in a fight is likely to have spells countered continually. Add a second mage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't get mad when your big boss gets disrupted. Limiting the effectiveness of bosses is fun too.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players a large view of the location and let them decide how they'll get inside.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "What did you enjoy most about the game?" is a good positive way to get feedback about what people enjoy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Encounters shouldn't all be well balanced but ensure players get the clue when it isn't.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always look for ways to offer inspiration for players' creative and story-building ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force the PCs to go into that crazy encounter you designed if they aren't headed there already.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players what they enjoyed most about the game. Write down their answers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The less time you spend designing boss monsters the less you'll give a shit when they're killed too easily.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mages won't cast magic missile on other mages unless they're too stupid to know better.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have the freedom to add silly elements into the game like an orc walking into a room in a ruffled apron that says "kiss the chef".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did your monsters get the drop on the PCs or vice versa? Switch to side-initiative and save a bunch of time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Outline your campaign's big beats but don't fill in the details until the PCs are about to get directly involved.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes your next fantasy location interesting and fantastic?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force the story to ensure a villain gets away but play villains smart. Let the players see how smart they are.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 250 word flash fiction in email is a great way to give players a glimpse of the movements of villains and off-camera NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Intelligent magic items are the NPCs that keep on giving. Great for giving clues to the PCs when needed most.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's quite interesting when the alignment of intelligent magic items and the PCs who wield them don't quite match.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use randomly selected targets to ensure you aren't biasing attacks or giving the perception that you are.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When you come up with a random name for a random NPC. Write it down. You'll never know when you meet them again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just like combat initiative, ensure every player gets a chance to do something interesting in a roleplay scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your game preparation by reviewing the PCs and their hooks. Can you build your next adventure off of that?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use pictures from the internet to define key NPCs your players will see more than once.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't punish PCs for splitting up in a town. If they're going to get in a fight, find a way for the groups to get back together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the PCs split up in an investigation or roleplay scene, ensure each group gets the right amount of screentime.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When rolling for random weapons and armor, define the type to make sure it's useful for PCs in need.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Send out an email RIGHT NOW to learn the birthdays of your players (and DMs!) and celebrate with a game focused on their PC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes players are happy to have a clear direction and a set of focused and well-designed encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write out a random encounter list for each level range and location type your PCs are likely to visit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your PCs are having an easy time with "hard" fights. Treat them as though they have one extra PC for a big difficulty boost.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Whenever you're lost thinking of a direction for your story, look back at the PC backgrounds and work from there.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a good gauge of what your group enjoys and what they find too disturbing. Make the game comfortable for everyone.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Each encounter or scene should have a seed or series of clues to help the players see the bigger picture.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't bring monsters out one at a time or they're likely to all get nuked one round after the next.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use artwork you find on the web to show your players people, places, and things. Save the ones that matter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use physical coins (like @campaigncoins!) to represent Inspiration, Icon Rolls, or Fate Points in your RPGs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in two types of monsters in a battle to make it more interesting and increase the choices players have to make.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to give a monster a special attack that represents its unique place in the world or the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of each encounter as a puzzle. What do the PCs need to do to succeed? It shouldn't always be "kill the monsters".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In 5e, you can use a monsters with CR significantly higher than the PCs above level 5 or so as long as there is only one of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want some large-scale environmental damage? Use 1d10 per level / 4 and give them a Con save to avoid or half it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix pre-planned treasure designed for the PCs with a good pile of randomly generated treasure for fun weird stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the PCs haven't gotten any loot in a while, give them a roll or two on one of the higher-end loot charts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For interesting environmental effects, tie concentration spells to destructable objects and place them in a villain's lair.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of planning out roleplay encouhters, create three NPCs with motivations and backgrounds and improvise it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: At higher levels in 5e, you can challenge tough PCs with monsters with a CR higher than the average PC level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give bosses a way to reroute debilitating "save or suck" effects to their minions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Intelligent weapons are fantastic quest NPCs for side trecks. Give PCs quests to upgrade their intelligent weapons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When you split the party, ensure you take care to give each group their share of screen time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't let NPC's overshadow player characters. Any powerful NPC should be severely limited in a way that PCs can offset.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use random charts to avoid cliche grooves we often fall into when forced to improvise stories.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use multiple spellcasters in a fight to keep a single caster from being destroyed too quickly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customize monsters by changing weapon types. The gnoll with the two hand-axes and the gnoll with the glaive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use short flash fiction in email to give players a view behind the scenes only involving the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let humor come spontanously at the table. Don't try to push it away or attempt to plan for it ahead of time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What evocative scene will you open with at the start of your next session?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even the biggest and baddest dragon is likely to have an ally or two in a fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drawing from a spell card deck is a good way to determine a random spell on a scroll.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Villains aren't static. They don't sit on their thrones or in their chambers waiting for the PCs. What are THEY doing?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't box your PCs into a corner. Success should lead down one interesting road and failure leads down another interesting road.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What secrets and clues might your PCs uncover in your next adventure? Sprinkle them in wherever they fit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What opportunities exist in your next game for interesting NPC interaction and fantastic exploration? What will they uncover?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep an eye on your players. Are they bored? Frustrated? Disengaged? Draw them back into the game with something they enjoy
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In scenes of heavy narration or exposition, give your players plenty of meaningful choices to make.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the names of NPCs who start to resonate with your players. They're likely to come back.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take careful note of the attention you're paying to each player. Don't let any of them get lost in the crowd.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes annoying NPCs can be the most fun for you and your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give flat bonus magic items interesting backgrounds, appearances, and traits. Give them a lot of fun flavor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Show your PCs the value of their gold. If they invest in a stronghold, show them what got upgraded for their cash.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is your villain or NPC unsure how to act? Maybe they ask the PCs for advice!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you find yourself saying "no" a lot when it comes to approaching a situation, maybe you want to make it more open.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give PCs good opportunities to use their crazy powerful abilities. Don't just short circuit them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find opportunities to bring back older NPCs and villains. Don't make your players remember all new people when old ones will do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always find an interesting event going on in town. Town's anniversary? Birthday party for a hero? The pigs got loose?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What PC hook ties in to the next adventure you're about to run?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Does one PC have a significantly high skill check? Let their obnoxiously high results tell something even more interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dig into the Monster Manual monster descriptions for some great adventure seed ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Princes of the Apocalypse is packed with great NPC monster stat blocks. Reskin to suit your own adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary of using monsters of a challenge rating higher than the PCs' level. Add more monsters, not bigger ones.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In narrative combat, give players a choice of 1d6 enemies in a burst if they don't target their friends or 2d6 if they do!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give PCs interesting quests to upgrade their magic items with added artifact-style properties.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use monster groups and themes to give an adventure an overall consistent flavor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time ahead of time to learn the spells your monsters are likely to use. Write down page numbers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build swarms of ghouls and zombies by re-skinning higher CR monster stat blocks and using swarm traits.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful of falling into the trap of spilling too much narrative when you don't know what to do with the table. Ask for a break.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running Rise of Tiamat? How about sending high-level PCs to the Mausoleum of Ebondeath!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bring back old NPCs in longer campaigns to reward the players who paid attention early on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build interesting fixtures into a combat area that evoke the details and history of a location.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use emailed flash fiction to give players a sense of the larger picture in their campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Because most magic items in 5e have flat math, don't fret giving too many out as long as they aren't all +3 weapons and armor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be fans of the PCs first and foremost (thank you Dungeon World!)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know the capabilities of the PCs, not just to thwart them but to give them the chance to show off.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix monster types so they won't all suck at the same thing. Do all your monsters have the same key attributes? Mix it up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are some of your monsters likely to get screwed by a "save or suck" spell? Consider adding a couple more.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your boss monsters legendary resistance and telegraph it to the players so they don't burn out spells finding out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan loot ahead of time and give your monsters a chance to show them off in a battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need to spice up a boring hallway? Try a random two-effect trap to make things exciting!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Legendary encounter design is a careful balance of challenge and PC empowerment. You must include both.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every battle needs to be a well-designed masterpiece. A quick skirmish is fine if it adds to the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: With legendary monsters, it's easy to forget your lair actions and legendary actions. Give yourself physical tokens to remember.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to increase a legendary monster's hit points by 25% for each additional PC above 4. Max HP is fine too.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give legendary creatures an extra action for fun things like magic item use or interesting spells.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Expect players to pour everything they have onto your legendary monster. Max HPs or rerouting damage can help mitigate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Temporary monsters who come and go can spice up a legendary encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider using a hit point pool when you have more than eight monsters of the same type in a battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What five fantastic locations will you stage your adventures in during your next game? What makes them fantastic?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a random NPC generator to make every humanoid enemy unique and interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 5e Beholders fight well outside their weight class, especially when they make the most out of flying and the antimagic eye.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What three interesting things do you want to ensure you describe to the players when they enter the location for a scene?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try rolling in the open to force yourself to adapt to unexpected dice rolls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start each adventure prep session by going over the backgrounds and motivations of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the 5e vampire an extra melee attack, double it's damage dice, and make charm break if the PC takes 10 damage from any source
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is an encounter going to start with something other than a straight fight? Jot down some notes on the start of it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never miss an opportunity to foreshadow an interesting enemy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Name every villain by using the Sly Flourish random name generator!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking to fill in a hallway with something interesting? Try a two-part random trap.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build your villainous lair in a way that makes sense from the point of view of the villain.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: An ancient forgotten temple to Shar under Waterdeep makes for a great assassin's guild hall for the Night Masks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to beef up that NPC mage? Start it off with mage armor, mirror image, and greater invisibility.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't give a PC a secret unless you're prepared for the player to not share it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can almost never go wrong starting your game off with a battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time to prep magic item rewards before the game. Give them to the enemies to use against the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Interesting details in narrative are great, but always try to give players an opportunity to act and make a choice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It is perfectly acceptable for the masked lords of Waterdeep to leave the fate of the city to the choices of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players the option to get involved in political struggles or not. Don't force them to make a choice if they don't care.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run NPC vs. NPC battles as background scenery or quick single d20 rolls. Don't play them out like regular combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Allow for unexpected outcomes in combat. Don't force "all victory" or "all defeat" as the only options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Waves of enemies can be cool but there should be a limit to them. Mercenaries are expensive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid battles with more than twelve enemies. Use swarms instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a shared hit point pool like 13th Age's mooks when running lots of creatures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if you end a battle early, do it behind thes screen. Don't kill the victory by stating "I'm going to call it here".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the opportunity to create really fantastic environments when running "theater of the mind" narrative combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the pace of the game starts to slow, move the story forward quickly. Don't force a battle to the end.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always include areas in your narrative to give the PCs choices and let them take actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't give a job to an NPC that can be given to a PC instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't put a single monster up against a party unless you want it to die a swift and anticlimactic death.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare for PCs to target the odd person out in a fight. That single mage is tasty!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give each NPC an interesting physical trait, unique weapons, or other mannerisms even if they share the same stat block.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change up weapons and their respective die-types to easily customize NPC enemies.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a break in your game every 90 minutes to two hours so everyone comes back recharged and ready to play.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A well balanced #dnd 5e battle takes about 45 minutes. Manage your time accordingly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a scene seems to start dragging, move on! You are in full control of the pace of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End dragging battles early by reducing remaining hit points to 1, lowering DCs, or having enemies explode.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be like @SFVDnDAL and stand when you run your games. It keeps everyone's energy up, including your own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use your experiences in the games you play in, both positive and negative, to learn how to be a better DM yourself.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in some detailed set-piece battles into your game along with narrative combat for big climactic fights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The dry-erase flip-mat is useful for just about any RPG. It's a big white board you can set down in front of all the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give unique characteristics to each monster so people can say "I hit the one with the tattoo of an octopus on his face".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend the time to pick out interesting treasure before the game begins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As long as they don't abuse it, adjudicate in favor of a PC's awesome actions rather than saying "no".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Doomvault from Dead in Thay makes for an awesome drop-in megadungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did a PC kill a legendary foe? Perhaps their weapon absorbed part of the foe and became something new and powerful!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Many villains, deep down, think they are doing good. What good does your villain think they're doing?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need some good random D&D 5e tables? Check out the Donjon!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know the motivations of your enemies and, if appropriate, their motivations to flip sides and work for the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let combat flow into the rest of the story if your enemies get caught in save-or-suck effects. Don't just negate it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reward PCs with the plans and components to build interesting magical weapons or armor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never expect a single monster to last very long. Give bosses powerful bodyguards.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use narrative combat to keep the story smooth from scene to scene, blending into exploration and NPC interaction
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How many targets should an area hit in narrative combat? Somewhere between 2 and 4 depending on the circumstances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What five clues might your PCs learn in your next game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to read the full Dungeon Master's Guide. There are tons of great ideas you might otherwise miss.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider carefully whether you should fudge rolls to fuel a fantastic story or let the dice fall where they will and steal thunder
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Balance the seeds for exploration, roleplaying, and combat in each adventure you prepare.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you feel unprepared for your next game but dive in anyway, you might well be on the path of the Lazy Dungeon Master.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare to give PCs the revenge they deserve against a hated foe. Maybe they live after 0 hp and the PC gets to choose their fate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Solutions often come at a cost. What will the PCs give up to un-petrify the victim of a medusa?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave enough blanks in your adventure for players to fill with interesting comments, motivations, or backgrounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use interesting props, dungeon tiles, or 3d terrain to build Chris Perkins style battle arenas once in a while.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you build an interesting battle area, start the PCs there but give them freedom to use it how they will.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll randomly for interesting loot and improvise its origin and background story. Where did that +3 battle-axe come from?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw your players into the story by asking them about the interesting physical characteristics of the enemies they fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are your players considering bailing out on their current quest? Let them. Don't force them to stay the course.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't know a detail about an NPC or location? Ask your players to fill it in for you!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking to draw out fantasy maps? Check out this site for some great tutorials!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build stories off of interesting random results from things like magic item tables or weird dungeon rooms.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players what the name of their new magic item is. Let them come up with silly ones until a good one comes out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Attacking the PCs with a big pile of low-level monsters? Pool their hit points into a big pool 13th Age style.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build environments with lots of variables instead of scenes with clear paths and solutions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For some variety, give magic items a once-per-day casting of a spell relevant to the item's origin.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In every dungeon there are always three hidden levels for each level discovered.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll for magic items when you prepare for your game so you know what weapons your villains possess.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to throw a side adventure into your long campaign. Not everything needs to be tied to the big plot.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There is tons of room in #dnd to ask the players world-building questions and use the results in your game. Keep an open mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stick to a single big boss fight in single session. Don't try to pack in more than one or it just overwhelms everyone.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every so often it's fun to build out a @ChrisPerkinsDnD style Acq. Inc. big set piece arrangement. Build UP!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try breaking your reliance on gridded combat with an off-the wall battle that simply can't be mapped out in 5 foot squares.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Differences in height can make battles really interesting. Flying foes, high ledges, massive waterfalls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Revel and celebrate when PCs instantly kill or incapacitate a powerful foe. "You feebleminded the wizard! Awesome!"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: PCs needing to spend their money? Maybe a shady dealer has access to 5 random magic uncommon magic items!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to make Out of the Abyss a little easier in the beginning? Start PCs at level 3 instead of level 1.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need some good random D&D 5e tables? Check out the Donjon!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to read over a monster stat block in full before you start running it at the table. Some things are easy to miss.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What fantastic feature exists in each of your scene locations?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Exotic tattoos, weapons, and armor are great ways to tie NPCs to the story or seed all new ones!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good scenes focus on exploration, interaction, or combat. Great scenes include all three!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to expensive spell components. Some spells aren't as easily cast as others.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A small random assortment of expensive magic items from a shady dealer is a good way to shed PCs from their barrels of gold.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let PCs get decide if they want to get involved in far-reaching decisions of politics and war.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to negate the PC's awesomely powerful defense. Revel in their power and find a new way to threaten them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a to-do list of things you really want to insert into your campaign at some point. Review each time you prep your session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to write a 3x5 card for each scene's location with its most interesting and fantastic feature.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use war as a huge backdrop for the story with the actions of the PCs steering the larger course.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie powerful concentration spells to physical objects for an interesting twist in a battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even for combat-heavy sessions, try to put in interesting facts or secrets that the PCs can learn.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even legendary monsters likely have a couple of minions around to cause problems for unattended PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A great battle provides a difficult challenge that leads to a monumental victory.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Party having too easy a time with a green dragon? Throw a Storm of Vengeance over the area that only stops on the dragon's death.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Improvised monsters only need ACs, hit points, an attack score, some damage, and a unique attack.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Foreshadow upcoming bad guys by giving PCs a glimpse of secret covens or stories of their horrible deeds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A picture is worth a thousand words. Use your cell phone to show pictures of the monsters the PCs encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful using the spell "blink" to protect your wizards. It's powerful but can end up just frustrating players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Too many protections on your Big Bad Evil Guys (BBEGs) can seem more of a slog than a fun fight. It's hard to balance.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Attacking the PCs with a big pile of low-level monsters? Pool their hit points into a big pool 13th Age style.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always consider how you can make the abilities of the PCs shine in combat, exploration, and interaction. THEY are your heroes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's always better to end a game early than end a game late. If time is short, call it there and prep for the next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Adding more monsters is always a way to make a battle more challenging and is often more effective than using bigger ones.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good ideas come from everywhere. Keep your senses open or you'll miss them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Look for interesting people and places throughout your daily lives. Fill your improvisation bucket.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mixing two or three ideas together can often make something new and interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The easiest way to increase the challenge of a 5e battle is to add more monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't build monsters to thwart the abilities of the PCs. Let battles flow naturally.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scale is an easy way to make an area fantastic. Mile-high waterfalls, hundred-story pyramids, mountainous cyclopean statues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the campaign worksheet to keep a focus on the PCs and how they're bending the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't go overboard with sub-systems or strange new rules. Stick to the main mechanics that the players are used to.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your final campaign battles straight forward. Too many twists and turns can ruin an expected climax.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fun should always trump realism when building encounters, spells, traps, characters, or monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Near the end of your campaign, let players tell you what THEY found in the treasure hoard instead of you telling them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid the "blink" spell for NPCs and monsters. It just ends up being a pain in the ass instead of an interesting challenge.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to circumvent the ability of the PCs. Let them enjoy their asymmetric advantages and overpowered abilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The asymmetry of 5e's design is what fuels interesting stories. Don't houserule around it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't counteract the PCs success in avoiding what you thought was going to be a big battle. Go with the flow of the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared with interesting story hooks, interesting NPCs, and fantastic locations in case you start to run out of material.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put in lots of opportunities for your PCs to act in your piles of narrative. PCs don't want to be passive observers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The number one rule to good dungeon mastering? Relax and have fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Legendary actions and legendary resistances are an easy template to drop on potential boss monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use random rolls to determine targets and remove your bias to punish the munchkins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Aim for the sweet spot of five PCs for your game. The game is optimal for four but you can usually get away with six.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid designing your own monsters and instead focus on reskinning existing monsters in the Monster Manual.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The looser you plan your game, the less you care when players go off the rails or bypass battles you expected them to fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "Your lives end here" is about the weakest thing a boss monster can say. "I murdered your sister" gets more attention.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Most game sessions can come down to five interesting scenes. Jot them down on a 3x5 card and you're all set.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal and reskin your favorite rooms and chambers from classic adventures to build fantastic locations on the fly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't fight against the PC's "save or suck" effects. Revel in their joy of the victory!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bloodborne's soundtrack (along with its amazing atmosphere) makes for great D&D background music.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never expect a single creature to survive if the PCs want to kill it. Instead, expect the threat to come from a group of foes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hit points are a gauge you can turn up or down. The listed amount is the average, not set in stone.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want that Tiamat mini to look really big? Make every square a 10 foot square instead of 5!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the winter holiday in your campaign? Perhaps it is Deadwinter Day?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about giving out too many magic items. Attunement is a built in limitation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End every campaign with a "three years later" montage driven by the players. Let go and enjoy how their campaign ends.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There's nothing like a nice walk sans-cellphone to ponder ideas for your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your primary plot motivations relatively simple but wrap it in all sorts of juicy complications.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Deep histories can be revealed through small tweet-sized clues left all throughout a dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Changing the elemental flavor of a monster is a great way to make it feel different with very little effort.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "What is its name?" is a great way to help a player bond to the story of a new magical weapon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What sort of hopes and dreams do your notable NPCs have for the new year?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes threef big chambers tied through with a single hallway is all the dungeon you need.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes its fun to leave major plot elements open but always good to have something ready as a backup.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep good notes when your players give you backstories of your characters. They're full of great story seeds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Asking world-building open-ended questions to your players can be great. Too open and your players will be simply lost.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful putting players on the spot with open story building questions. Sometimes they don't want to make stuff up on the spot.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Narrative combat can be fine but many times players are more engaged when they have a pretty map and some minis to look at.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start off your new campaign with some character building and maybe a short battle to get folks into it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every adventure is yours to twist and morph for the fun of you and your group. Never feel you must run it as written.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: when asking players for improvised stories, let them jump in rather than you call them out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't give your group megadungon access if you don't expect them to start exploring it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your group starts exploring random rooms in a random dungeon, what story seeds can you plant that gives it some backbone?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared for your players to hate your quest giving NPC. Find a new way for the PCs to get involved...or not!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you have the opportunity, try running games at your local gaming store instead of just at home. Great exp and new friends!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 13th Age style player-driven montages are a great way to enjoy long scenes of travel.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all player-driven improvisation works well but when it does, it's pure gold. Say yes!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Cool names add a lot of depth to otherwise faceless enemies. Captain Belmont Graycleaver is better than "leader of the orc mercs".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Blank dry-erase maps with interesting textures is a great way to balance flexibility with detail.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if you love narrative combat, some minis on the table can draw in the attention of your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of NPCs and monsters as piles of clay to be molded into interesting beings by the themes, backgrounds, and drives of the PCs
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A tip from @13thAge: ask players what elements of the game they'd like to see come back in the future.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep track of the number of magic items PCs have so you know which one could use some magic item love.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use out-of-character scenes to give players a wider view of the big goings ons in the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you have one course that is clearly more fun, don't put in an artificial choice. Add more choices elsewhere.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Building a Fantastic Location: What was your fantastic location originally? What happened to it? What is it used for now?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe profound hits, misses, and even close calls in narrative: "Her blade cuts deep into your left flank!"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can begin your journey of PC-focused gameplay by taking the time to memorize the PCs' names.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In any tough fight, always consider how the PCs will fail forward if they happen to get TPKed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remind players to let you know when they feel like another player deserves inspiration for a cool deed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down three interesting things about any given location the PCs are likely to see.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add seasons into your game to keep the feeling of life strong in the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep track of the number of magic items the PCs have so you know what to reward next and to whom.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Cool magic items are flavored with rich history and their own origin stories that return throughout a PC's career.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When reskinning a monster stat block into a new monster, try not to give away the fact that you're reskinning or what from.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the 13th Age style icon rolls to see which PC's background and alignments might come into play in that session's game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down ten tweet-sized secrets the PCs might discover in your next adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you give your players the opportunity to explore, don't be surprised when they go way off the edge of the map.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What's a great way to prepare for your games? Absorb a shit-ton of awesome fiction. SF, fantasy, books, movies, TV, games, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your section off with a bang. Earthquakes, demon lords, castles exploding, crashing airships, whatever.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give vital information to the character with the highest skill roll. That way they get it and get a spotlight at the same time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Love it or hate it, players love loot. Give at least one exciting piece of loot away each session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow @sageadvicednd to watch the latest rulings and tips from the D&D designer's themselves.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe problems and enjoy creative solutions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A interesting map needs to be little more than some squares connected by some lines.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "Bends" damage is totally appropriate if your PCs quickly swim 100 feet up in the ocean. No, they're not resistance to the bends.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good player-driven travel montages can be as memorable as any other scene in your game. Embrace them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every feature in your game is a lump of clay forming into a detailed person, place, or thing as the eyes of your PCs behold it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "Describe your killing blow!" is a great way to push players into the creative realm during combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful using "describe your killing blow!" with kids or you're going to hear "I SHOOT HIM IN HIS EYEBALL!!"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Can one dwarf use another dwarf as a bludgeoning weapon? Sure! Dwarves might even be proficient. Consider it a two-handed maul.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid boring locations. What makes your location fantastic? Is it enormous? Made of something strange? Does it fly? Is it alive?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't always have to kill table humor to keep your game going straight. Table banter is much of the fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Encounters with an non-stop stream of bad guys can build an interesting sense of urgency that a normal encounter can't.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can build interesting encounter areas and then fill them up with different types of monsters depending on how your game goes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did the wizard's fireball just kill every bad guy in the room? Don't despair, enjoy the victory!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Quality props, maps, and handouts are worth their weight in gold at the table. Physical props even more so.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: PCs from previous games can become interesting NPCs or even background flavor for current games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not really enjoying part of that published adventure you're running? Throw it out and build something you'll love!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fail forward on failed skill checks. How does a failed skill check escalate the tension?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: @roll20app isn't just for overhead maps. Drop notes, pictures, and other game aids into a campaign desktop page.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Aim for a group size of 4 to 5. It's the perfect blend of screen time per PC and a great group of creative minds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Face icons in @roll20app can help everyone identify with each of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend a few minutes before each session refreshing your notes and putting it all back into your mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take every opportunity to shine the spotlight on a PC and their abilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What secrets will be revealed in your next session and how might the PCs discover them?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to read over the published material you plan to run. Even if you don't run it as is, it's great inspiration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clues, PC-focused quests, treasure, NPC actions, and interesting locations are great things to prepare for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe a combat location and ask your players to draw it out. You get to decide where the combatants start!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Rolling in the open makes things exciting for everyone.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: One to two types of monsters is about all you need in a normal fight. Great big set-piece battles might have three.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A trap for trap's sake isn't very interesting. What does the trap tell the PCs about the location or its creators?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did you build out a cool battle arena with 3d stuff and all that jazz? Get the most out of it with multiple waves of monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force a trap's effect on the same PC twice without good reason.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to re-read around the current location in a published adventure in case your PCs take an unexpected turn.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sandwich your looser improvised stuff with solid locations and well orchestrated encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Email some 250 word flash fiction to give your players a wider view of your antagonist's actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Separate fantastic locations from the monsters who may inhabit them to keep your world both solid and dynamic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try different RPGs and steal the best parts for your own game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When trying a new RPG, try to understand the intent of the rules-as-written before you start changing things up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of useful magic items for each PC you can draw from when an opportunity for treasure comes by.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Convert NPCs in published adventures into those meaningful to the PCs. Fathers, brothers, war buddies, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Along with a strong start, have an idea how the end of your next session will hook into the session after that.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't have to reskin every monster. Many times players are very happy to fight normal by-the-book monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all players want to join your table-side improv class. Some just want to throw dice, kill monsters, and have a few laughs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep descriptions brief and focus on the most important parts. Add extra flavor as scenes continue to move forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want a bit more Cthulhu / Darkest Dungeon in your D&D game? Stick in the madness rules on page 259 of the DMG.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Apocalypse World style threats are one way to keep track of the main baddies in your D&D campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Great tip from Apocalypse World / Dungeon World: Play to find out what happens, don't presume or force a single direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus your attention on the world, the people, and the places that your PCs can lay eyes and hands on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What fantastic location do the PCs head towards? What makes it so? What eight interesting places does it contain?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For every room, chamber, or focused location the PCs find themselves in, what are the three notable features that matter to them?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to inflict trap, obstacle, or angry DM damage? Use 7 * the challenge's CR for one target or 7 * 1/2 CR for multiple targets.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take note of the quiet players and ensure you can find ways to draw their characters into the game. They're easy to forget.
author: Michael E. Shea
