text: #dnd tip: A number of portals or rifts are a great way to throw a bunch of bad guys at the PCs in a strange battlefield configuration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End a session before a big fight and you can spend time planning out a nice fun encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random Spell Scroll (roll 2d4): 2. Bard; 3. Sorcerer; 4. Wizard; 5. Cleric; 6. Wizard; 7. Warlock; 8. Druid
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in set-piece battles, theater-of-the-mind skirmishes, exploration, and roleplaying to give players a wide range of experiences
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always look for a way to hook an NPC, plot, or story element back to a PC's background to draw them tighter to the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of vomiting forth narrative, try tying discoveries to the skills and backgrounds of the PCs. Let THEM discover it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have some fun with your players describing the previous ages of the world: the Age of the Old Ones, Age of Discovery, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want your player to put down the cellphone? Ask them an interesting question and listen to the answer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Battles with multiple waves are great ways to create a really epic battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players love it when their idea shatters the rules in unexpected ways. Say yes!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Designate a player as an arcane archivist to help look up spells when someone has a question.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Designate a curio curator to look up magic items in the dungeon master's guide when they come into play.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't sweat the details of the rules. Choose a rules lawyer to arbitrate and focus attention on the fun parts of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ware the player who takes advantage of your "say yes" style by getting away with murder. Let the group arbitrate their bullshit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Maybe not all the bad guys are willing to throw themselves onto the PCs blade. Maybe they're double agents!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choosing some interesting treasure is a worthy way to prep your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to impress your players with a cool battle environment? Build it high!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan puzzles carefully. They're not something easy to improvise right at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of fun and interesting characters from your favorite books, movies, or TV shows to use as NPC archetypes in your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Two big monsters is a good way to have a powerful, explosive fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Rory's Story Cubes are a great way to fuel @13thAge style scene montages. Let them roll some dice and tell you what happened.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Here's a quick DM alignment check. How do you feel when a player rolls a critical hit? Do you love it or fear it?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start game prep by looking at the backgrounds and motivations of the PCs for interesting hooks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not everyone will get into your crazy math puzzle. Make it quick so you don't alienate those who aren't into it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in word puzzles and riddles into your more mathematical cypher-type puzzles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When playing a public game, keep your game accessible to those with disabilities. How will it run for someone vision impaired?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use rich narrative when running combat in the "Theater of the Mind" to engage players in the action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Who are the three main threats in your campaign? What are they doing right now?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Triggering skill checks is a good way to ensure the narrative is relevant to the PCs. What do they discover?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down ideas and study the stat blocks for monsters you're likely to run in your next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the explosive headline for the first scene in your next adventure? Thanks @monkeyking!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: At the end of your campaign, ask your players to describe their favorite moments and keep them in mind for your next one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before ending your campaign, write down the main character threads that should be resolved before it ends.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ending a game right at the beginning of a big battle will start your next game off with a bang!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make sure to keep the energy high and be patient in explaining the scene when running narrative "theater of the mind" combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every monster, even packs of wolves, might have interesting names or characteristics. Ask your players to define them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Villainous wolves: Redpaw, Gleamfang, Scar, Cloudeye, the Sisters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did your PCs just discover a scroll? Use this table to determine what it is!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random Spell Scroll (roll 2d4): 2. Bard; 3. Sorcerer; 4. Wizard; 5. Cleric; 6. Wizard; 7. Warlock; 8. Druid
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need to come up with a strange but flat die roll? Use one die minus 1 for the 10s and one die for the 1s. 1d4-1 + 1d10 for 1 to 39
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus your narrative on the theme of the adventure. Go fantastic with high adventure and dark with your Ravenloft stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Wrap counterspell in some colorful narrative to make it not such a fun-sucker. See the Harry Potter spell duels.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Madness rules are a rough but powerful set of mechanics to add some Cthulhu into your D&D.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need a quick boss? Double hit points and add an extra standard action of any monster.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus location descriptions on the most important, useful, and fantastic elements of the location.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Dungeon World style "hard moves" and "soft moves" to fail forward on poor skill check results.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Advantage and disadvantage are your core ways to reward good ideas or great skill checks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep some simple mechanics on hand to reward great skill checks or fantastic player ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The core of our game is telling stories with our friends. Don't let anything get in the way of that.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running narrative combat, be descriptive and high energy. Don't spout numbers, spout action!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be brief with room-by-room explorations. Focus on the important clues. Don't let it become a slog.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Going around the table and switching directions is a good way to ensure every player gets deserved screen-time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Cheap tricks work well for horror games. Gross descriptions, false visions, creepy descriptions; etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Beef up the vampire by giving it 21 (6d6) necrotic on its slam attack and increasing the necrotic dam of bite to 21 (6d6).
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be aware of people's limits when it comes to graphic depictions of bloodshed. Use an X card.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: An oldie from Dungeon World: Address the character, not the player.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reward players for being willing to move the story forward at the sacrifice of their character's safety.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Quick sketches of rooms and doors help even if you're running mostly theater-of-the-mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There's no such thing as a generic monster. All of them have interesting characteristics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pictures, maps, and handouts are fantastic ways to draw your players into your game beyond just words.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the smells, tastes, and senses of touch to make an area come alive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a published battle call for a single monster but you have more than one extra PC, add a smaller minion for each extra PC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of the PCs in front of you all the time so you can call out by character name.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let published adventures inspire your own stories. Don't be a slave to the written word.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What cults are operating in your campaign? What are their goals? Who leads them? What do they think of the PCs?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Action is the name of the game. What can your PCs do in any given scene? What options do they have available?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Check youtube to practice interesting accents for NPCs in your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The dread and depression of Barovia might be too strong for a whole campaign. Add some levity and moments of joy from time to time
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep a dungeon on hand if a small town gets too boring. Forgotten cellars, old crypts, ruined towers, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give a stat block of combatant NPCs to the player with the simplest PC build to let them run it during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Using 3d terrain? Encourage PCs climbing them with skill checks and gaining advantage for high ground.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't let the mechanics get in the way of a fantastic scene. Use the mechanics to guide the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up gridded, big set-piece battles, and theater of the mind combat to make the most of all of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to learn the names of the PCs. Can you name them all right now?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid pitting the PCs against foes they're not supposed to beat. Combat is as much of an option as careful negotiations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down random names you use during the game. Those NPCs are sure to come back.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to underline or highlight important notes in your adventures. These books are meant to be used!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put a large acrylic sheet on your table with the awesome Curse of Strahd map underneath for both atmosphere and utility.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In 5e, hit points are the average of a range determined by hit dice. Don't worry about increasing or decreasing them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: No matter how lazy, spend time outlining a strong introduction, a few cool scenes, and review your PC names and backgrounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always be careful asking a child to "describe their killing blow". Their responses will give you nightmares.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Google image search and deviant art are great places to farm for images to show in your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Video game music makes for a great background soundtrack. Assassin's Creed, Witcher 3, and Skyrim. What are your favorites?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How little material can you get away with and still run a fantastic game? What can you add that makes it significantly better?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What evocative details can you describe that supports the theme of your scene, adventure, and campaign?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't punish the PCs too much if they split the party. Multiple separate scenes can be cool if juggled well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Kaizen foam with Dungeon tiles can make some really cool 3d elevation for your battle maps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When a character faces a fear, such as a phantasmal killer, ask the player to describe the fearful images their PCs see.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hag covens are a great example of splitting up a "boss" into three separate monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Litter the land with landmarks of corruption. Ancient sacrificial stones, idols to forgotten gods, unholy circles of ages past.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Who are your main villain's top three lieutenants? What makes them unique and interesting?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Skills are the PCs' primary interface to the world. Think about how they hook into the world and scenes you create.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the names of random NPCs. You never know when they're going to come back again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Design relevant terrain for random battles. What interesting statues, old ruins, or arcane circles will they see?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give each PC something to do in every session. Note their strengths before you plan the whole session out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Wrap your ruses, tricks, and subterfuge in two layers. Players will easily discover the first, but maybe not the second.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of each scene as its own sandbox with many ways the PCs can act and interact within it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build teeter-totter environmental effects that start out rough on the PCs but, with skill checks, can swing it the other way.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Doing less prep doesn't mean doing NO prep. There are a FEW things we should prepare for our next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When players talk, really listen to them and use what they say to make the adventure awesome.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time in the minds of your NPCs before your next game. How will their motivations intersect with the PCs?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes off-the-cuff joke comments can lead to really interesting in-game situations. Omit nothing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mash up the vampire spawn stat block and the stat blocks of NPCs to make a wide range of horrific vampiric NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The Barovia map in Curse of Strahd is betting to sit under an acrylic sheet on your gaming table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If things are feeling directionless, it might be a good time to work out, with the players, what the current open quests are.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid situations that cut off characters from their powers. Seek situations that showcase them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use ungridded sketches to help people understand a situation without resorting to five foot square bickering.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Almost any mechanical problem can be improved with in-story narrative. Overpowered mechanics turn into fantastic scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never forget that the game is about having fun. Smile, laugh, don't take things so seriously.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seek out and latch onto hooks that players reveal. Did they give their sword a name and origin? Work it in!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Do everything in your power to make new players feel welcome. Spend little time going over rules and just let them dive in.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend more time listening and less time talking. Give players the parts they need and then let them expand it with their actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if you use narrative combat without a grid, some miniatures can help people understand where they are relatively.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players for the kind of items they want rather than a specific wishlist. Choose within those categories.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Vampires make great reoccurring villains. Even if they die, they just reform in their coffins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw players into the story with easy questions like "how do they die?" and "what do they look like?"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If players are frustrated by a vampire's regen, give them a clue or a check to learn the vulnerabilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If NPCs get involved in combat, give their stat block to a player and let them run the NPC on their initiative.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a gridded battle map for hard battles where players need to micromanage their characters in order to survive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to refresh yourself on the material you plan to run in your next session. It's easy to forget stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Vary the difficulty of encounters. Not everything needs to be a life-or-death event.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use weather as an interesting way to add flavor to your next scene or adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a 13th Age style hotpoint pool if you're running more than six of a single type of monster.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on two or three NPCs in any one scene. Any more and you and your players will lose track.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep in mind the threads that bind scenes and locations together as you run each adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use @schley's maps on a tablet when running Curse of Strahd.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin the stat blocks for giants for powerful warlords and champion barbarian NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Over the years, how have you gotten better as a GM? How do you hope to be better in years to come
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ancient destructible monuments are a great way to boost monster damage with extra fire, cold, force, or necrotic damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spill secrets, clues, and lore through the mouths of monsters and villains during combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let PCs interrupt big rituals. Have a plan whether they disrupt it or not with both results leading to cool exciting stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use magic items to share history, lore, and background of the campaign. Did that +2 sword once belong to Strahd's brother Sergei?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Using a big detailed 3d battle terrain setup doesn't mean you have to fall to the tyranny of counting 5 foot squares.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Interesting locations have layers and layers of discoverable history going back for eons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Flashbacks, visions, and dreams are great ways to give PCs a wide view of the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: PCs having an easy time with zombies or scarecrows? Fill them with swarms of wasps that flood out on slashing or piercing attacks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good scenes have interesting weather, historical features, stressful situations, layers of history, and clear value to the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What scene do you have in your next game that focuses on or showcases one of the PCs?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the details of NPCs, whether friend or foe. Use the opportunity for some "yes, and" improv.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your group and your players be who they are. Don't try to force your group to be something it isn't.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every magic item has a story to tell.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Call for actions around the table, even outside of combat, and switch directions to ensure everyone gets the spotlight sometime.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spellcasting isn't just for combat. How are NPC spellcasters harassing your party from afar?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't shy away from PC death but ensure it doesn't ruin the fun of the game for the player. How can they get back in?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's ok to step in and offer a recommended path (or paths) if it leads to a more entertaining game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep an interesting encounter with solid story ties in your back pocket for potential dead spaces in your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Layer scenes with fantastic locations, deep characters, discoverable secrets, and interesting story hooks
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A single battle with waves of enemies and good story ties can be the centerpiece of a single adventure. Think Helm's Deep.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you're game is running a little short, don't ram in a combat encounter. It might just fatigue people.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: After your game, jot down some notes on what worked well and what could be improved. Post them to twitter as #dnd tips!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Beginning with a battle or ending with a battle is a great way to start strong at the following game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a loose outline of the directions and hooks your campaign might go but be prepared to throw them out the window.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Intelligent weapons are fantastic ever-present NPCs who can give quests and relay important facts to the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: This one is for players. Take notes during your game to stay focused on what's happening and help you avoid cellphone surfing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seriously, write down those NPC names. They're easy to forget and it breaks immersion when you stumble to find it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Villains spouting narrative is a great way to keep the story moving while combat is going on. James Bond villains are just fine.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The core of D&D is having fun exploring dungeons and fighting monsters. Hang on to that.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you want to see how a game can come alive, watch @matthewmercer run Force Gray.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Overwhelming forces of monsters is ok but don't build expecting a surrender. Prepare for all outcomes. Don't be a jerk.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary of NPCs who travel with the group. Don't let them overshadow the actions of the PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End battles early by killing monsters on the next hit or have them dissipate when villains fall. No "let's end the battle here".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up battlespaces from big elaborate 3d terrain sets to "theater of the mind" narrative combat. Experiment!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your game preparation by writing down the names, backgrounds, and motivations of your PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The more we talk about #dnd in public, the more likely we are to find new players for our games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run one-shot games with new players to see if they would be a good fit for your regular games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What interesting magic items will you reward in your next session?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Interesting scenes could lead towards interaction, exploration, or combat. Let the PCs choose the course!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Swap out the monsters in published adventures for monsters you're excited to run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Super simple encounter building. Choose one monster per PC with a challenge equal to 1/3 of the PC's level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about getting voices and accents right. Put yourself into the mind of the character and become them for a short bit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Emailed flash fiction is a great way to keep the game going between sessions. Outline the big points you want to get across.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Step outside the narrative of the PCs and foreshadow villains the PCs have yet to face.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use puzzles, riddles, and quests to unlock new powers in magical weapons the PCs love.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Replace cash with expensive gems, jewelry, and artwork if the raw coins don't make sense.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use 13th Age style montages to offload interesting travel stories to your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be mindful of the time you spend, and the players' body language, when describing history, plot, or background.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't expect anyone has the time to read that great piece of flash fiction you wrote. You have no right to anyone's time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build traps and obstacles logically and let players come up with interesting ways to get past them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Care not for any monster. For when you do, it shall then be polymorphed into a canary. Love the canary instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't circumvent the wand of web. Embrace its creative use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow the wise words of @dmdavidblog and highlight the leads in your published adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Abstract your big set-piece locations from your story and plot so you can use them in many potential situations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players should enjoy their save-or-suck spells but don't let them get away with it all the time. Villains are smart.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ioun stones of greater absorption are powerful weapons of powerful villains and not game-breaking in the hands of PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add legendary actions and legendary resistance to any normal monster to make it a powerful "named" boss version of that monster.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't forget about the lair actions of legendary foes. They're easy to forget.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your game prep notes brief so you can quickly review them before and during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Using monsters with increasingly higher challenge ratings is the easiest way to challenge powerful parties.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot magic item bonuses for bosses down on a sticky note and stick them on the monster stat block page you plan to use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you're running a deadly encounter, have a fail forward for the TPK ready to go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want some monsters the PCs really don't expect or understand? Grab the Tome of Beasts by @KoboldPress!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What dark power seeks out that powerful weapon your rogue just picked up?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every set-piece battle map actually has to be a battle. Let the players know they have choices other than combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dungeons don't need to be huge labyrinths. Focus on the fun chambers even if its only two or three.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Protect elite villains with shield-guardian-like bodyguards that absorb half the damage intended for the villain.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a skilled set of players with some powerful characters? Don't be afraid to go way above the standard encounter challenge.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Save hard fights for the ones that are really important. Be liberal with a big bunch of easy fights that showcase the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every player will love your crazy interwoven drama. Some just want to explore ruins and fight bad guys.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Thinking through the eyes of your villain is fine until your villains become complete assholes. Keep them fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The hard choices aren't always as much fun as you think. Don't pile up too many hard decisions in a row.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's good to reconfirm the social contract of your game regularly. Is everyone getting what they want?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Flash fiction is a great way to play D&D away from the table but don't expect everyone loves your flash fiction as much as you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When your players remind you of a thread you lost track of, smile slyly, nod knowingly, and write that shit down.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes a straight fight with your adventurers isn't your villain's goal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How can a villain like Strahd convince the PCs to give him Ireena and leave Barovia without a blade being drawn?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There's a difference between a smart villain and a total pain-in-the-ass. Always aim towards fun first.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up a bunch of easy and normal fights with a few hard ones. Don't just punish the PCs all the time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running narrative "theater of the mind" combat means not worrying when the PCs short circuit it with something creative or crafty.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A handful of monsters with a CR of half the level of the PCs will be much harder than a single monster with CR equal to level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a challenging encounter, add one to two monsters per character above four in just about any battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll your d20 before worrying about looking up the DC or the modifier. A really low or high roll means it won't matter anyway.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The purpose of a boss fight is to bring a good challenge without removing the key abilities of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be ready to handle (or accept!) the heavy focus fire on your favorite monster with more than four PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Test your group before a boss fight by putting them up against a similar boss you don't care about.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Move the story away from tactical tabletop jargon with some high energy narration about the action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't try to circumvent the awesome random chances that aid the characters in their big fight. Revel in it!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fog cloud and darkness are great ways to clear the field from lots of advantage or disadvantage circumstances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you run a long series of encounters without a long rest, go easy on the difficulty of those encounters or it becomes less fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go heavy on wild narrative when running narrative "theater of the mind" combat. Describe what happens.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use individual random magic item tables when you want a nice single magic item as a reward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: While we heal and find a path ahead, we can find support among friends and family playing the game that we love.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll random magic items before your game and keep rolling until you get something you know the players will love.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know your characters so you know what will make them shine and what will push them to the edge.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remove the troublesome vampire charm with a flavorful, powerful, but not jerky beguiling gaze.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give characters an opportunity to acquire a map of Castle Ravenloft and save yourself hours of description.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every monster needs to be dropped to zero hit points. Dispel magic on a lich's phylactery is enough if the story is cool.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random targets help avoid DM bias. Roll for monster targets when it makes sense.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Awesome circumstances beats out rules of written every day of the week. Don't let the story suffer for the rules.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Villains aren't aways afraid to die to the characters. Some know they serve a greater purpose in death.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Increase boss hit points and damage by 25% for each character above four in a boss fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Call for skill checks when a player misses what a character might notice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From @dungeonbastard , boss battles are much harder after characters have drained resources on many smaller fights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lower monster hit points during a fight if the battle's beginning to feel stale.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll dice before looking up modifiers or saving throws in a book. If it's really high or low, it won't matter what the mod is.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take it easy on your first session. Let you and your players get to know the characters and share some stories.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend the first few prep sessions of your campaign focusing in on the PCs and their backgrounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe every attack, spew forth the fantastic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep as much as you need to feel comfortable, and no more.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep three to five open story threads going at any given time. Refresh to suit the desires of you and the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Re-read the next chapter of your published adventure before the session even if you've read it before to keep it in memory.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players the flexibility to let their characters' backgrounds grow as they play. Don't force a rich background all at once.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give characters a reasonable appraisal of a difficult battle before they rush headlong into it. Let them make an informed choice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Encourage players to try interesting race and class combinations even if they're not optimal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players the freedom to change their characters class or builds if they're not having fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let humor spontaneously erupt from scenes as they unfold rather than try to plan it up front.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry too much about continuity when bringing new characters in or dealing with absent characters. Players rarely care.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give characters some defensive terrain like defending an old keep once in a while.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remind players (and yourself!) that not all battle maps need be for a battle. Maybe some strong conversation takes the day!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use your Forgotten Realms calendars to describe the months and seasons of the times.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You know who makes for a great model for the Zhentarim? The Sons of Anarchy!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Revel in the characters' use of the Save or Suck spell. Describe the muddy naked ogre surrounded by a Crown of Madness!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: All old castles and keeps have forgotten cellars and secret tunnels.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When players feel like they only have one way to go, give some skill checks to discover other options yet uncovered.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Besides the giants, who are the three factions working across interests with the characters in your Storm King's Thunder campaign?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your campaign world's month and holiday names handy. Context builds worlds. Here they are for the Forgotten Realms.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Quests need to matter to the characters. No one wants to travel 1,000 miles to deliver some news.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running a looser "theater of the mind" style adventure gives you the agility to react to player decisions instead of forcing them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared with the seeds for your next adventure before you start this one. Think two steps out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A single sheet of laminated paper can be a great portable whiteboard for small maps, hit point records, or diagrams of glyphs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seriously, write down those NPC names. On paper. You're going to forget in like 10 seconds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: No game this week? Practice some "lonely fun" gaming by taking an hour to read your favorite D&D sourcebook or adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a picture of your campaign worksheet with character names, backgrounds, plot hooks, and motivations. Review it when bored.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fear not inserting your own cool idea into a published adventure. Fear not cutting what bores you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Quests should have a strong motivation for the characters. Dump or refactor those that do not.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Missing read-aloud text in your published adventure? Jot down quick bullets you want to focus on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a few good small dungeon maps handy and use them when you think the characters have been wandering the overland too much.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players make decisions at the end of a session so you have a better idea what to prep for in the time in between.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie secrets, histories, and clues to the magic items the characters discover. They'll love the +2 bonus, you'll love the hook!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't fret about skipping parts of a published adventure that don't resonate with you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: After a game, write down some notes about what went really well and what you wish went better. Review them before your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even the smallest town has some fantastic characteristic that's sure to make it memorable.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down and remember the names of the characters' pets and familiars. They can matter as much as the characters themselves.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: No single quest or artifact acquisition should spell total success or total failure for a campaign...until the end.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep handy those tools that best help you run your game and eliminate those that do not.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the rule of three when describing a town. Three interesting locations, three important NPCs, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every interesting town has a strange dungeon laying beneath the surface. What is yours?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Which character has an old friend or relative living in the town they're visiting?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of asking "what do you do" when the characters enter a town, give them some options. Rest? Barhop? Investigate rumors?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What fantastic feature marks this town as different from any other?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good towns are all about the details. Name the bar, describe the atmosphere, give it detailed life.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the ancient history of this small town or hommlet? How does it reveal itself and why is it relevant?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Does this town or village have a powerful artifact they're willing to give to the characters for a price?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What rumors or secrets lurk in the town? What do the characters ovehear at the local tavern?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What mystery lurks in the shadows of the town? Which inkeeper is keeping the sacrificed corpse of her husband in the cellar?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What antagonist of the heroes lurks in the town? Are they covert or overt?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every band of orcs comes from a particular tribe. Define it and make it memorable.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the random name generator to come up with interesting tavern names that tell their own story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What event is going on when the characters come into town? Farm animals on the loose? A crazy parade for the goddess of tricks?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Short off-screen stories are a fun way to re-introduce a missing character. Ron Weasley hiding and fighting snatchers in HP.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Anton Chigurh from No Country for Old Men may be the best villain archetype ever. Use him as a perfect NPC assassin.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Show flashbacks with one-off battles set centuries ago rather than just tell players about it in narrative.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down a short list of the important parts you need to pass along when describing narrative histories.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Characters stumbling into a battle between two other foes is an interesting twist to the monster closet.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your dungeon designs flexible to add or remove rooms as fits the pacing of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hunt for great images across the web to use as show-ems during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay special attention to how long your descriptions or narrative is going. It can get boring very quickly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When describing past events, use a quick summary at the beginning, end, or both, to give players the gist.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even random encounters can expose secrets and clues important to the larger story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every battle needs to be a tactical masterpiece. Some can be funny. Gnolls trying to use ancient dwarven war machines.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even ancient traps can hold clues to the history of its makers and those who attempted to come before.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw maps on a 45 degree angle on your battle map to break people away from the grid.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use email or off-line discussions to cover intermissions between games. Don't expect or rely on a lot of engagement, though.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be nice at level 1 and increase your bastard ranking proportionally to the level of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start building your campaign world around the features that directly affect the characters and spiral out from there.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: At the start of your campaign, list the top six to ten themes so your players can get a feel for it before they build characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Simplify your DM kit by removing books or tools that don't serve to run a fantastic game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reinforce the growing informal connections characters build between one another as part of the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't punish poor strategic choices done for fun role-play purposes. Let them lead to a fun unpredictable scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: List the ten fantastic features that might come up in various locations in your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pre-roll some of your random charts ahead of time (encounters, NPC names, loot) so it doesn't make the game feel too random.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Survey your players with "what did you enjoy the most? What do you want more of?" at the end of each game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Widen the players' view of the world with cut-scenes and flash fiction. Maybe state ancient battles they can participate in.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of fantastic town features you can whip up when characters visit some place you're not prepared to fill out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of seven solid NPC names on hand. Random names at the table can have unexpected results.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even when running theater of the mind, a monster miniature on the table can keep players focused on the situation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fleeing from combat with the grand macguffin might be the best victory condition. Make sure players feel it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put in locations and let characters explore interesting places that aren't necessarily part of the main story thread.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin locations and dungeons you find in books and adventures to fit the intricate history of the world you're building.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let characters wander into existing conflicts between enemies. Fire giants versus gnolls!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix the features and stat blocks of two monsters in the Monster Manual to build hybrids. Stone giant wights!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use skill checks to let characters directly explore the world around them instead of just telling them everything all at once.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Which character's background are you going to directly tie to in the first scene of your next game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about filling in details you forgot (or just made up!) in an interesting scene. Your players will forgive you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill dungeons with artifacts that tell the history of the world in which the characters travel.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Rarely can a single creature take on more than four characters. Add minions for each character above 4.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill in details of dungeon rooms ahead of time enough to make them interesting but not so much that you mind discarding them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all ghost possessions need be malevolent. Some ghosts just want to hitch a ride.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Magic items can tell as much of a story as anything else, and they're likely one players will pay attention to.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the rules of combat before combat begins when using narrative or abstract combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Beholders are always likely to use flight as their biggest defense.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choosing different deities is a great way to make unique temple locations for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use narrative "theater of the mind" combat when running more than eight or so bad guys. A swarm of 36 stirges? Sure!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Connect characters to important NPCs in the story if your one-shot games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How can your villains stop the likely bloodshed in a negotiation with the characters?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Putting out a battle map is a clear sign that things are going to get violent. Save it until violence becomes a certainty.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskinning dragons is a great way to get a powerhouse boss monster of any flavor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your imagery brief and powerful. Stone giants impaled on fifty foot obsidian spikes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make magic items unique by adding a once-per-day spell effect to it based on the theme of the item.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The physical appearance of a magic item tells a lot of its story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What fantastic feature does the characters' campsite happen to have? Remember Weathertop!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared for turn undead to blast away half or more of any undead army you throw against the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: All powerful dragons have spells and magic items at their disposal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some spells work really well with legendary monsters: Shield, Divine Word, Misty Step, Spiritual Weapon, Counterspell, Smite.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The capabilities of your group matter more than any formula you might use for building encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes your group wants a real challenge and sometimes they want just some slaughterhouse fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take two monster stat blocks and mash them together for a unique challenge. Stone Giant Wights!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mark the words of @newbiedm. Focus on the local heroics of your low level characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not digging the way a published adventure handles a location? What if its taken over by your own big bad?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before prepping your game, jot down the names of the characters and their motivations as your initial seed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about your monsters getting banished, held, blinded, paralyzed, or slain. That's world-breaking fun for players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never fall in love with your villains. Your players will smell it and break your heart.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your game didn't go as well as you hoped, take a step back and do a post-mortem and think about why and what might improve.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some players don't enjoy being pushed to the edge of death all the time. Some just like to relax and kick ass.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes players are distracted by stressful things going on in their lives. Be patient with them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's fine to give players disconnected pieces of a puzzle but it can help them to know they don't have all the answers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: An "Elrond Council" sort of gathering of the important NPCs is a great way to rebaseline the goal of a campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down evidence and clues on 3x5 cards your players can hang onto.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep track of spontaneous NPC names, you never know who's going to become a star in the players' eyes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just as a sixth PC adds significantly to a battle, reducing to 4 PCs will reduce a lot of synergy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Help your players build.effective characters for the story you intend to tell. Pacifist enchanters? Not so good against the undead
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe and outline interesting features in each scene the characters encounter. What makes it fantastic?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Outline interesting locations the characters will encounter as they travel long distances. Ancient skeletal remains, giant statues
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Break up descriptive scenes by giving players a chance to jump in with their actions, reactions, or skill checks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every magic item has a story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: At the beginning of each character's turn, give them a quick summary of their current situation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use descriptions from the Monster Manual and Volo's Guide to seed your mind with adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From @StvWinter Steeping yourself into a campaign world makes running sandbox adventures much easier.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use sketches of locations when theater of the mind combat doesn't give people a good idea what the hell is going on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review all of your clues and secrets right before you run your game so you're clear on the evidence the characters can discover.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down names for potentially named bandits or humanoid enemies before the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Replace NPCs in your published adventure with NPCs important to the characters and their backgrounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When the characters tend to wander around town, clarify their options or have something crazy happen. DMG page 79!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build interesting features of a location based on the backgrounds of characters. Ancient drow ethereal portal of Maeramydra!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add spell effects to fantastic locations that characters can tap into with a skill check. Ethereal orbs that grant "blink".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Differentiate between "quests" and "clues". Quests are clear paths they might follow. Clues are pieces of a puzzle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't push too hard to get feedback. "What did you enjoy and what do you want more of?" is fine and often no answer is ok.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't pile a bunch of high damage monsters on the characters one after another. Mix up hard fights with easy ones.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be mindful of the impact an NPC who travels with the party will have.  Will it overshadow them? Will it complicate things?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always remember that your players aren't there to critique you. They just want to have a good time like you do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't build scripted scenes. Build situations and let the scene play out from the actions of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Nothing beats a strong start to your game. What will start your game off with a blast?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't stick to the published adventure if what is in your head sounds cooler than the words on the page.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your long-term campaign plans light and flexible. Focus two sessions out and let the campaign grow organically.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put Acs and DCs out in the open as soon as it is no longer interesting to hide them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Play D&D like you play craps. Everyone is on the same side and the only villains are the dice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change up your intricate puzzle if the characters are stuck. Don't admit that you ever did so.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a council meeting with the characters' favorite NPCs to clarify quests and goals. Think Council of Elrond.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bring the NPCs the characters like the best to the front. Bury those who hold little interest to the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Turn old enemies into new friends as the world changes. Cult of the Dragon as an ally? Sure!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use miniatures to represent the main villains in a campaign and keep them out to focus the players' attentions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use collaborative storytelling with your players to turn "ice troll 2" into Doctor Meat Haunch!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When faced with a deadly fight, clarify the risk and give the characters a dignified escape route.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all fantastic features in a location need some crazy environmental effect. The shell of an ancient purple worm is cool enough.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did the players come up with a short-cut by teleporting into the final bosses chamber? Go with it! Always aim towards cool.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: NPCs act from their own motives and interests, not from the direction you want the story to go. Does it make sense for them?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Regularly give your players three options plus any interesting ones they come up with on their own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running Theater of the Mind combat, give players the chance to describe how they want their characters to avoid threats.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give out powerful encounter-breaking magical items with heavy consequences. Let the characters make hard choices.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your mind wander to fantastic worlds, characters, and stories. Keep them flexible and only make them solid at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mash up multiple campaign adventures to give players a lot of interesting and unique options for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare as much as you need to feel comfortable running your next game ... and no more.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The less you prepare, the more room the game has to go in exciting directions at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think through the eyes of your villains. What are they doing right now?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal what you want from published adventures and throw away what doesn't delight you. Make them your own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use random tables to inspire and fuel your own creative ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How will the start of your next session draw your players into the game? What's the hard starting hook?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: from @JamesIntrocaso. Build a quick NPC by stealing a character from pop fiction and switching genders.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What secrets and clues might your characters uncover in your next session? This is the fuel and payoff for exploration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fantastic injuries are an interesting way to have a character change in your game. A mangled arm that sprouts Black Tentacles!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a set of five scenes in mind on hand for your next game. Why will the characters care?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down your players' birthdays in your calendar and run special sessions for them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review your characters before prepping and running your session. How can you hook them into the story?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the ACs of various armor types in mind. Customize the armor of humanoids to keep things interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pound for pound, giants make for fantastic powerful monsters. They hit hard and have tons of HP.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep your game by asking: Where does it start? What 5 fantastic locations do I have? What 10 secrets might be uncovered?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "What do you do?" is the key question to bringing the players into the game. Make sure they have good options available.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dungeons don't always have to make ecological sense. Sometimes players just want a funhouse to explore.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try different kinds of adventures, stories, and scenes. Solicit feedback to gauge what types of games your players enjoy the most.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build rooms like large physical puzzles. Use the rooms in White Plume Mountain as examples.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you know you're going to have some big choices of direction in your next game, prepare those directions ahead of time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every good battle has some interesting terrain going on. What are the terrain hooks the characters can use?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill in parts of the story with flash fiction when you want the game to continue away from the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put your own layer of antagonists on top of the dungeons in published adventures. Zhents invading White Plume Mountain?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Show pictures from your books so players can see the monsters they fight or the dungeons into which they delve. Use the art!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put enemies in disadvantageous positions from time to time. Life doesn't always go well for them either.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use gridded combat, abstract maps, or theater of the mind whenever the scene and pacing best calls for it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reward dangerous heroics with inspiration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be fair with an enemy's attack. Choose random targets or have good reason to pick on a particular character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Refer to a character's background when relevant to the description in a scene to make them a part of it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As players to describe parts of their own backgrounds relevant the the current story or scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time just listening to your players talk about their characters. Just shut up and listen for a minute.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build up a good playlist of music and run it in the background of your game nice and low.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of saying "no" offer a check at disadvantage against a hard DC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write intelligent weapons down next to your characters on your campaign worksheet. They matter too and are worth remembering.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Replace meaningless NPCs in published adventures with NPCs your players know and remember.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin chambers in published dungeons with those that fit the theme of your campaign. WPM bubble room to submerged giant tomb.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Look out for and save great fantasy artwork to inspire you and your players during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your favorite tools on hand to help you improvise during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good dungeon masters are flexible and can adapt quickly to change. How do you stay flexible and adapt during your game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seek sources of input that bring you the most creativity. Movies, music, books, TV shows; which ones ignite your imagination?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be patient and listen to your players. Let them bring their own creativity to the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Break away from the Facebooks, Twitters, Twitches, and Youtubes for a bit and sit down and read your favorite #dnd sourcebook.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even for the most improvisational DMs, knowing where your game starts is likely a critical bit of prep.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Earn the players' trust to run a great game. Play fair and for the fun of all.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Battles shouldn't just be filler. What interesting parts of the story will the characters learn in this fight?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you know a battle is going to take place in a certain location, a cool battle setup can add a lot of fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Theater of the Mind if you aren't sure where things are going or whether combat will turn into a RP or exploration scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Intelligence weapons are NPCs that are always on stage ready to share useful secrets or backstory.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let scenes flow naturally. Don't assume a scene will focus on roleplaying, combat, or exploration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make Dungeon World "Hard Moves" to push the PCs. Swimming salamanders pop the bubble in White Plume Mountain!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't always have to draw overhead maps. Draw side-views and isometric maps to show the depth of places.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write notes on 3x5 cards or print emails to keep track of away-from-table RP and story developments. Stick them in your DM folder.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every game will be great. You'll have your share of stinkers. Learn from them and let them improve the rest of your games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry too much about overpowered magic items. You can always increase the challenge level and add more monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Oceans Eleven style heists are a great hook for a D&D adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some situations require more than seat-of-the-pants improvisation. Give yourself the time you need to build out detailed scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lost for ideas? Start with the backgrounds of the characters and see what comes up!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Character names are important. Spend the time necessary to commit them to memory.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need a good in-scene gambling game? Try "Gladiators"!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players three clear options if they get stuck but let them come up with and follow their own if they prefer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on fantastic locations, motivated NPCs, and interesting situations. Let the characters drive the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Street craps, gladiator dice, and cee-lo are fast tavern-style dice games to run in taverns or casinos in game. Google them!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put action into the hands of the characters. Let them drive the action of the game, not your favorite important NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be ready of fail forward at any given skill check so a whole operation doesn't fail completely on a single shitty roll.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw maps of locations even for exploration and roleplaying scenes to help players see the scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always be prepared to throw away any big fancy thing you prepared if the story is more fun going off the path.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up exploration, interaction, narrative, and combat scenes to keep the pace of your game moving at a fun speed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use Theater of the Mind, rough abstract maps, and gridded set pieces to fit the battle that brings the most fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your unpainted giant statues unpainted so they can fill in for different kinds of giants or even ancient fantastic statues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Our hobby is constantly evolving. Do not look at how others play differently with scorn but with awe, wonder, and happiness.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use elevation to make a set-piece battle look really interesting. High platforms and tall mountains.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure your fantastic features have hooks relevant to the characters and that hook your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In every scene, in every narration, ask yourself "why would the characters care?" Give them a reason.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try not to get too crafty or deep into your story. Many players just want to explore a dungeon and kill some goblins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Feel free to dynamically reduce the hit points of monsters to speed up a grinding combat. Don't tell them you've done so, though.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stand up to help your voice project when you're describing important elements of your game. It also keeps your energy level up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When teaching the game, get as fast as possible (like within 10 minutes) to playing the game. The rules aren't that important.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the players come up with a better idea than the one you had, smile, wiggle your eyebrows, and pretend it was yours all along.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "I seek adventure" is the best character motivation. Let your own characters' background come as close to this as possible.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be ready to throw the subtlty and hidden details of your mysterious story aside if the players don't seem to resonate with it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time reviewing the quests the characters are currently working on so the players can get a refresher.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure you balance narrative descriptions (you talking) with the investigation, roleplaying, and combat driven by the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use titles and in-world accomplishments as rewards to characters. "Heroes of Gauntlgrym", "Ally of Klauth", etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hard choices sound like fun but they can put a large cognitive burden on the players. Sometimes they don't want hard choices.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare a few relevant encounters to keep on hand if the story's getting stale and its time for a scrape.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What are the unique characteristics of the locations the characters will visit. Bar with a sagging upper balcony?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Frame your world's history and descriptions from the point of view of the characters, their histories, and their drives.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use elevation to make your combat scene interesting. Foam blocks are a great way to prop things up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What are the big interesting features of your combat area? How can characters use them to do something fantastic?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ancient machinery makes for great objects and areas to explore. How does it work? How does it KEEP working?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just because the characters are level 12 doesn't mean all the castle guards became champions. Use context-relevant monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend time learning the interesting features of popular landmarks of your campaign world. Describe the dank majesty of Skullport!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When a player gives you a rich character background, it's a gift! Mine it for interesting story threads to weave into your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the backgrounds of the characters as the lens to describe what they see. Dwarves understand the ancient structure of caves.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use an old black t-shirt or other piece of cloth as a fog-of-war on your 3d dungeon setup.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Big maps and 3d terrain setups don't only have to be for combat. Use them for exploration and roleplay scenes as well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of building your own random encounter charts, spend time building interesting and meaningful encounters you'll always use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of vague descriptions of long travel, add in one or two interesting specific scenes that happen along the way.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the wild magic table to spice up a battle. Expect the room to be filled with flumphs, however, so prep a fireball.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even without a grid, its fun to see a miniature of a monster you're about to fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give bandits, guards, and other humanoids different weapons, armor, and appearances to spice them up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't fret the save or suck spells the characters inflict on monsters. Revel in their short-circuit successes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Character rests are a resource. Keep track of them to not overwhelm or underwhelm your characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up hard fights (room full of Slaads) and easy ones (two CR 1/4 guards). It doesn't always have to be perfectly balanced.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Epic chamber battles always seem to take place in the doorways. What will draw the characters into your epic chamber?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What hooks in your next adventure tie into the backgrounds of the characters?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A handful of specific locations with fantastic features helps you fill in gaps as characters explore the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: bookmark individual @DnDBeyond pages to your home screen for a quick lookup during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a battlespace inhibits movement, make it clear what the characters can and can't do. "Two moves to get to the balcony".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of the characters on your phone or in your pocket notebook so you can refer to them as ideas come to you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time reading through the Dungeon Master's Guide again. There's always ideas you can use to refresh.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every few sessions try a downtime session where characters can spend time in a city on personal quests.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: During downtime sessions, ensure each player gets time to talk about their actions and goals.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Magical scrying is a great way to foreshadow things the characters otherwise might not see.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe rich and evocative locations but be brief, no one wants a 30 minute monologue.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read the body language of your players. Are they into what's going on or tuning out? Adjust as you go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare your game  just up to the edge of comfort, but not quite fully.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Practice voices in your car and by yourself to wire them in.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare for your game by speaking through the voice of the major NPCs. What would they say right now?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seed your mind with your favorite source of fantasy art. It serves as both direct inspiration and as mindful priming.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players explore the wonders of the world through the eyes of their characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down features of a battle ground useful to the characters so the players can see it and use it. Think Fate-style "aspects".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe evocative and dramatic details when running Theater of the Mind combat. Don't focus on the numbers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes we must take discontinuities in our story and world and MAKE them true.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Improvise the threads that connect characters to the world. We need not plan them all out ahead of time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start managing the time your game is going to take right away. Don't wait until there's 30 minutes left to worry.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the players pick up on a false clue, worry not unless it's going to steer a great deal of the game off course.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dungeon crawls offer an excellent fixed world where the characters can rarely get too off course.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your game as close to the action, any action, as you can. Nothing helps players lean forward right away like action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In a rush to prep your game? What is your strong starting scene and what are ten secrets and clues the characters can discover?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From @JeremyCrawford View things as a player. What would hook YOU?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the plethora of live-play games to get ideas how other DMs run their games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From Never Unprepared: 'The true goal of your session notes is to make you comfortable enough to run your session.'
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From Emily Care Boss in Unframed: "Become an attentive fan of what the players create."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From John Arcadian in Unframed: "The least important thing about your game is the plot."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From @ChrisPerkinsDnD "Listen more than you talk."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Challenge powerful parties with more monsters not just bigger monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't shy away from letting your characters mow through lower powered encounters. It's fun!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The listed hit points of a monster is just the average, you are free to adjust them up or down to suit the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep control of the number of rests the characters get to keep the pressure high.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw maps of large areas and denote the main features the characters can explore.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Powerful monsters control their terrain. When appropriate, use terrain advantages to put the pressure on the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Expect a shit-ton of attacks to pour out of your high level fighters right away with multi-attacks and action surges.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful removing actions and options from characters. Give them the freedom to choose their actions and change the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary of invisibly "wrong" choices. A quick decision shouldn't lead to unknown and irrevocable consequences.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Increasing hit points is the most likely way to make a boss harder to plain defeat. Double or triple HP with lots of PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Magic items are a great vehicle for story, secrets, and clues the characters will remember.
author: Michael E. Shea
