text: #dnd tip: Great magic items define characters. They become a core component of the character's arc, motivations, and desires.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Running combat in the theater of the mind may make you care less when battles don't go as you expect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use that flip mat in front of you to sketch side-views that show the huge scale of vast halls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When things are slow, the door bursts open to reveal assassins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of rewarding a straight magic item, consider rewarding parts of a larger powerful magic item crafting quest.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe zombies by the people they used to be. Farmers, blacksmiths, tavern waiters, barbarian hunters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Anything we can do to improve our improvisation skills will pay dividends the rest of our DMing lives.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players to describe the results of their heroic actions. Let them take control of the scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bookmark the monsters that may show up in your next game and use your MM right at the table!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Charmed enemies are a great way to reveal secrets and clues to the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before you build a super-challenging boss fight, put yourself in the mind of the players and ask if it would be fun for you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Like us DMs, boss monsters will test the characters out with powerful minions or simulacrums to see how they do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There are fewer fun suckers than action denial. Be careful taking actions away from characters in combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read adventures, and the next section of adventures you plan to run, before you run them. There's no good lazy trick.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choose the number of monsters during the game based on the need for hopeful (fewer monsters) or fearful (more monster) beats.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good drama comes from an intermix of hopeful and fearful beats throughout the game. Prepare to improvise both.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not every boss fight needs to be a balanced arena. Let the characters set the stage to trap a boss and kick its ass.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop in hard moves when things look too easy or well refined. Two fire giant guards go to fetch Duke Zalto for dinner.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use John Carpenter's "The Thing" to model the stressful situations when NPCs might be possessed by ghosts or Yakfolk.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fire, water, and the limitless energy of undead might all be harnessed to power aspects an ancient dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw vertical maps along with flat maps when the battle space is in 3d.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Villains aren't totally omnipotent. What do they know and what is outside of their sight?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players inspiration when they willingly move the story forward and take risks doing so.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find and keep handy the tools that help you improvise during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drape initiative cards with vital character stats over the top of your DM screen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stat blocks for NPCs are extremely useful for improvising various bad guys. Be familiar with them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep maps for common locations like castle ruins, catacombs, villas, and other common fantasy locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared to improvise for all three pillars: secrets for exploration; random names for NPCs; good monsters for combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the price in blood, flesh, and soul required to forge powerful magic items?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie NPCs to characters to build meaningful relationships right from there inception.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend the time to really read the stat blocks of monsters you plan to run. Then read them again right before you use them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Light prep doesn't mean no prep. Spend the time you need to prepare for a great game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Beautiful maps and 3d terrain isn't just for combat. It works well for exploration and roleplaying scenes as well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running Theater of the Mind, ask for the players' intent and lean towards saying "yes and here's how".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Talk to payers about their overall intent and expectations with the design of their characters. What do they hope to do?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When building interactive components of a detailed combat encounter, start with the story and design around it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Miniatures work just as well for table props just to show off villains and keep people's attention on the goal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Begin your game by asking players to describe what happened in the previous session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need a "hard mode"? Switch from average damage to max damage, or add 50% more dice to attack rolls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even a few 3d props on a battle map can make it pop. A gnarled tree or strange statue are perfect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Native habitats, leylines, ancient monuments; any of these can give monsters an advantage against the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Nothing shakes up a fight like waves of monsters. Have the boss show up on round 2.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even the very walls of a dungeon can lead to exploration of the ancient and the strange.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend the time to actually read the Monster Manual. It has hundred of adventure ideas packed into it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scale up legendary actions and lair actions to account for more than four characters in big battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Elder gods staring out of the abyss make for great powerful environmental effects in a big battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Challenge players in powerful encounters but be wary of taking away their actions and favorite abilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Many encounters without a rest will wear down even the most powerful characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up poster maps and 3d terrain to build large battle areas that pop.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Waves of enemies will put a high pressure on the characters in a challenging encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Who doesn't love tentacled horrors? You can never have enough tentacle attacks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Great villains scry on the characters but not all the time. They know a lot but not everything. The chars must deal with scrying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You can paraphrase descriptions from the DMG or Monster Manual almost directly to build evocative imagery to the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When building a ship, airship, or spelljammer for the characters, let them describe the features of the vehicle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Place situations in front of the characters but not necessarily the solutions. See how they approach the problem themselves.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: NPCs have cognitive biases just like we do. Sometimes they refuse to believe the truth because its just too painful.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: D&D is about sitting around a table laughing with your friends. That's the core of our game. Embrace it every session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Boss confrontation isn't about fights, its about the story. What is the boss doing as the characters approach? What do they want?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes your dungeon unique among all other dungeons? What is its overall big trait?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hunting a lich's phylactery might be a campaign-long adventure. Think Harry Potter hunting horcruxes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What angle might the characters discover that lets them outsmart their villain?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What traps make sense for the dungeon the characters crawl? Just write down the idea and improvise the mechanics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes the characters get the drop on the villain in a really bad spot. Not every boss fight is a huge set-piece encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A jaunt into the astral plane is always fun for high level characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce henchmen and sidekicks to your boss early and often so the characters enjoy facing them later.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Things a bit too easy on the characters? Try using maximum damage instead of average damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus less on balancing encounters and building mechanics and more on pondering the story of the game that unfolds at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write out one fantastic location and three notable features for every 45 minutes of gameplay you expect to run. Example: Chamber of Orbs; dozen multicolored orbs swirling around the room, covered orb of antimagic in the center, angel of vengeance carved into iron door.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reflavor features of a dungeon to fit the background of the characters. Statues become those of the deities of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build situations and let the characters decide if they're going with combat, exploration, or roleplaying. Don't presuppose how it will go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running a legendary monster, take the time to re-read the stat block before combat begins. Don't forget lair actions!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What five fantastic locations might come up in your next game? What three notable features do each of them have?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bring up the threat of any boss monster by maximizing its hit points and damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Boss monsters are more than just bags of hit points and beams of damage. What plot are they setting up to thwart the characters?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the main hook for your next session? What is the goal?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take inspiration from anywhere. Old cover to an Iron Maiden album? Done!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to throw dozens and dozens of low CR monsters against your high level PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try out static monster damage when the stakes are low and combat speed is important. It's not as big a deal as you think.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always start by considering the characters, their backgrounds, and their motivations before building your next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down seven tips after your D&D game on things you learned and areas where you can improve.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep track of and cultivate the relationships the characters build with NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give options and opportunities while describing the story. Expect the characters to get involved and change it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Research or make up the histories of the fantastic locations the characters explore in the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the individuals of a mob of enemies. Don't make them just a faceless mass. Give a few of them unique character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seek out and show interesting artwork depicting fantastic locations. Change your description to fit the art. It's not canon until it hits the ears of the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players describe the upgrades to their airship or the details of their home, castle, or tower.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: We can lazy-DM our way through a lot but boss confrontations require some careful planning and preparation. Give them the time they deserve.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For major confrontations at high levels, don't be afraid to go well beyond "deadly" encounters as long as you have a vague idea how the challenge will play out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of thinking about a boss encounter as strictly tactical combat, ask what big story element will be revealed during the confrontation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Smart villains know the devastation caused by splitting the party. How can they use that to their advantage?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Boss fights aren't just an opportunity to beat the hell out of the characters, its an opportunity for the characters to play true to themselves and their capabilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Wizard and sorcerer villains can use simulacrum to split themselves into multiple headaches for the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What series of events might cause a boss villain to become an ally of the characters against an even worse foe?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What are your new year's goals for your D&D games in 2018?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't rob the characters of a killing blow against a boss just because you have some cool story idea on how they die.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End your campaign with some collaborative storytelling asking where the characters headed next in turn; where they went, what they did, where they were one year out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful with character manipulation at the end of a campaign. Let the player drive their character's actions and desires. Don't tug too hard.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drive the final boss battle from the story. It doesn't need to be a perfectly well designed combat encounter. The story of the battle matters more than the mechanics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Defeating a boss doesn't always mean killing it in combat. It could be destroying the boss's plans with a single word, act, or deed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ancient dragons are really powerful even for their CR and especially the spellcasting variety. Be wary.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reading sourcebooks, monster manuals, adventures, and campaign books is one of the best non-lazy ways to improve our DM skills.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your session zero with the basic rules of the game. In particular, characters exist to go on cooperative fantastic adventures with their companions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Intro sessions to new campaigns are the best place to establish the scope, scale, and theme of the campaign for the players and DMs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a small intro scene prepared for your session zero games just to get everyone started playing some #dnd.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Other than a name, we don't need much to improvise NPCs. Jump into the shoes of the character and see how they fill out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes what players say they want out of their D&D games, and what they ACTUALLY want aren't the same things. Observe their behavior as much as listening to their feedback.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Campaigns don't have to be long affairs, build fun and focused campaigns that last about five to ten levels.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes each location in our adventures fantastic, functions, and familiar?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As anxious as we feel about running our next game, we can remember that we're with friends and all of us want to have a good time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use miniatures to represent the off-stage villains so the players never lose track of who their nemesis is.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read through whole published adventures before you run them and then read each section again right before you run it to be as familiar as possible.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't have to remember every canonical bar and shop in Baldur's Gate. Just make one up. (art from the game Epic Citadel)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go easy at level 1 and get them to level 2 fast. This is the most deadly level for characters of any.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In the right circumstances, kobolds can always be deadly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Beautiful fantasy maps can draw your players into the world their characters inhabit. .
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Improvise NPCs from your favorite movie or TV characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What features make your mundane locations fantastic? (anyone know the artist?)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your session preparation by reviewing the characters, their backgrounds, and their motivations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: At low levels, even a battle against rat swarms becomes a fight to remember. (artist unknown)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a scene start to feel boring, feel free to jump forward to the next interesting path you can see.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all fantastic items need be magical. A clockwork fish in a bowl can be well loved and remembered.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of copying monster stat blocks down, simply use the actual monster manual at the table. This helps you avoid railroading towards certain monsters if the story ends up in a different direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There is little need to build your own NPC stat blocks. Simply reskin one of the NPC stat blocks in the Monster Manual or Volo's Guide. Close enough is just fine.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Battle maps and terrain need not only serve combat but also as visual guides for exploration and roleplaying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The world does not conform to the level of the characters but that doesn't mean the characters don't have a chance to see when they're outmatched.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Monsters aren't always standing guard waiting for the characters to rush in. Sometimes they have other problems.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Weather and celebrations are a great way to add another dimension of life to your adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players love to have a base of operations to call their own. A dwelling, lair, fortress, or ship make fantastic rewards.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players an expectation of the types of gameplay they might expect in a particular session. If they don't seem interested, consider a pivot.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in upward beats with your downward bits of terror in a suspence or horror session or it will seem like a slog the whole time. Give them some fun breaks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer inspiration to those willing to step foward into obvious danger to keep the game moving smoothly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build murder mysteries by laying out what happened and writing down potential clues the characters can discover that might reveal the true story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Feel free to change the result of a mystery if the players went down a different and more interesting road.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Two mysteries wound together can add fun complications to an investigation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the madness effects on hand. Madness is a wonderful universal mechanic for horror in D&D.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend less time talking and more time listening. Enjoy the banter of the players and step in when guidance and direction is needed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the failed special attacks of monsters as you would the successes so the characters recognize how close they came to the edge of doom.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build situations, not plots or solutions. Let the players choose how to approach the challenges in front of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give chracters a cool home base they can call their own. Let them customize it how they want and refer to it often.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tap into the reactions of players to fill in the details of NPCs. If their nickname is cool or funny, let it stick.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Break up travel with a fantastic spooky monument and the monsters to which it calls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Generate random NPCs to break away from stereotypes or cliches.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Base in-game events to real-world events. On the night of a supermoon in real life, have them fight the beasts of the supermoon!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: We don't need to write down the stats of our reskinned monsters. Make the changes in your head and use the base statistics at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the pace of the adventure moving fast. Don't linger in one scene when it starts to get stale; leap forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: This is our monthly reminder to write down NPC names when they appear in our games. Players feel them break apart into ethereal mist when even we can't remember their names.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the players plan their approach to invading a small fort, pirate ship, defended keep, tower, or villa. We need not railroad them into one approach. Set the situation and let them choose the approach.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the hooks that seem to resonate to the players. Let those guide where the game moves forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch the movies that fit the theme of the adventure you're running to fill your head with ideas you can improvise as you run the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer advantage on attacks for those willing to perform a skill check to gain an advantageous position in combat. It's an easy mechanic for an infinite range of awesome flavorful situations and attacks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Monsters don't always make optimal moves. Let them make bonehead mistakes for the fun of the story and the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Help players break away from counting squares by letting them move more squares than they normally could so they can actually engage an enemy other than waste a whole turn.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tell small bits of the story, history, and situation through small bits of lore the characters learn with skill checks as they investigate the world around them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use video game soundtracks for background music during your game. My personal favorite? Witcher 3!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your group's size down to four or five players so each player gets enough screen time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never worry about putting piles of low challenge rating monsters in front of your higher level characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: We can get away with just about anything for monster miniatures on a map but players really love to have nice miniatures for their characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a set of generic pogs or tokens for monster minis when running unexpected improvised combat and keeping the flow of the game moving smoothly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a truly lethal game, remember that damage to a character at zero hit points inflicts a death save. An assassin can use all three attacks to kill a downed character outright.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer multiple lines of investigation and let the players follow those that they discover, choose, or enjoy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Player's don't all seek the same thing from our games. Take their feedback, consider it, and make small changes to improve your game carefully.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Though a player cannot pull the punch on a ranged attack or spell to knock out an opponent, nothing prevents you from asking the player whether the shot or blast killed the character by sheer circumstance.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When planning your game, build sitiuations and have the NPCs act as they would act even if the characters aren't there. Let the characters interact with the situation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your characters find a creative way to circumvent a long plot line you had planned, let them! They will find their way to new and interesting adventures. .
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the actions of your characters have a big impact in the world they may not see, break away from their PoV and describe the impact from another character's view.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin scenes and situations you had planned to fit the unexpected direction your characters took. A scene in a ball might turn into a carnival.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When thinking about your game, seed your brain by repeating the names of the characters over in your head.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the players clues that villains may be scrying upon them. Let them worry about it or use it for their own advantage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put hard choices in front of the players and don't pre-suppose the answers. Give them reasonable options instead of death behind two of three doors.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop clues and lore in random encounters to tie them to the main story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep inspirational art at hand to help you imagine and enrich fantastic locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Encourage the narrative descriptions of attacks and killing blows from your players to draw them into the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the tools and accessories that help you run your game smoothly and with the flexibility to change as the story changes. (pic from @newbiedm)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players to describe interesting sights, sounds, smells, and situations instead of droning through long descriptions of travel.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The limitless age and experience of hags are their ultimate weapon. How will they thwart your heroes from afar?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go big with fantastic features. Nothing creates awe like sheer size.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Monsters might not be simply motivated to kill the characters. Sometimes they just hate fire and want to put it out...or start one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus the spotlight on the NPCs the players find the most interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Select the number and type of monsters by the story and situation. Check to see if the encounter is deadly with Kobold Fight Club.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bring back NPCs from previous campaigns to reward your players for their past stories.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Throw easy encounters into the mix so the players don't feel like they've had a whole night of getting the crap kicked out of them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not all players enjoy or loathe the same things in our games. Survey regularly and take note of who likes what.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Vary the damage of traps so they don't feel too vanilla. Don't put too many traps in a row.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pondering how to start a new campaign or fork into a new one from an existing one? Have a new session zero and bring the players into the discussion. Ask them what they want out of it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scenes with antagonistic NPCs might or might not turn into a fight. Don't force them one way or the other. Let the scenes evolve as the characters interact.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Printing 11x17 maps from published adventures is a great way to squeeze a lot of the production value of published adventures into our game without breaking the bank. (map by Mike Schley)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Learn from everywhere. Read books. Watch movies. Watch #dnd streams. Take a break from social media and read an actual D&D sourcebook.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of having a high-level NPC save the party, give the stat block to one of the players and let them RUN the high-level NPC in a big battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Re-use interesting combat encounter areas by having the characters return to the scenes of old battles to face new foes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did the characters suddenly come into unexpected wealth (say slaying a dragon)? Don't find ways to steal all their money. Let them change the world with it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make sure the scope of the story matches the level of the characters. Rat swarms are suitable for level 1. Demon princes are suitable for level 20. The scope and scale of the characters' actions should increase proportionally.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use loaded questions to guide character creation "Why does your character want to travel into the jungles of Chult with the rest of the party to stop the death curse?"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make sure to write down what the players bring to your session zero. It's your best chance to understand what the characters are bringing to the campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A big 36" by 48" sheet of acryllic is a perfect tabletop accessory. You can slide maps, pictures, and handouts underneath. It's perfectly flat and miniatures feel great on it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Old characters can become the patrons of new characters in a new campaign. Let previous characters have a background impact in the new campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running a published adventure, make sure to have one or more strong threads that help the players make choices and navigate open worlds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to paint a Reaper Bone in a hurry and on a budget? Paint it with gray gesso and use an ink wash on it for a nice-looking table-ready gray-scale mini.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Do you have a great idea for an action-packed scene? Don't force the story to lead them there, just start them right in the middle of it! "How did you end up riding a Triceratops in the Unchained dinosaur race?"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down a list of interesting locations in towns or cities in published adventures so you have a quick index and don't have to flip pages.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running a published adventure, spend time reviewing the next section even if you've already read it. A refresher is always handy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if you have piles of miniatures, keep some generic monster tokens on hand for improvised battles or small fights that don't demand you dig through the vaults looking for the perfect mini.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Adding a daily spell to a magic item is a great way to make it both thematic and mechanically useful.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A strong start is very important. So is knowing where things might go AFTER the strong start. What's next when that scene is done?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choose the tools for running your D&D game that help you stay flexible and improve your improvisation. Less is more.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Outline important locations in a city and offer these options to players so they don't feel completely lost when exploring this large city.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The soundtrack to Darkest Dungeon makes for some excellent D&D background music.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give magic items a name, a history, and a once-per-day spell effect to make them unique, powerful, and exciting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep small dungeons on hand when the players want some fun exploring lost ruins, ancient temples, forgotten cellars, and other unexplored locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dark dreams and strange portents are great ways to drop hard clues in on characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Zombies are harder to kill than you'd think for a challenge 1/4 monster. Be prepared for a hard slog if it keeps making it's constitution save.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need some dinosaur minis for your Tomb of Annihilation game? Pick up a sheet of dinosaurs from @TrashMobMinis and @JohnPuhCreation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend some time describing the grandeour of the characters' location including sights, sounds, and smells.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a careful eye on the challenge of improvised threats. Two CR 5 creatures are definitely too hard for five level 3 characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe situations and observations by the context of the characters. The assassin's killer instinct tells her that invisible eyes are upon her.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes a list of ten secrets and clues the characters might discover during the adventure is all you need to run a fun game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use weather, potential random encounters, the results of exploration skill checks, and interesting ancient monuments to build a rich scene during your exploration adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your preparation by running through the characters to put their stories firmly in your head before you prep anything else.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make dungeons seem mysterious and real by adding the sound of large wheels, running water, and dropping counterweights behind the walls of the halls they explore.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend a quick moment reading up on the story of a monster before throwing them at your group. You might glean some interesting story hooks from the monster's background.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Low challenge monsters like koblds and goblins can still harass higher-level characters by setting off traps, stealing goods, or alerting larger foes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Interesting scenes have a lot going on in them. Goblins stealing canoes and blowing a horn to call a t-rex right after the characters left a dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some of the most interesting magical items have no combat value but lots of roleplay value.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Only have a few minutes to prepare for your game? Write down a strong start and ten secrets and clues the characters might discover.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In dungeon delves, keep note when the players are rolling like crap and find a way to add some upward beats to keep them motivated to go forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in a good bit of non-combat encounters into your random encouters while traveling. Let the characters learn about the world through the creatures they meet.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give big monsters names that will follow the characters throughout an adventure. Ambereyes the ancient crocadile seeks revenge.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the right combat system for the right situation. Theater of the mind works well for quick skirmishes. An elaborate map and miniatures work well for large cinematic and complicated situations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did the characters run into a lot of money or rescue a bunch of prisoners? Use the followers and loyalty rules in the DMG to establish a home base or sailing ship full of hirelings.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add interesting monuments to random encounters so the place as as much character as the monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Battles aren't always about killing all of the enemies. Sometimes the goal is to stop the goblins from stealing canoes while avoiding a zombie T-rex. (miniature by Ryan Harris)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players to define interesting physical characteristics of monsters to draw them into the story and help you identify targets in combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie interesting spell effects to magical items that make sense for the origin of the item. For example, a dwarven elemental breastplate that casts Stoneskin named Mountainhide.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie secrets and clues to enemies with things like strange tattoos or decorative symbols on weapons or armor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Evil doesn't always wear a black hood and cloak. Evil can lurk in the hearts of the "righteous" lords who send thousands to their deaths based on ego.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes, instead of straight victory, a battle instead gives the players something to learn about the story or the characters something to discover. It's not all about combat victory, sometimes it's about information.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Low challenge battles are a great way for the characters to feel powerful and have opportunities to try other options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For single-session scenes, along with a strong start, have some idea where the adventure will end. It might change but keep the end in sight when there's a fixed timetable for the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll on random encounter tables not necessarily to show the characters what is there but to show them what HAD been there hours or days ago.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill your mind with fantastic fiction; books, movies, comics, and TV shows. Steep yourself in great writing and bring it forth during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Turn named enemies into "legendary" versions by doubling their hit points and giving them legendary actions for single attacks or cantrips and resistances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The story of a monster is more important than the monster's statistics. How does this monster act and react in the world around it? What makes it dangerous?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use fantastic specifics to describe locations. The smell of ozone. The deep rumbling in the earth. The radiating feeling of electrical dread.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some villians are most dangerous outside of combat. Only when their plans are either fully disrupted or fully in fruition will they put themselves in harm's way.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good villains think they're right in what they do. Great villains actually ARE right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A fantastic feature, a hazard, a hidden foe, and a box of treasure makes for a wonderful focused adventure scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What agents seek out the same treasures that your characters seek?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Continually switch genders of the NPCs and monsters your characters face when exploring the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare your players for the harsh possibility of character deaths. Suggest they build a stable of characters should one suddenly perish in the darkest depths of the deathtrap dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build meaningful but well-hidden treasure parsels and then move them from place to place if the characters don't find them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Aim for high fantasty and brevity when describing the locations the characters explore.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give characters a clear reason to explore dangerous locations or don't be surprised if they simply give it a miss.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down ten bite-sized pieces of history the characters can learn when exploring a forgotten location.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get used to averaging and maxing dice damage in your head to help you streamline rolls and tweak monster damage. Avg dmg = die max + 1 * (num dice / 2). 8d6 fireball = 28 avg or 48 max. 24d10 deadly trap can be converted to 4d10 + 110.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tweak monsters but consider what these changes mean within the story. Increasing an ogre's AC from 11 to 18 is fine but describe the full plate of iron armor they now wear.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the Dungeon Master's Guide guidelines for running a large number of foes to let your group face huge numbers of low CR monsters. Fighting fifty skeletons is fun!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prune your miniatures, maps, and 3d terrain pieces by taking out and storing those you tend not to use very often, if at all.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid too many battles of a similar type too close together. Don't run two large battles against hordes of monsters back to back. Shake up small skirmishes, large battles against hordes, and fights against big bosses.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running a puzzle, make sure there are logical ways the characters can figure it out. Avoid puzzles that require some external force to explain it all to them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In sandbox games, give players roughly three potential options or paths they can choose from plus any more that they come up with while hearing those options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use small simple sketches to help explain physical situations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be a slave to a published adventure. If a scene doesn't work for you or the group, change it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use small tricks to get players into the story. Have them describe killing blows. Have them identify interesting physical traits of monsters. Have them describe details of locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: worry less about the damage players roll and, if the story and energy calls for it, call it a killing blow!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use passive insight and passive perception to speed up gameplay when desired. Use them to narrate scenes from the point of view of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid building encounters with expected outcomes. Let the characters find unique ways to deal with a situation. If they can fly over deadly pit traps, so be it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Shadar-kai from Mordenkainen's Tome of Foes can be reskinned into some pretty bad-ass vampires.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep some quick and loose encounter building guidelines in hand to improvise encounters at the general difficulty you have in mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Integrate the story into combat. Let the characters discover interesting secrets and clues or meet new NPCs while combat rages around them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Create "assassin" versions of normal monsters by boosting their dexterity and giving them stealth proficiency, Cunning Action, and Sneak Attack.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make any monster a vampire by giving it regeneration, a bite attack that drains life, movement that doesn't provoke opportunity attacks, and vampire vulnerabilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random encounters can be a fun way to liven up travel instead of just combat. Flying monkeys can steal the rogue's lucky decksof cards or a curious baby triceratops can wander into camp.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep three paths open in front of the characters so they have meaningful choices that move their story forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leap on the opportunities to add some roleplaying to combat encounters. Such scenes make battles unique and something to remember.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: when learning from other DMs, have more questions than opinions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is the energy around the table waning? Bring some energy back into your descriptions!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Do you find joy when your monsters make short work of the characters? Maybe shift your view to taking joy in their victories instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: DMs should know enough of the rules to keep the main game moving but needs little more. Work with the players to adjudicate when it makes sense or make a judgment and move on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to run a shorter adventure? Stick to Theater of the Mind battles with fewer foes to keep things going smoothly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: help players navigate the best skill to use for a given situation and don't punish them for exploring options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: One-sided battles that favor the characters are just fine when they make sense for the story and give them a chance to see the organic world around them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use flavor descriptions and theatrics to keep people's imaginations on the story when running narrative "theater of the mind" combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stay true to the tactics of monsters. Are they smart enough to know how to dive around melee to attack ranged attackers or are they a mindless hoard?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: After a session jot down some notes, particularly where the session ended, so you know where to start when preparing for your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the players feel like they're being railroaded, outline some alternative options they might have missed or forgotten about.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Celebrate when characters circumvent combat in a creative way. Skipping a fight can be as fun as defeating it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use what the players bring to you but don't screw them with it or they will never speak up again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Refresh your understanding of a monster by reviewing its background in the Monster Manual before you run it at your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use email to interact with players regarding the individual stories of their characters between games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are you prepared to have your battle circumvented with an intersting conversation or some great stealth checks?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For new DMs, watch streaming #dnd games like Dice Camera Action or Critical Role to see what this strange game actually looks like when played.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about how the characters are the best ones to handle a particular situation? What traits make them the right folks for the situation at hand?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Action doesn't always mean combat. Keep the story moving and interesting with lots of choices and lots of momentum even when the swords are sheathed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find interesting ways to test bosses before a final encounter. Simulacrums, dreams that manifest into reality, lich-like regeneration; any of these are ways bosses can test the mettle of characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Whenever you're hard pressed for original ideas, bring in a bit of randomness and see where your mind goes. Use Donjon; the best #dnd random generator on the net.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be generous with inspiration when players roleplay their characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a step back when into the deep tactics of combat to describe the imagery of what's happening in the fiction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add hidden rooms and secret doors to your dungeons. If they don't find them, move the contents elsewhere.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be really nice to level 1 characters and get them to level 2 after a stern conversation and a dead giant rat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What was your dungeon before it was a dungeon? What was it before that? Layer history over history to enrich fantastic locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't bother building your own random encounters since any you don't use likely end up wasted. Instead, use random generators to give you ideas for building interesting encounters the characters are sure to run into.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random encounters can be friendly parlays, meeting interesting people, or discovering hidden mysteries instead of just combat with monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Track the various factions of NPCs in your game, villians or not. What are they up to while the characters are off on adventures? Where might they come back into play?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use magic items as anchors for the story. A serpent-hilted sacrifical dagger found early on could be a key to unlocking the secrets of Dendar the Night Serpent later on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave blanks in your story. Let the imaginations of the players fill in unsolved mysteries, even at the end of a campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the players hard choices with unseen consequences. Let their own minds imagine what happens based on the decisions they make.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters new forward bases when they've explored deep into a land. Maybe a crashed airship can be their staging ground for a deep dungeon adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask loaded questions to fill out the story of the game. "What ancient piece of civilization do you hide behind when the undead gorilla comes around?"
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the difficulty dials in mind when running combat. Feel free to tweak hit points, damage, and the number of attacks to suit the threat of the situation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the Arcana skill to describe how a character can see into or manipulate the Weave; the web of magic that surrounds all of life. Twists, holes, and surges can reveal much of the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Study the stats and lore of the Monster Manual and then reskin to suit your own story as you need.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use strange and dark rituals to restore hit points lost to life drains during the death curse from Tomb of Annihilation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about the vertical axis in your combat encounters. What is above and below? Run battles in stark vertical climbs to change things up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop hints at the deeper and darker world that exists beyond the horizon. What is that huge shape that stirs storms with each beat of its wings?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use colorful descriptions to off-set seemingly boring monster statistics. Give them improvised abilities or let them use the environment to make them exciting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down character connections to the story as they occur. Review them while reviewing the characters at your next game prep session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a notebook handy during your game sessions. Write things down and review them after the game is over.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Talk to your players about them keeping game journals to tie them to the stories as they occur. Encourage them to draw pictures regardless of "skill".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on the tools and accessories that help you run fun and flexible games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put hard decisions in front of your players but don't shut down creative Kobayashi Maru solutions that get through them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 11x17 color maps are relatively cheap to print and make for great table accessories. Hit up your local print shop.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Physical well-made handouts can tactically tie players to the story as it goes on. Write in-character letters with fancy fonts on copper resume paper.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of dungeons as an entire set and situation the characters can thoroughly explore instead of a series of pre-defined encounters. What's happening in the whole dungeon?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reckless attack and pack tactics are some great monster abilities you can drop in when you want to up the threat and when they make sense for the story and situation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe actions using in-story narrative, not mechanical or numeric descriptions. Describe the scene, not the numbers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Work on projecting your voice. Try standing. It isn't always easy but it makes a big difference.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Visualize the scene and situation in your mind's eye and then describe it. Take a moment to imagine things as though you were standing there.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in low challenge monsters and encounters. Don't constantly seek challenging fights one after another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Create fast and hard-hitting combat encounters by increasing damage and decreasing hit points on monsters. You can tweak monster damage within the range of the damage dice and monster hit points within the range of hit dice and still be within the design.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be conscious of the amount of time things take between turns. Players should get more than 15 second turns in between eight minute rounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't make sausage in front of the players. Don't get into encounter design, challenge rating considerations, or what they WOULD have seen if circumstances had been different.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't hide initiative. Use table cards or fold-over initiative markers on the edge of a DM screen so everyone can see when the go in the order and can get ready.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understand the capabilities and desires of the characters and set them up for success. Give polearm masters and shield masters opportunities for their benefits.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask for a player's intent when they start asking about the environment. Ask what they want to do and help them do it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If it isn't clear, assume damage hits the most damaged monster. It's what we would assume smart adventurers would do anyway.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Each session, ask for something unique and interesting about each character. Learn together as a group what's going on within each character's story and background.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use random encounters as a way to expose new information of the story. Perhaps those random kobolds know where the shrines of the trickster gods lie.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Frame scenes with interesting weather and the times of the day. Where is the moon in the sky? What does the sunset look like? Is there a contrail from an airship high up in the sky?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Each session find a way to draw in one character into their backstory. Do they run into an old friend? Have a prophetic dream? Get hunted by assassins for a crime they didn't commit?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw side-view maps and isometric maps instead of always drawing top-down. Show the height of things.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give intelligent magic items their own character arc. Where did they come from? What do they want? Where are they going?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players a physical map they can mark up with a pen so it stands as an artifact to the campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go for a walk and think about seven tips you picked up from the last game you ran or watched.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the in-world actions taking place during the game. Who is doing what? What happens? What does it look like? Sound like? Smell like?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Recommend to players that they take notes during the game. In particular, note down the names of people and places and how they relate to the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read up on locations around the current position of the characters. Look up places in the Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide and let it spawn ideas for future adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What trade-off would make a character want to keep a curse or disease intact? What benefits does it provide that they may not want to lose?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use lower numbers for the quantity and challenge ratings of random encounters. Tie them to interesting secrets and clues the characters can uncover.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: build music playlists for relaxing, tense, and combat scenes to build the right atmosphere for the scene taking place. Witcher 3, Divinity Original Sin 1 and 2, Pillars of Eternity, Horizon Zero Dawn, and Darkest Dungeon soundtracks are awesome.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Encounters don't always have to lead to the central story. Some encounters, even random ones, give characters a view of the living world around them. They shouldn't be pointless but they don't have to be laser-focused either.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Highlight the other options for ending combat such as saving someone, capturing someone, stealing something, breaking something, staying quiet, being loud, or other such ends.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep in mind the motivations for the characters an the ways that can weave into the story. Are they trying to stop someone? Trying to save someone? Trying to make up for the past?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful forcing high level villains against low level characters to force them into an agreement. Give them an edge that won't make them either agree or TPK.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fighting hoards of low challenge monsters is a great way for mid- and high-level characters to feel awesome.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stay hydrated. Always keep some water nearby when running games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find opportunities for the rogue assassin to get the drop on enemies. We're too quick to ignore surprise rounds and assassinating is their one special thing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep options open in crucial conversations between the characters and NPCs. Always be thinking about the options available to the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When the characters find themselves facing an insurmountable foe, always make sure they have options available to them. How can they get some sort of upper hand?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember that random encounters don't have to be combat encounters. How can the characters negotiate with those goblins?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a character finds themselves in a life and death situation not necessarily of their own devices, give them a few chances at saving their lives with multiple skill checks and saving throws.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build scenes and situations without necessarily assuming they will be combat, exploration, or roleplaying. Let the players decide how to approach it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful with tag-along NPCs overshadowing the characters in an adventure. Give NPCs a reason to stay out of the spotlight or leave the party completely. Let them defer to the characters in most scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build terrain setups or maps in a way that lets you store them and pull them out when you need them so you don't force any particular scene to take place.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down a list of the critical scenes you want to see take place over the course of the next few sessions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Opposing factions within an enemy organization is a good way to add some interesting roleplaying and decisions to an otherwise slaughterfest.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add two different and viable entrances to your dungeon to help ensure your dungeon isn't a railroad of encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use dieties and powerful patrons as ways to tie into a characters' backgrounds. Visions and portents from their dieties shows you care enough to remember to whom they pray.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix monsters and story-appropriate environmental effects (mad monkey mist with wights!) for an interesting multi-variable encounter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If the players get stuck on a puzzle, use active or passive ability checks to drop in hints that help steer them to the right direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dreams and hallusinations are great ways to impart secrets and clues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try using maps and table top terrain for scenes of exploration and interaction instead of just combat. Use them as a table-aid to draw your players into the story (awesome setup by @Hyperionpdx).
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the right combat style for the right job. Use Theater of the Mind for quick skirmishes. Use tactical gridded maps for difficult battles with lots of moving parts. Use abstract maps when the battle area doesn't fit cleanly onto a grid.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Shake up boring battles with flavorful descriptions, intriguing secrets revealed, and interesting environmental options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer multiple solutions to most problems. Can they talk, sneak, or fight their way out?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Note down intelligent magic items as you would characters. How do they evolve over the campaign?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always have an exit strategy for tag-along NPCs. Why does Artus Cimber and Dragonbait want to leave the group soon?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Golems with shield-guardian-like hit point sharing options are great ways to protect NPC wizards. An archmage with a pair of iron golems who take her damage for her is a hard foe to defeat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read through sourcebooks and adventures to fire off your imagination for your own game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read sourcebooks and adventures from other game systems. The mechanics matter little and the ideas cross system boundaries easily.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read through and, if possible, try out other game systems to cross-train your DMing skills.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spell descriptions contain bits of story all to themselves. The powerful spells cast by NPCs can change entire adventures. They mean as much to NPCs as PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: NPCs may have spells outside of those in the books. These might be devastating world-changing rituals that must be stopped.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if money is plentiful, expensive spell components might not be. Few 1,000 gold piece bowls exist in the world, even for those with the funds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hit points and damage are two dials we can tweak to increase or decrese the threat depending on the needs of the story. Keep these dials in mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes a hero? How can we tug on that concept in our D&D games? Which antiheroes in our campaign might become heroes? Which heroes might fall?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find ways to shake up your game and the expectations of your players. At the same time, don't forget to keep it familiar and fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Blow up Vulcan. If your game needs to be shaken up, don't be afraid to let the meteors fall. It's your world and huge things can happen in it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write out your ten secrets for your game but then reveal them last to first. Those last secrets are often the doozies.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: That feeling you have that you're not ready for your game and they're all going to laugh at you? We all feel that way and it's still bullshit. Carry on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take it easy on yourself. Your players want to have a fun time. You want to have a fun time. Breathe deeply and enjoy your escape to a new world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Look for small ways to tweak your game and try things out. Make a large number of small changes over time. Make a small change, observe the impact, and then make another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add story-appropriate elemental damage to lower challenge monsters to make them fun tough opponents for higher level characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Constrain your game prep to a single piece of paper to get you to focus on what is most important.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Worry more about a monster's story and how that fits into the world than it's challenge rating.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add some chaos into your strong start. Entryways collapse, temples explode, Giff show up in a steampunk spelljammer (thanks @navy_dm!).
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let your story drive your tools and accessories, not the other way around.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a shot of inspiration, go through old boxes of miniatures or old maps and see what fires off your mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't punish impossible victories. Embrace them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reflavor monsters with interesting weapons and armor. Don't worry about changing the stats.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build trust with your players. You are not their adversary, you are there to make their characters do awesome things.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about setting a particular atmosphere. Your players will bring their own emotion to the game as it plays out. Follow the group's lead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a loose grip on the precision of the rules. There's a lot of flexibility built into 5e's mechanics. Allow for it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on what the characters will learn in the next game. Let the future of the campaign expand from this moment forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep an archive of your favorite maps from other adventures. Pull them out and maybe reverse them when you suddenly need a new dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the arc of the intelligent weapon in the character's hand? Where does it want to go? How will it get there?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bring in NPCs that matter to the characters. Let the others fade away.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Telegraph what kind of adventure you're going to run. If the theme of that adventure changes, let your players know.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep campaigns short and focused on the theme of the adventure. Work with players to build characters likewise focused on that theme.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down and track the story threads that matter to the characters. Tug on them appropriately.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let villains become allies and allies become villains. The line is thin between sharing a drink and sharing a blade.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep on hand the accessories that help the story unfold at the table. Note which tools help the most and which can go into deep storage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build situations and let the characters navigate them how they choose with exploration, roleplaying, or combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep an eye on the time. Start managing it the minute the game starts and adjust to fit the length of your session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give dungeons, even small ones, two entrances and one secret room. It helps avoid building one-track railroad dungeons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give each room in a dungeon at least two interesting features the characters can interact with.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the appearance of skeletons to tell something about the history of the area.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of every encounter, even random monster encounters, as an opportunity for roleplaying or exploration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Share the world through the eyes, backgrounds, and motivations of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about your dungeons in three dimensions. What's above and below?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you have the opportunity, re-running adventures makes them much smoother the second-time around.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even in the thick of running an adventure, take note of the hooks the players hand to you and use them later.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't thwart a player's unexpected idea. Embrace it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run monsters as they are in the Monster Manual. Tweak them only when you have a clear reason for it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the characters' actions uncover secrets and clue. Maybe that last casting of shatter revealed the secret passage behind the wall.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the characters find creative ways to use the environment to their advantage. Can they use the metal-destroying shield to get past the big propeller? Maybe!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Foreshadow potential deadly threats with dreams, visions, and feelings of dread portents. Let the players know they're walking into a deadly situation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure your players are prepared for the type of game you plan to run. Will it be a deep character-introspective adventure? An action serial? A deathtrap dungeon?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure players have spare characters if you're running a deathtrap dungeon. Tell them not to get attached.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players may love the idea of hardcore deathtrap dungeons but might like to actually play them. Test them out with one-shot deathtrap dungeons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always stay within the narrative of the story. Describe what happens, not the numbers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Address players by the names of their characters (thanks Dungeon World!)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your list of random names on hand. You'll never know when someone or something, even an old memory, needs a name.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Visions and hazy dreams are fantastic ways to project clues or potential dangers. Adventurers are constantly getting assaulted by strange premonitions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: pay special attention to new players in your group. There are things they might not get that aren't obvious to you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: let the careful plans of the players work out as they would. Don't do mental yoga to circumvent their efforts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: sometimes a dented breastplate can be an awesome treasure. Add flavor to every item to make it interesting and unique.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: size and age are two great ways to make realistic things truly fantastic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: use digital pictures on a tablet to show your players fantastic locations or interesting NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some dungeons, even entire worlds, are characters to consider during your prep. What do they want? Where are they headed?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: fear not throwing large amounts of enemies at your characters. Use mass combat guidelines to help you adjudicate such big battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on the start of your next session. What will draw your players into the game and let them know they're hip-deep in D&D?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the players time to plot and plan their approach. Sometimes such plans go off as expected and sometimes unforeseen variables throw them into chaos.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always keep an eye out for new members to join your group. Even if your group is perfectly healthy, a substitute player always helps and you never know if real life will tear someone away.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Expose the history of the world through the backgrounds of the characters. What do THEY know of the strange god-like beings depicted in the frescoes on the wall?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customize monsters with unique armor, weapons, and spells. Give them interesting tattoos, scars, or battle insignias.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe how characters passively perceive something. Do they see cobwebs blowing in a breeze that shouldn't be there?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Immerse yourself in the fantastic. Play games, read books, watch great TV shows and movies, soak up fantasy artwork, read fantasy poetry; fill your brain with fantasy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up weapons and armor types among humanoid monsters to make them all feel unique and interesting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When a player drops a story element on you, like an NPC from their past, grab it and run with it even if you don't know where it will end up. The story will happen on its own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players to reiterate their goals in an adventure. Let the other players fill those goals in. If none of them can remember, that's trouble.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep character and NPC backgrounds light hearted. Not everyone needs to come from a slaughtered village or a bloody altar under a gnoll's knife. Sometimes they come from a family of sixteen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players specific questions about their characters and listen to what they give you. What did they see in their uncle that got them to start adventuring? What inspiration did they take from their mother's book?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared for character conversations to go surprisingly well or surprisingly poorly. Not every meeting with a lich ends in death. Sometimes it ends with tea.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need inspiration? Grab the Dungeon Master's Guide off the shelf with some dice, read, and roll some random ideas to see what shakes up your world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take note of the pets of the characters. In many ways players love their pets as much as their PCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful with character arcs. Some players have a clear path they wan to take and shaking it up too much can ruin their fun. Ask them what they want from their PC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Study whole dungeons in published adventures thoroughly and you'll have a much easier time preparing from session to session as the characters navigate it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll on random tables ahead of time so you don't tip your hand showing that the world is just some random nonsense you're coming up with at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Simplify puzzles on the fly if they get boring or tedious. Let skill checks reveal things the players might have missed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reveal the purpose and origin of a dungeon through it's visible details and construction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players enjoy dominating what could have been a tough fight. Don't rob them of the easy victory.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: We get to choose whether to embrace fantasy with either childish wonder or adult cynicism. Open your eyes wide, smile, and be a kid again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down notes on your last game as close to the game as you can while it's fresh in your head.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Who are the characters? What is the strong start? What are ten secrets they might discover in the next session?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add some single-use relics to spice up treasure boards without overpowering your characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Inspire yourself with art.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a mix of props, printouts, music, and narrative to paint a picture in all dimensions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End sessions at the start of a major encounter to start strong at your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on the tools that help you create the story at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Relax, breathe deep, you're game is going to be great.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your DM kit small and flexible to let your game go in directions you haven't thought of. You need little more than a white board and a marker.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let music inspire your ideas. Put on some of your favorite tunes, close your eyes, and let the images come to you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hypothesize, experiment, and think about the results. Try stuff out and tune based on your experiences.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Explore randomness as a seed for new story directions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about the theme of your campaign and how you express it to your players.
author: Michael E. Shea
