text: #dnd tip: Be careful with effects that take away actions from characters. They can really bum players out. Give them options. Maybe they take psychic damage to steel themselves and get back into the fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The only way you'll really know if your players are ok with character deaths is to see how they act when characters die. It can be fun for one-shots but might suck in longer story-focused games
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember that spell effects occur in three dimensions. One can shrink the diameter of a fireball by casting it higher up in the air.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read up on a monster's background and lore before you run it. The stories of a monster can inspire new ideas when you roleplay them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even in combat scenes, it's worth knowing what a monster wants or what it needs. Some of the best roleplaying negotiations can happen in combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Break away from your typically story-focused narrative game with a really interesting tactical battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read body language to see what's working and what is not when you're running your game. Are they leaning forward or sitting back, arms crossed, and eyes narrowed?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let go of the tactics and mechanics of your game and lose yourself in the world of fantasy and the story of your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Embrace what's fun for the group and run with it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop circumstances, both lucky and unlucky, into the story. Watch what happens.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use maps, terrain, and miniatures to show off scenes of exploration and roleplaying instead of just combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Include two entrances and one secret room in dungeons you design.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Cursed magic items are tricky to inject. Think about how they may come into play, how not to overplay your hand, and how to ensure they're fun and not a drag.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Cursed magic items are tricky to inject. Think about how they may come into play, how not to overplay your hand, and how to ensure they're fun and not a drag.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your players are getting bored, speed up the pace. If they're getting frustrated, give them a boon. Oscillate the beats between hope and fear.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters a one-use item of power well beyond them. Let them shake the game up in an exciting way.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't fear for your monsters. You have an infinite supply.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read rooms in published adventures ahead of time. Cut or modify the ones that don't excite you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run published adventures more than once if you have the chance. Nothing solidifies a published adventure in your mind like actually running it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sit back and enjoy it when the players are talking strategies among one another. It means they're fully engaged in what is going on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep an initiative order even if the party is split. It helps ensure you're giving each character enough time in the spotlight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Telepathic villains are a great way to torment the characters anywhere they happen to be.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the players break the game with particularly good combinations of powers or abilities. Don't let that particular game breaking quality become the new norm.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Insert roleplaying into combat. Villains love to banter with their enemies during a fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even the walls in a dungeon tell a story. What do yours tell?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The limitless depth of an Abolith's memories are a fantastic way to bring ancient histories to the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What character options make your campaign interesting? What makes your campaign unique for them?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Foreshadow dangers in dungeons with smells and feelings.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the story unfold at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A single charm person can subvert a battle against one hundred foes. And that's awesome.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Acererak has a lot on his mind. He might miss the small detail of his succubus lawyer getting charmed by the bard.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Acererak doesn't hate the characters. He doesn't think about them at all. They are insects hardly worthy of the neurons to consider (does Acererak have neurons?)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before you shut down a player's bullshit tactic, is it actually an awesome turn in the story?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players what they are and are not comfortable with in the game during your session zero. Pay attention to body language during the game as well; you might have missed something.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let go of your pre-definition of a scene. Combat can become roleplay, roleplay can become investigation, investigation can become combat. Create a situation and let the players define their interaction with it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Work with the players whenever it helps move the story forward. They don't always need to roll a skill check to succeed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players negotiate out of potential combat. Not every conflict requires a fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Worry less about the tactics and focus on the players' intent. What do they want to do with those eight summoned constrictor snakes? Focus on that.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fewer players give you more of an opportunity to let those characters shine. Try to aim for four or five PCs when you're able.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Simple adventures are just fine. Don't worry about including a lot of twists and turns. Sometimes a straight forward but flavorful adventure is all players desire.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if they can't do anything with it, finding a 10,000 gp gem in the bottom of a killer dungeon is fun. Tangible rewards matter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try to reward one meaningful magical item to each character every four levels or so. It doesn't need to be perfectly systematic but that's about the right overall pace.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Address the characters, not the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe fantastic locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find a way to help characters shine even if the dice are against them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let characters stray away from what you've prepared if it makes sense in the story. Prepare to let them wander.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Display maps and artwork on tablets to show the players what's going on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: High skill checks don't just show them what they can do but what they certainly can't do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie magic items to the story of the adventure and location. Why is it here?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let characters spend time figuring out puzzles. If they're all engaged, the game is going well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remove extranous combat. Maybe the goblins were killed by something else wandering around the dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: One need not run gridded combat in Roll 20. General positioning on a cool background can work for quick combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes it's fun when a monster is down to a single hit point. Sometimes it's better to round down.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Vivid descriptions of high action help ensure that theater of the mind combat doesn't feel stale and static. Focus on the fiction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have some cool maps? Use them as inspiration for your fantastic locations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Building a huge campaign? Consider focusing first on the characters and their immediate surroundings.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Your next game matters the most.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Huge epic miniatures work well as centerpiece statues, monuments, or displays in low level games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did a character leave the story and then return? Bring the player in to fill in what happened.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Foreshadowing can come in many guises. Faded images on the wall, haunted dreams, the curious look of a stranger. Everything can be a message.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare enough to feel comfortable letting the characters explore the dungeon however they choose.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Modify a published encounter to fit the most enjoyable pacing of the game. Make it easier or harder to fit the current atmosphere at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes you'll want the most elaborate battle environment you can  build. Other times a circle on a piece of paper is all you need.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin spells to fit the flavor of the casters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep musical playlists for suspense, relaxed, and combat scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend the time to prepare big boss fights. We can improvise a lot of our game but boss fights require careful planning.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build solid mechanics in your boss fights and include gauges you can turn to raise or lower the threat as needed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Do your traps and puzzles make logical sense or do they simply require random selections to pass them?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What does your villain want? What are they doing to try to get it?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What makes your town or village fantastic? What features does it have that sets it apart and grabs the attention of the players?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always be learning.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stay in the fiction. Describe what's happening in the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Never forget that the characters are the heroes of your story. Your universe revolves around them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What drives the characters to dive into your adventure? Why do they care? What do they want?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remind players to leave gaps in their backstories so they can grow into their characters as the adventures move onward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Easy hacks for the fantastic: go big and go old.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mash the defining traits of one stat block with another to build something completely unique. Ghoul assassin! Stone giant lich! Goblin veteran! Pick one for base stats and steal defining traits from another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Beholders likely have large physical minions who punch the concentration out of spellcasters while they're within the antimagic cone. Helmed Horrors and Shield Guardians would be particularly nasty against invisible opponents.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay special attention to preparing boss battles. They're not like other encounters. Add dials to change the pacing and difficulty while running the encounter at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Evolve! Take in new experiences and ideas and nudge your DMing style in new directions. Don't throw out the past and don't let the past close you off to new ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plant seeds early on in an adventure so confrontations with boss battles aren't just straight-up fights. What do the characters possess that the villains greatly desire?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As you close in on the end of a campaign, ask the players what remains in their characters' arcs that have yet to be resolved.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: As a campaign ends, ask the characters where their characters have gone and what they've done one year later. Write it down and email it around as a remembrance.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's ok to have a planned end to a campaign. Let the players' imaginations fill in the future of their characters after it closes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't negate a character's big special ability. Let them enjoy their broken power in monumental scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When the characters have tough choices ahead, make it clear what those choices are. Don't let them get steered too far away from success or it can get frustrating.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Gauge your players' tolerance for character deaths. Do they like it? Do they hate it? You'll only really know when it happens but keep an eye out for it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go easy on first level characters. Watch the damage the monsters do carefully. Ignore instant death if you want to be nice to new players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep meaningful NPCs down to about three in any given adventure. Too many and players lose track of them too easily.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Challenge rating is one way to get a general gage of a monster's actual challenge but its hit points and damage output are also important to consider.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Your most important session is your next one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build layers in your locations. What is it now? What did it used to be?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understand and reinforce the themes in your campaign. Describe them in your session zero to ensure your players are on board. Is it dark fantasy? Urban intrigue? Jungle exploration? What defines the theme?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes all you need are two ogres in the woods to see how your players want to interact with the world. Will they attack them? Will they trick them? Will they sneak around them? Will they listen to them? Leave the approach open and build situations instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stopping the dark ritual at the end of a campaign is a poor motivation. Gathering the items to contain the result is a more interesting goal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to read about the lore of a character's background or origin. Are they elvish? Read the lore about the Fey. Do they have a connection to the Shadowfell? Read about the history of Shadar-Kai.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stringing characters along the quest to acquire an item they cannot attain can be demotivating and frustrating. Instead, let them gather clues to understand and face the perils ahead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In early levels, pay particular attention to the damage monsters inflict. It can surprise you how quickly a low level character can go from full hit points to zero.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dreams and visions are a fantastic way to foreshadow events happening later in the game. They can introduce villains. They can answer questions. They can make the ethereal true.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need inspiration to draw your players into the action of the game? Review the skill list in chapter 7 of the Player's Handbook and see all of the things they can do with skills.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make sure your players are on board with the theme of your campaign. It's worth a series of conversations even before your session zero.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know the structure of your short campaign. You don't have to fill in all the details but a general outline helps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What interesting magic items might your characters discover in your next adventure?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to give powerful single-use magic items. They can add some chaotic fun without completely breaking an entire campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Oscillate between easy and hard battles to change up the beats in your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't kill off NPCs just to get an emotional reaction out of your players. You can put them in danger and the situation may kill them but don't force the conclusion.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The night of or the morning after your game, spend ten minutes writing down what happened in the last session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some moments in the game will surprise everyone at the table, including you. Let them happen. These are the surprises everyone will remember long after the campaign is over.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build story ideas from old mythological folklore. Seek out Celtic, Greek, African, Native American, Chinese, Middle Eastern, and Authorian legends.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put in longer moments of rest in between adventures. Ask what the characters did in between these sessions. Let players develop their characters so you and the rest of the players can understand them better.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a structure around your game that you and your players understand. The characters must seek four breakers-magical artifacts capable of destroying the four anchors that bring the Demon Lord to Urth.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good campaign arcs have a single sentence that defines them. Even if the world is wide hope, the players and characters understand their overall goal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build one fantastic location for every 30 to 45 minutes of expected gameplay. What is it called? What three aspects does it have that will interest the characters?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build out what the characters will see and what is just over the horizon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the characters at the center of your game prep.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Delegate rules responsibility to your players. You need not carry that burden by yourself.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Break canon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Absorb great fiction and use it to build the texture in your own game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understand and reinforce the theme of your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a sharpie and mark the rules in your book that have been updated with errata. Fear not writing in your books. Remember the potions book of the Half-Blood Prince.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the mythology of your world?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill your mind with the words and images of the fantastic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try out a short campaign in which the characters level every session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Shrink your aperture.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave loose ends loose.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch their body language.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Attack with a horde.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reduce your tools.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Simplify.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Attack in waves.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Deep caverns lie beneath every gnarled tree.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build on the bones of dead gods.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Cut off passages and chambers in a dungeon on the fly if it better fits the timing and pacing of the adventure you're running.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take the time to select or build intersting magic items. They matter a lot to your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Balance lore and action. Don't just tell them stuff, let them discover it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Look to the DM's Guild for interesting playtested character options that fit the theme of your campaign. Players would love to expand beyond the PhB.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Crosstrain with other RPGs. Pick up tips from these other RPGs. What are your favorites?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the players fill in the timeline gaps in your stories with their own descriptions of their character's time off screen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the story shift direction based on what the players remember and focus their attention on. What do they care about?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of spending a lot of time building a custom monster, reskin an existing one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking for an interesting variant of a monster, like a wererat assassin? Stick to the normal assassin stat block and reflavor it as a wererat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure your dungeon design makes sense for the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure there's a purpose for a puzzle room. Most lichs likely don't build rooms just to challenge adventurers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Worry less about designing a location and its inhabitants around the current power level of the characters. Give them one that makes sense given the current story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Rule number one for running narrative combat: Help characters succeed with their intent.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The general flow of narrative "theater of the mind" combat: describe the environment and situation, ask the player for their desire and intent, adjudicate the results favoring the character. Repeat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let monsters act in a non-optimized way if the pace of battle calls for it. Just because a bully wig can swim doesn't mean players want to chase it for six rounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Above all, stay on time. Watch your time throughout the whole adventure. Let players end on a high note. Don't "call it right here".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Its perfectly fine to play sub-optimally for the fun of the story and the pace of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe what the characters are seeing or what is happening to them before asking for a roll. Ask that players likewise describe their actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There's a fine line between a challenging fight and an annoying one. Keep a careful eye on it so you don't cross it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Work with your players, not against them. Help them succeed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get as close to you can to asking "what do you do?" Give players options often.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just like campaigns, individual adventures can have an overall theme. Paint your adventure from this theme.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's ok to throw in vorpal swords into a short campaign. Even if it's overpowered, it won't be around forever.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Gauge your players' tolerance for gore. Talk to them about it before you let the blood fly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time to find interesting monsters to drop into your next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend less time finding the perfect monster and go with one that's good enough.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Flavor standard monsters with new weapons, interesting traits, notable appearances, new attacks, and dangerous spells.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mash two dungeon maps together to come up with something new and unique.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a handful of standard maps on hand so you can quickly drop a dungeon into an improvised adventure. Don't have too many in your kit or you'll be paralized by indecision.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give yourself ample time to include a nice big boss fight at the end of your single-session adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Flavor the details of your location with historical statues, frescoes, and other markings that expand the history of your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up scenes with opportunities for roleplaying, exploration and combat. Consider multiple solutions to each scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up monster difficulties and quantities. Include some encounters with lots of little guys, some with a few big ones, and some with both!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lower the hit points of monsters to speed up battles when they get boring or tedious.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Increase the damage of monsters to make them scarier and increase the tension.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bathe locations in iconic imagery. A collapsed building that seemed to form a giant screaming skull. A twisted tower that looks like a single finger pointing up to a dead sky. A deep pit that looks like a seeping wound in the earth.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce villains early and keep them present, even if just in rumor or the aftermath of their crossing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe world-changing events that may take place off screen to give the players a view of a living world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stuck for inspiration? Start with five to seven fantastic locations and see what ideas they bring to you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about the situation of a location. What would happen there if the characters didn't show up?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A boss arriving later in a battle is a good way to avoid them getting alpha-striked in round one of a battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Inflicting damage when hit is a great way to scale threat with the number of characters. An ancient red dragon with fireshield is a truly deadly experience.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters glimpses of a villain's alternate plans. What if they're planning to escape the world if their sinister plot fails?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Improvise the actions and reactions of the characters as though they're balls on a pool table. Who can say where they're going to go until they start moving.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a few basic monsters at your current challenge level available to reskin when you need a creature you haven't thought of. Ogres and giants work particularly well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put the characters into hard situations that combat simply can't get them out of.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin spells to show off the background and theme of villainous NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Nothing is more stressful than a villainous garden party you can't simply burn down.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What can the villains offer the characters that will stay their hand?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Illusions that affect some characters but not others is a great way to add some inter-party suspense and fun roleplaying for your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Villains have all sorts of motivations. Some may not realize they're villains at all. What if an innocent person might cause the end of the world?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add your own folklore to your campaign. A black dagger might be a shard cut from the fabric of the night sky.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give yourself time to run boss battles. Expect them to take at least twice as long as a typical battle. Give them the bandwidth they deserve.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend the time to understand complicated boss monsters. Read over their stat block again and jot down notes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time to understand the capabilities of the characters. Talk to your players about the choices they've made for their character and what they hope to see them do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Email microfiction to keep the players playing the game even when they're not at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Email a campaign closer that talks about the state of the world six months after the characters finished the campaign. How has the world changed due to their heroic actions?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider dedicating an entire session to a big boss fight. Multiple waves, environmental changes, big set-piece dioramas; go big with your boss fights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review the characters' backgrounds each time you prepare. Give the characters a chance to shine with their background, not just their race or class.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start off with a bang. Get the characters into the action as soon as you can.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your characters a home base they can call their own. Give it to them early.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In the beginning of a campaign, let the players choose a faction or organization they all belong to already. Get them started already tied together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write up a one-page handout to help your players understand the campaign and their characters' place in the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get a feeling for whether your group prefers to fight it out or talk through situations. Give them more opportunities for the one they prefer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters a reason to interact with the scenery in a fantastic location. Why would they risk investigating the strange starscape-filled pool?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let characters navigate bottomless pits using reasonably safe ideas without requiring a skill check.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Smile. Laugh.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In complicated situations players are probably in trouble understanding what's going on about half the time. Keep this in mind and help them out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up situations. Let the players decide how to deal with them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run big battles in the background story. Focus on the skirmishes the characters deal with during the bigger wars.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Show art.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spread a thin layer of history and lore over the whole adventure. Let it be discovered through attribute checks and character backgrounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The world is built upon the ancient remains of a thousand civilizations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Respond to the decisions of the players as the world would respond to the actions of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend ten minutes before your game going over the characters. Who are they? What do they want? What do they like to do?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal bigger dungeons, particularly dungeon maps, from other published adventures if you're worried the characters will take a dungeon path you didn't expect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make sure the characters have something to do in each of the locations they might explore. Otherwise they'll just wander through.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reward curiosity.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use miniatures or tokens to show positioning. Who's up front? Who's in the back?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop in one interesting magic item into each session. If you're worried about imbalancing the game, make it a one-use item.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Move the spotlight to the NPCs the characters seem to like the best.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before you plan out your campaign, talk to your players and make sure its the sort of campaign people want to play. Do this even BEFORE a session zero (session negative one?)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Vary the types of monsters your characters face. Two or three battles of zombies in a row can get boring and repetitive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add or remove encounters to change up the pace of the game. Too many battles can be weary and too few can lose the action
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add magic items that fit the backgrounds and desires of the characters. Let's face it, Sting was made for Bilbo.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let confrontations go from verbal to physical and maybe back again. Don't expect or force a scene to go one way or the other. Let the players choose.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write a one-page campaign summary that focuses on the characters and their role in the campaign. Write it in the second person.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use hand torn crumpled copper resume paper to make cool in world  notes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your session zero relaxed and let your players know not to expect crazy powerhouse action. It's a time to get to know the characters and the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use downtime between adventures as a way for the players to get to know one another's characters. "What was your character up to over the past two tendays?" is a great way to learn more about a character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Nothing beats a body washing up on shore to start a mystery.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change the hooks in published adventures if the one in your head will grab your players more than the one in the book.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make vampires more dangerous by increasing their life draining bite to 21 (6d6) necrotic damage and requiring Greater Restoration to restore the drained hit points.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend time learning how to draw cool maps. Regional, dungeon, and battle maps are a great way to draw your players visually into the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change the weather.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Zombies that explode like fireballs when they finally die.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Block and schedule some time in your week to spend real time preparing for your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Award inspiration to reward risk taking that moves the story forward. Putting your head into a well full of poisonous snakes? You get inspiration!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Level one is its own special game. It's far more dangerous and lethal than any other level in the game. Treat it accordingly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep an eye on the damage output of a monster. It may swing harder or softer than the challenge rating indicates.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop hints of interesting things the characters might otherwise miss. Strange thudding noises in the attic, strange glowing shining reflections in the mud at the bottom of the well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie the PCs' backgrounds to future adventures. Maybe one of the characters sailed on the ship that sunk the pirate vessel Tammeraut.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build handouts to draw players into the world. Strange fonts on copper-colored resume paper with torn edges works well.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build two layers of deception into your villains. The first one discovered covers up the second.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review the material on the DM screen every so often to refresh you on the tools you have right in front of you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep track of character hit points so you can get a more accurate gauge of monster difficulty.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add accessories and details to your terrain builds. The details make it come alive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use larger encounter areas with a few rooms. Monsters can come from many sides and the characters might need to split up to keep them at bay.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When a horde of monsters attack the characters you can assume about 1/4 of them will hit. Edge up and down depending on big differences in AC.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even if you only have ten minutes to prepare for your game, spend those ten minutes on the most important elements of your game prep: Who are the characters? Where will it start? What secrets and clues might they discover?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even rot grub swarms have interesting physical characteristics that separate them from other rot grub swarms (little mohawks, spiral stripes, ugly spots).
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even in open sandbox scenarios, it helps to clarify what the characters can and can't do. Give some guidelines so they're not completely flailing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are the players smiling? You're doing it right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When putting a big scenario in front of your players, like infiltrating a villa or invading a pirate ship, take the time to understand all of the variables. How will the NPCs act? Where are they going? What do they want?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify when the characters have exhausted all the information they're going to get in a scene. "You're pretty sure you've learned everything you can here."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the players discover the number of enemies they're likely to face in a big dynamic area. How many hill giants can they expect to find in the steading of the hill giant chief?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes skill checks go so catastrophically wrong that it shakes up the whole world. A simple attempted distraction might capsize an entire ship.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Help guide the players' discussion of their plans for an infiltration or ruse. Steer the conversation towards what will likely work, away from what won't, and towards what will bring the most fun for the group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hide your secret villains from the characters and leave clues of their existence and their impact on the surrounding world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In any open situation offer three plausable paths plus any the players come up with themselves.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are the villains in a hard situation? What would you do in their shoes? Sometimes a pirate captain will scuttle their own ship if it means their own survival and killing the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In "breather episodes" in which the characters return to town, let the players know its coming ahead of time and offer options for downtime activities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change out boss monsters based on the backgrounds of the characters. Is a character hunting a black ship-eating whale that ate her parents? Get that sucker into the adventure!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Foreshadow future adventures with quest hooks and rumors the characters hear about around town.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read one or two chapters ahead in any big campaign adventure you're currently running. Read up the next session within a day of running it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep small add-in encounters to add in when things go quicker than expected in your planned adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Expose multiple paths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave options open for dialog even after combat has begun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have quest givers offer multiple quests and let the players choose the ones they want.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify objectives.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Increase the legendary actions, hit points, and damage of legendary monsters for each character above four.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Show maps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In combat, think about how your monsters would act given the current situation. Would they run? Would they stay and fight? Would they surrender?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up big set-piece encounter areas and leave open lots of potential options. Let the characters approach the situation how they will.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Allow for encounters with lots of enemies who act sub-optimally. Sure, there are more than a dozen bullywugs but they're clearly not coordinated.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End with a cliffhanger and give yourself a built-in strong start next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before running any monster, give its lore section in the monster manual a read and see if it fires up any ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Perhaps a malenti, a sahuagin spy and assassin who appears as a sea elf, has infiltrated the local lizardfolk lair as a false ambassador with plans to assassinate the queen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A gelatinous cube with a single-use magical relic floating inside is its own encapsulated D&D adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A few miniatures on the table just to show general positioning can help players better understand how a battle is going.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understand how the action economy affects combat difficulty. The number of actions on each side compared to the ither matters a lot. Four on four is much more balanced than one on four.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the number of items you need to run a game small. Only keep what you need.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Award inspiration for creative and detailed descriptions of the previous game session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the NPCs the characters might want to visit in a downtime scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add rumors to your secrets and clues. You never know what you might learn when hanging around down at the docks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What plot is your secret villain hatching right now?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use strange, wondrous, and horrible descriptions to change up common monsters. There are infinite notable variants of the common swarm of insects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The age of wood and stone has a story to tell.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Switch out villains for ones who have a clear connection to the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In combat, the side with more actions has a big advantage over the side with fewer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A single monster is roughly equivalent to a single character when it's CR is a quarter of the character's level below level 5 or half the character's level if above level 5.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Foreshadow your adventures with sinister weather or the attitudes of the crowds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run small experiments.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your descriptions in the fiction. Don't describe mechanics, describe the story behind them. "You take 8 damage" becomes "The orc's greatsword slashes across your thigh leaving a weeping wound. You take 8 damage."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 500 word bits of flash fiction is a great way to give the characters a glimpse of what happened before. Ship's logs, letters, journals; give them a small taste of the larger story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In longer mysteries, hold back incriminating evidence until it's time for the discovery.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The warlock's relationship with their patron is a complex one. It can be just as antagonistic as the strength of its bond. Warlocks are not slaves to their patrons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful turning a liked or beloved NPC into a secret villain. Your players may be committed to them and the betrayal might break them out of the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin spells to give villains particularly unique abilities and effects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You need little more than the core books, an adventure, and some dice to run a great D&D game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask what the characters can do in any given narrative scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Model NPCs after interesting characters in books, movies, or TV shows; then change their genders.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are 5th-10th level characters getting attacked by fifty skeletons? Assume one quarter of the skeletons will hit their targets or make their saving throws.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sinister and secret plots sometimes are so secret that the characters never discover them. Expose them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even smart villains make mistakes and reveal too much of their hand. Even powerful villains sometimes have horrible luck.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Throw in a random conversational NPC if you find you're having too many battles in a row. The characters sometimes need someone to talk to.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: There's always another cult.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review the players' character sheets, not to circumvent their abiltiies but to spotlight their specialities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Game time starting in ten minutes and you have nothing prepared? Steal a map, write out a strong start, and write down ten secrets and clues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters a reason to talk to NPCs and vice versa.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reveal the wider world through ancient relics, statues, tapestries, scraps of old books, and other elements of ancient history.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Layer your cultists. What secret does the inner circle keep from the outer circle? What's dark secret lies below the four elemental cults?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a collection of good maps handy. Every old tree has a dungeon below it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to the players who, through bad luck, roll low or get hit all the time. Give them a boost somewhere else in the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the environment as a tool to tell the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Discern intent
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix good things with bad things in your dungeons. Mix in healing fonts, blessing statues, and powerful relics with your acid-bolos, psychic razor-wire, and ethereal javelins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What is the larger story going on in your dungeon?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop in secrets in clues into dungeon crawls so the characters learn the story while navigating the dangers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Include interesting NPCs in your dungeon crawl such as ghosts, intelligent items, lost explorers, or enemy turncoats.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Telegraph to the players when they'll likely be in a resource-draining dungeon with little to no chance for a rest for some time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop in a sentient weapon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drape environments with lore.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Note player interests from downtime scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Move the enemy's plans forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Move things forward in towns while the characters are away.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure everyone gets a chance to describe their actions in downtime scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Did someone die and get immediately revified? How many years did they experience in limbo in the seconds that passed in the world?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make common monsters interesting by shaking up their appearances, weapons, armor, and your descriptions of their attacks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What does that skeleton smell like? What do its fingers feel like when their ragged ends scrape the character's skin? What drips from their open dead mouths?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put something in the hand of your NPC.  Spinning knives, twirling moonlight, cats cradle; anything.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A friendly priest casts "aid" on your 1st level party before they begin their adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Highlight three meaningful options for infiltrating the enemies' fortress.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Assume the adventurers are smart, capable, and observant. Clarify what they might see that the players might not realize.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players have trouble understanding what your describing about half the time. Be patient and clarify.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters leeway on infiltration missions. The whole dungeon shouldn't come down on the group for a single failed stealth check.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bathe dungeons in interesting iconography.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change up the number and types of monsters based on the best forward pace of the adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid awarding similar magic items. Give them something new and cool.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie sentient weapon origins to the backgrounds of the character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run adventures twice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Include juicy set-piece battles roughly every other session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read over your players' character sheets and come up with interesting hooks to draw them into the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customize monsters with weapons armor and traits from other monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about the histories of your characters and their families while considering the history of your world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sink your adventure hooks deep.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce shady NPCs that can't simply be killed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Inspire yourself with cool maps and art.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When running with three or fewer players, tailor the story of the adventure around those characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Simplify.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write for the players at your table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use existing stat blocks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus more on the story and less on the mechanics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When a character counterspells your big boss's big spell, let them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put yourself in the mind of your monsters; how would they behave?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix monster traits to fit a special creatures unique story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customize monsters with flavor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend less time on Twitter and more time reading your source books.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe enemy spells by the components they use. Let the players guess what they're casting or use Xanathar's rules for identifying spells.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Save time and money by using a dry-erase marker and a flip mat to draw monsters. Get cool hero minis for the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer multiple options for the characters in a big assault. Will they protect the gates? Will they stop the sewer infiltrators? Will they hunt down the assassins?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Are your monsters getting beaten down too quickly? Give the survivors more actions to account for their dead fellows.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: More monsters pose a greater challenge than bigger monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just getting started with D&D? Start with the inexpensive Starter set and the adventure Lost Mine of Phandelver.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe even common monsters with the details and flavor that make them unique to the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Shake up the weapons and monsters of humanoids to make them different and exciting.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Enemy NPCs can dual wield even if its not in the stat block.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe what's happening in the story instead of the details of the mechanics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Provoke opportunity attacks. Players love a free hit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your adventures simple. Let them get complicated when the characters smash up against them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take some time to research the history and lore (or write it yourself) for the areas immediately surrounding the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepares to shrink your dungeon to its most interesting rooms if time and pacing demand it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the players plan a strategy but move things forward if the planning starts to get stale or boring.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tweak monster hit points and damage to suit the upward or downward beat of the scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Smile. Laugh. Have fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Negotiate. Offer deals.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Areas of effect can almost always be manipulated to hit a single target. Adjudicate those situations fast and easily.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review your players character sheets. Show off their strengths and note their limitations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid denial fights. Players want their characters to do stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about matching challenge ratings to character levels. A hundred goblins is an awesome fight against a group of 8th level characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use advantage and disadvantage as easy mechanics for improvised terrain features.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run combat fast and with a focus on the in-world story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fall into the fantasy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on the big picture.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep note of who enjoys political intrigue and who prefers more straight forward adventuring. Season to taste.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Recap the cinematics of the previous rounds of combat. (Thanks @JoeManganiello!)
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know when to stay behind the curtain and when to pull it back. Only pull it back if it brings delight to the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When in doubt, lean towards revealing too much.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Feel free to announce ACs, DCs, and legendary monster status.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskinning is the most powerful of a DM's tools. Skim off of the inertia of others.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start with a combat to get the players' energy up.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep monologues short and sweet. Get to the point.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good villains think what they're doing is right. Great villains might actually BE right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't assume a conversation won't turn into a fight or a fight might turn into a conversation. Let the pillars bleed together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep some action-packed encounters on hand up the pacing when required.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Characters, and players, want to do stuff. Make things happen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Develop a menu of options for downtime scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players describe and upgrade their lair, home, tavern, or ship.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal cities, steal worlds, steal universes, steal the gods themselves!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a menu of downtime activities tailored for the characters and their interests.

text: #dnd tip: What hook will draw the characters into the adventure?

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Facetime or Hangouts is a great way for an absent player to still play.

text: #dnd tip: Keep a long playlist of sinister video game music playing in the background.

text: #dnd tip: Don't judge your games by what you see on the net. Learn from them but remember, you're doing great.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you have players fooled into thinking you're a good DM, you're a good DM.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players an overview of the structure of the city when running big city adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a solid list of random events taking places in big cities to give them continual activity and flavor.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start your city-based adventures with a big event; a contest, a riot, or a religious festival brings the city to life.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Of your three villains or factions, have one that requires no big moral choice to beat the snot out of.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every inn, university, or noble house might have an old forgotten dungeon underneath full of dangers and adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus your city-based adventures on a particular region or neighborhood.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your characters an early headquarters in city-based adventures. Perhaps they hang out in the room above an old inn, a old pawn shop, a tea house, or a gambling hall.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every outhouse has a gray ooze lurking in the bottom. Sometimes its an otyugh. Sometimes its a purple worm.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Even in dungeon delves, ensure there are opportunities for exploration, roleplaying, and combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Two groups seeking the same item is a great way to complicate and otherwise static dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the characters learn about the world through discoveries in ancient crypts, frescoes on ruined temple walls, and strange tattoos on their assailants.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your default levels of sex and violence to PG-13. Think Raiders of the Lost Ark.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Borrow liberally from other RPG products and stick their best pieces into your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Want to turn a legendary monster into a normal monster? Ignore legendary resistance, legendary actions, and lair actions. Give it an extra attack on its attack action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare one scene for every 30 minutes of gameplay.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When playing remote, check in oftem with your players to see how they're feeling about the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review your players' character sheets. Spotlight their strengths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Which movies feed the theme of your campaign?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Play to your campaign world's strengths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What song or album is the theme to your adventure or campaign?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your players a home base. Let them customize it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw players back into the game by asking for skill checks to reveal details about the situation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the players go shopping before a big party or social event. Ask them how their character prepares for the event.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When developing situations, review the character sheets to ensure you have the right hooks to draw in each character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Warn characters when it looks like they're about to bite off more than they can chew. The players may not be getting the more subtle warning signs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Help your players out. They're probably lost about half the time.
author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Some monsters are perfectly suited for particular jobs. A mimic spy? Why not!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up the situation and steer it towards the fun.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steer towards the action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know the characters' skills. Set up situations that fit them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Shift the game continually through the three pillars: combat, exploration, and roleplaying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "What does that look like?" is a great question to draw players into the fiction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set things on fire.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players forewarning of a coming downtime scene and potential options the characters can follow.

text: #dnd tip: Draw secrets and clues from the intersection of character backgrounds and the lore of the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start strong with an action packed battle against weaker foes to build up the energy of the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know and broadcast regularly what makes your world unique among worlds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a simple visual to show the general positioning of combatants even when running theater of the mind combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep theater of the mind battles simple and straight forward. Focus on the big stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know clearly what drives the characters through the story. Why are they doing what they're doing?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Why will your players care about the upcoming story arc and big reveals?

text: #dnd tip: Ensure each scene in your game has lots of opportunities for the characters to act.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be grand in visuals and specific in details.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal from fiction and mash ideas together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always be ready to grab what the characters bring to the story and wire it into the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer three plausible options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reward with tangible benefits.
author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary of 1st level published adventures. They're often unexpectedly deadly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What ten fantastic features will the characters find in your next dungeon?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure the characters have things they can do in any given scene. This isn't a movie.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus your narration on the most important information in any given scene.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the proficient skills of each character. Tug on those skills to bring the characters into the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember that players are grasping about half of what you're describing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build situations and let the players choose their approach.
author: Michael E. Shea

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a backup communication tool if your main one fails during your online game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players options for roleplaying, exploration, or combat when entering into adventure situations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players to customize and define their pets, companions, and figurines of wondrous power.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If players struggle with plans; restate the goal, clarify the options, let them in on details they may have missed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Chasing a single spy through city streets can be as exciting as a big battle against dangerous foes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw out locations, even if it's just for you, to help them solidify from your fuzzy brain into a real place.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Things going slow? Blow something up!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Powerful and dangerous magic items are wonderful vehicles for the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reflavor standard magic items.

text: #dnd tip: Two villainous groups seeking the same item in the same dungeon as the characters is a great way to make the whole dungeon come alive.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put something interesting in every room.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stuck for inspiration? Write down ten things for your game. Secrets, locations, hooks, villains, items and so on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write out custom downtime activities for each character based on their own interests and backgrounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes a silly encounter can break up the continual grim nature of most encounters. Use them as a break.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Try new tools but don't fool yourself into overweighting their importance in preparing and running a great game. A stack of 3x5 cards can go a long way.

text: #dnd tip: Use the tools that you love and that get you excited to prep and play.

text: #dnd tip: Strong starts can be good or bad. It may be a parade or it may be a crashing airship full of ghouls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always be ready to drop in an interesting conversational NPC into your dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the players enough information to make more meaningful choices than left or right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the tools that keep you and your players focused on the transpiring story.

text: #dnd tip: Inspire yourself with art.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The main DM mechanic: choose a DC between 10 and 20.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What can the characters do in every scene?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the tables from chapters 3, 5, and Appendix A of the Dungeon Master's Guide to inspire adventure ideas you can drop in front of the characters and see what types of adventures they want to go on. Build your own job board.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The DM doesn't tell the story. The DM facilitates the story that happens at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure your battles don't continually favor one type of character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seek inspiration from everywhere.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build characters together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the basics in mind: a quest, a location, some monsters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have one scene in hand for every 45 minutes of gameplay.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build situations and let the characters navigate them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Improvise encounters based on the situation and evolving circumstances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change dungeon configurations to fit the pacing and timing of your adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dial back the urgency and let the players choose what they want to do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Provide three meaningful options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Protect your delicate villains. Players love to pin them down and kill them first.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Waves of combatants is a great way to put the pressure on the characters without overwhelming them completely.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Working off-camera is the easiest way for a villain to screw with the characters and not get instantly killed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What the villains would reasonably do may not be what's most fun for the group. Just as "that's what my character would do" is a BS excuse for players, "that's what my villains would do" iSs a B excuse for DMs. A bad time is a bad time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't force a story angle to happen if the characters can thwart it. Let the thwarting occur and figure out what would happen next.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Hordes of monsters don't all act in a well coordinated battle. Some get scared, some run in fearlessly, some act smartly. Get into their heads and act as they would act.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask for stars and wishes. What did the players love in the previous game? What do they want more of in future games?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary of taking away the characters' stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your descriptions brief and fantastic.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Sometimes even dead villains have laid careful traps and plots for the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Villains need not be strong in combat. Perhaps a single blow would fell them. It's the monsters and obstacles they've put in the way that cause trouble.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Things getting complicated? Default back to an old fashioned dungeon romp.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop the dungeons from Princes of the Apocalypse beneath any big town or city.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use minis and maps to draw the players into the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A quick list of who is next to who in what area may be all you need to articulate combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Characters above 5th level? Bring on the pain!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Do your characters counterspell? Change how you describe enemy spellcasting to give them time to respond.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give cool magic weapons. Don't be stingy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep one scene for every 30 to 45 minutes of gameplay.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Aim for six regular players and be willing to run with as few as three.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Aim for a regular day and time every week or two. Try hard to run at that time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use your favorite image editor (Preview, MS Paint, whatever) to quickly annotate @DysonLogos maps with evocative descriptions for your D&D game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build quests and adventures from the backgrounds and drives of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Rescuing people being attacked is a good way to get characters into the adventure without having them continually beset upon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: failed Athletics check? Describe the searing pain that rips down from the side of one's neck to their lower back. A pain that will twinge them awake for three nights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When improvising scenes or situations, ask yourself what makes sense given the current situation. What would be in those sewers? How would the bad guys prepare ahead of time? What makes sense?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's common for DMs is to feel unprepared and nervous before the game and feel awesome during and afterwards. No matter how long you've been running games, that nervousness is always there. It'll be fine.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run published adventures months after their release and capitalize off of the shared experiences of hundreds of other DMs who jumped on it early.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End early. Keep your players hungry for more.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful with majority-led choices. Check in with those who haven't spoken up before choosing the path of those who have.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build out cool locations for big boss battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give yourself dials to tune battles as they happen. Tweak damage, hit points, number of attacks, spells, and number of combatants when running potentially deadly encounters.

#dnd tip: Need quick monster or NPC stats? Choose a challenge rating:

AC / DC = 12 + 1/2 CR
Attack and primary saves = 3 + 1/2 CR
HP = 15 + 15 x CR
Damage = 5 + 5 x CR

Tweak to suit individual particularities.
