text: #dnd tip: Don't drop all of the big story reveals at once. Space the out so players have time to digest and enjoy them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: How do the villains relate to the characters?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give major villains a spokesperson. Antlers the Killer Moose has Thumper, the shit-talking hare.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan for multiple possible outcomes in any given situation. Ideally, plan no particular outcome at all.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters a home base with a unique fantatic feature.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Warn players ahead of time of the potential for downtime so the can plan their actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customize a published campaign adventure by tying it to the characters, their backgrounds, and their goals.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End at the beginning of a huge battle to build a strong start for your next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choose magic items both randomly and from those that make sense for the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your villains access to magic items that will soon fall in the hands of the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Potions and scrolls are a great way to beef up a villain.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Characters having an easy time? Treat them as one level higher when calculating potentially deadly encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When in doubt, run a dungeon full of cultists. Everyone loves cultists.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up situations and let the players choose how their characters navigate them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer three options + any others they come up with.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of quest and adventure templates that work well in a variety of situations. Kill the boss; steal the MacGuffin; rescue the prince; stop the ritual; etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Look for the spaces in published adventures where you can stick in your own ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build your physical and mental toolkit to help you facilitate the stories that bloom at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End on cliffhangers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add secret doors, secret passages, loops, and short cuts to you dungeon maps or seek those maps that have them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare and be ready to drop in easy battles, hard battles, interesting discoveries, and interesting NPCs into your dungeon crawls.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drive narration from the points of view, backgrounds, and skills of the characters. Avoid passive voice narrrations. Let the characters discover the world around them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give weak monsters circumstantial advantages when facing high-level characters. Cultists can drink demonic blood to give them advantage and extra necrotic damage before exploding into demons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give bosses access to powerful potions, scrolls, and other single-use magic items.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Advantage, disadvantage, inspiration, and the sliding scale of DCs are your tools for improvising just about any situation in D&D.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down ten things you learned after running any given session of D&D.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lean in to the unexpected.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep simple adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add elements of roleplaying, exploration, and discovery inside your long multi-stage battes. You can run an entire D&D game within the bounds of a big battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Breathe deep. Your game will be fine.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What did each of your players love in your last game? What do they want to see in the future? Ask them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Adventures serve as inspiration and frameworks for the stories you and your players to share at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run simple adventures. Your players will make them complicated.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep potential quest to around three. Enough to have meaningful choices but not too many to cause decision paralysis.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every few sessions ask players what they're enjoying about the campaign and what they'd like to see in future sessions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build your world and campaign from the characters outward. Build for your next couple of adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review your characters first and build in secrets, NPCs, and locations meaningful to those characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Secrets and clues are the treasure and rewards for exploration and discovery.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure your players are on board with the theme and structure of your adventure, whether it's an open sandbox or a story-driven campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the published material that excites you and looks like the most fun to use.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add elements of exploration, discovery, and roleplaying into your huge boss battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Steal great ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let characters shine.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mash ideas together.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players time to consider their options for downtime scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop fantastic locations and monuments along long overland journeys.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players to describe their killing blow.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Turn killing blows into decisive blows that give defeated bosses an opportunity to negotiate or offer interesting secrets.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put the characters in hard situations and work with them to escape.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bathe the world in texture and details.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put options in front of the players near the end of your game so you know what to prep next.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie environmental effects from Tasha's Cauldron of Everything to fantastic monuments the heroes come across in the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid story-driven thefts the character's can't stop. Give them a chance to stop the theft or chase down the stolen goods.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the villians and minions operate as they would in the world, with the information and capabilities they have. Run them like living people, even in the background.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Little is more fun than two brash bandits who overestimate their chances.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build situations, describe options, reiterate the goal.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Highlight the fantastic accomplishments of the heroes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use heralds that build up the villains for the characters. Sometimes they'll be the most hated NPCs in the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down a strong start, three to five fantastic locations, and ten secrets the characters might discover and you're all set.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use critical hits and critical misses as ways to push new directions into the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask specific players for their thoughts on potential options when the group faces multiple paths.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When desired, give monsters additional attacks when facing a group of characters alone.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop an interesting location as the characters travel from one main place to another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use rough abstract maps and theater of the mind for smaller battles and more tactical combat for big boss fights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run with as few tools as you need to share an awesome story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a group of six players plus two "on call" players and be willing to play with as few as three. It takes six cancellations to not run a game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Captured enemies serve as easy vehicles for secrets and clues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop in single use magical relics with interesting connections to the world and its mysteries.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Develop an understanding for the offensive and defensive capabilities of the characters; it serves you better than encounter balance tools and tables.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add fantastic backdrops to your random encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Check in with players often to ensure the game and their character's role in it is going the direction they want it to go.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Shift between easy and challenging fights to the players enjoy the full range of their characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Suggest players build and level characters together to work towards complementary abilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Regularly reiterate the goals of the adventure or quest.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players understand half of what you're describing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary when taking away a player's agency from their character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reinforce that a character cannot adversely affect another character without their player's permission.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your boss a couple of big dumb brutes to give characters something to banish and otherwise crowd control and a big pile of weak monsters to blast to smitherines.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: One-on-one games are a fantastic way to focus a game around the story of a single character. It's a different, yet no less fun, way to play D&D.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What tools do you need to run a game? What gets in the way?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Whenever you have questions, dive back into the story and the NPCs in it. Think through their eyes. What would they do?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: At 11th level and above, a battle may be deadly if the sum total of monster challenge ratings is 3/4th the sum total of character levels. Or equal to the sum of character levels if they're 17th or above.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Save time by using existing maps instead of drawing your own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Adding monsters is the easiest way to make a fight more dangerous.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Highlight the important points of your narration and keep it brief and focused.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: 3x5 cards are the DM's secret weapon for preparing and running games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Save time by avoiding transcribing monster stat blocks. Bookmark your books or online pages instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: D&D Beyond, Discord, and Avrae together build an excellent online D&D platform.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: D&D is, first and foremost, a shared story with random variables. Build out from that core idea.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players to describe interesting physical characteristics of monsters beginning with the letter of the monster's token or in your D&D Beyond Encounter Builder roster.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players meaningful options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Handle NPC battles off-screen. Describe the results rather than roll dice against yourself.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run a new session zero as new players come into your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players time between sessions to consider their downtime activities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Random encounters need not be combat. Sometimes its a friendly merchant. Othertimes its an ancient white dragon swooping down on a yeti.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think big and fantasic with your locations and features. You have an unlimited special effects budget.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Seek books, comics, movies, TV shows, and games that push your imagination into wild new areas. Absorb everything and let it fuel your games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find and tie together the intersections between character backgrounds and the stories in a campaign. Is that villain a cousin? Are those prisoners from your village? Is that skeleton a former adventuring colleague?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run turns for downtime scenes for each character like you would for any other scene. Make sure every character gets to do something and doesn't take too much of the spotlight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Warn players ahead of time that you'll be including a downtime scene so they can prepare ahead of time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer custom downtime options tied to the characters and the story. Offer what you think they'd want to do.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use an abstract map or some loose visualization for hard fights against lots of monsters so players have a good idea what they face and how they face them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Work with the players' intent when running Theater of the Mind combat. What are they trying to do?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Monsters need not act optimally in every battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players the option to break out of debilitating status effects like Stun by taking damage to break free.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Before your game, spend a minute visualizing you and your friends at the table and ask what you need on hand to run the game. Write a checklist and grab those things before you run the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Things you may need to run your game: numbered initiative tents, character minis, monster minis or tokens, flip mat, 3x5 cards, dry erase markers, sharpies, list of random names, monster books, the DMG, the Lazy DMs Workbook.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let action-starved monsters fire off cool abilities as bonus actions or as part of their attack action so they have a chance to show off their unique characteristics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Copy and paste or highlight useful bits of lore from published material you can expose to the characters as secrets and clues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Interesting and useful lore is the reward for exploration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put yourself in the shoes of the NPC. See through their eyes. How would they act in the situation?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End on a cliffhanger and set up strong start at your next game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Delight in the successes of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lean towards revealing too much instead of revealing too little.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If a player seems disconnected from the current story, work with them to see how their character might have a deeper connection than either of you realized.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know when to drop in combat, roleplaying, or exploration based on the current pace of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bathe your adventures in the details of the world and its history.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What three villains currently weave their webs in the background of your campaign?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think through the eyes of your NPCs. How do you think they'll act or react?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The day after your game, think about how it went and jot down your own tips.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Check your list of secrets throughout the game to see what you can drop in where.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Copy and paste text from your published adventures and sourcebooks and format them as handouts you can give to your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choose monsters that make sense for the story and situation first and THEN figure out if the challenge meets your intent and the pacing of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put characters first.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep only what you need for your next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You get to choose what's canon at your table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read the monster manual.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Expose fantastic lore through secrets and clues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be a kid again.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Trade cynicism for wonder.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be brief in descriptions. Get to the action.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What can the characters do in the scene? What choices can they make?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build situations instead of outlines.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about how things work in the world before worrying about mechanics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use handouts to organize and focus your game for your players and for you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's better to end a session early than to end one late.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End a session after the characters have made a big decision about where to go next.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change published adventures to suit your players and characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend time understanding how your players enjoy the game. Are they looking for something relaxed and low key or looking for something brutal and hard core?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End your session right before a big battle and start strong at your next session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Monsters hitting below their weight class? Give them an extra attack or two.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build campaigns from the characters outward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For players, taking and sharing notes is a great way to avoid distractions and be even more useful to the rest of the group.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Short one on one games are a great way to get in some D&D in a short bit of time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Good cult fanatic tactics: round 1 spirit weapon and sacred flame, round 2 guiding bolt and spirit weapon attack, round 3 inflict wounds and spirit weapon attack.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reflavor a cult fanatics spells to fit the dark gods they follow.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer three choices for new quests and adventures. Prune the options that remain unchosen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run survival aspects of your game (food tracking, cold weather travel, encumbrance) as long as it's fun and handwave it when it becomes tedious and boring.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer fast travel options such as airships and portals when the world opens up to the characters at higher level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What are the three possible options the characters discover in the next game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Your tools and tricks for running great games are there to serve you. You don't owe them anything. Use what works. Modify to suit. Throw things away.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about the hooks the characters might have with an NPC you're going to introduce.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drawing maps may be fun but it isn't necessary. There are hoards of maps out there waiting for you to pilfer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Integrate new characters quickly through trust and companionship. Describe the heroic spark in their eyes and get quickly past initial distrust.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a toolbox in your head of tools and tricks that help you improvise your games at the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer customized character options for downtime scenes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run games and learn from them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer three interesting and meaningful choices.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Skip the boring parts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep an eye on mood, pacing, and beats. Adjust as needed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of locations, NPC's, monsters, and secrets on hand for each session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When using a virtual tabletop, speed up prep time by turning off the visual grid and turning off "snap to grid". Thus you can spend less time trying to line up imperfectly-aligned map.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the world from the eyes, capabilities, and backgrounds of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of locations is the backgrounds to a play. Give each location an evocative name and three interesting features.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Looking to add morale to your monsters? The DMG has you covered. Roll a DC 10 Wisdom saving thro when it makes sense for a monster to potentially flee.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Non-legendary boss monsters feeling action constrained? Give them an extra action they can take on their turn.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change the number and type of monsters in published adventures to suit the current pace and feeling at your table. Lots of hard fights? Maybe they only run into one. Having an easy time? Maybe it's a dozen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Maps are for more than just combat. Use them for exploration and even roleplaying.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use waves of monsters to keep the pressure up in great big battles. Bring out the boss last.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Subtlety often gets lost in the translation of ideas from DM to players. Sometimes you need to be direct. Describe what their characters notice.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pool damage done to an entire horde of monsters instead of individually. Every time they take damage equal to the HP of a monster, remove a monster. Round HP to the nearest 5 or 10 to make life easy. Horde hit with an AOE? Remove those who fail their save.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go with the flow of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep published adventures from the path the characters are likely to take.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Alternate between hard battles, potentially easy battles, roleplay scenes, and exploration.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build paths and choices based on different types of gameplay so players can choose the type of game they enjoy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer suggestions if the players seem to miss obvious solutions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Treat the characters like experienced adventurers facing life and death decisions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find the easiest way to bring in a new character and note the heroic spark in their eye to avoid thirty minute of suspicious questioning.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give NPCs interesting details to make them easier to remember.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down NPC names as soon as they're exposed to the players. They've become real at that point.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the characters use the environment to get the edge on their foes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Characters getting thrown off a cliff? Give them an athletics or acrobatics check to catch themselves and only take a little damage instead of a 20d6 fall.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For a series of ability checks, think about how the situation works in the world first and what needs to be done. Then assign DCs and ability checks to the in-world situations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: When revealing vital but hidden information, call for a group ability check and give the highest roller the information they see.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Call for ability checks and let the players bring forward skills that may be applicable and how they'd use them in the fiction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make quick legendary creatures with three legendary resistances and three legendary actions per round with their most appropriate single attack and a non-provoking move.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add interesting environmental details for big boss fights. Improvise how they behave when the characters mess with them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take turns going through downtime scenes. Rely on your abstract secrets and clues to fill in interesting details the characters learn during downtime.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't overdo NPC to NPC discussions. Involve the characters as much as possible.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Though you may find yourself in the DM chair because no one else would take it, you may find DMing to be an incredibly rewarding experience. Lean into it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on the characters. Build the story from them. Keep them in the spotlight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Avoid DM PCs and tag-along NPCs. Keep the focus on the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Experiment with jump-cuts into high action scenes. "A yeti punches you in the face"".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run multiple non-legendary bosses simultaneously when characters hit 7th level and above.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't get frustrated with banish. Embrace it in the fiction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Expect the whole feeling of the game to change at certain level increases. 5th feels very different than 4th. 7th feels different than 6th.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build situations, see how the characters choose to interact with it, adjudicate the world's response.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give your notes a quick read-through right before your game to internalize what's important.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Higher levels is more than harder monsters. The scope and scale of the whole story should change.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a moment to consider the mood and energy level of the table and adjust accordingly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give characters opportunities where time isn't a factor and they can take their time to decide on their approach.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give lots of chances to fail forward in conversations with NPCs. It doesn't have to be one check and done.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Always consider what choices and opportunities for a character's action exist in any given scene. Narrative-only scenes get stale fast.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Jot down three bullets of interesting features for each fantastic location you intended to run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Listen to audiobooks to hear how narrators describe high fantasy.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider how random combat encounters reveal secrets to the characters as they do battle. What can they learn from the fight?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Is a player rolling terribly in a battle? Call on their character to discover interesting or vital secrets during the fight.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up easy battles and hard battles; battles against many foes and battles against a few.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up scenes of roleplaying, exploration, and combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix in random treasure and treasure selected to support the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make magic items unique with an origin and a condition. Add history and a cool name.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Include secrets about NPCs, locations, history, gods, villains, and plots.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Expose secrets through artwork, NPCs, magic items, books, scrolls, dreams, portents, and characters' historical knowledge.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scale up the story of your campaign by orders of magnitude as the characters reach 5th, 11th, and 17th level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Study the capabilities of the characters both to help you challenge them and let them shine.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Enjoy connecting larger campaign adventures and sharing those connections with the players even if the characters don't understand the connections.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare for any single powerful creature to get banished once the characters reach 7th level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Three bosses are better than one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use the characters' skill proficiencies and passive ability checks to share information as they explore the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Share the world through the eyes of the characters. What do they see? What do they notice?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customize published adventures around the backgrounds and drives of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep things simple. Sometimes a straight-forward dungeon crawl is just the thing.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure friendly NPCs show up even in the darkest dungeons.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build interesting variant monsters by applying traits from one monster stat block to another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to jack up that damage dial on monsters above CR 10.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If you offer a choice, expect players to choose either one. Prepare for them to dive into the wrong answer.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Customize monster stat blocks on the fly. You know better than anyone how a monster might work at your own table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be stingy with magic items.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Need to roll a d20 but don't have any dice? Use a stopwatch. Look at the tenths and hundredths digits. The hundredths is the single digit. If the tenths is even, that's a 10 + the hundredths. If it's odd it's 0 + the hundredths. A .80 is a 20!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Dragons make great quest-giving NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Identify legendary foes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In big challenging fights, give the characters enemies to crowd control.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understand the damage output, hit points, and combat capabilities of your specific group. This offers much greater insight than overall challenge ratings.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give legendary monsters a physical in-world representation of their legendary resistances such as tattoos that wink out, floating ioun stones that explode, or gemstone teeth that crack. Thanks Level-up A5E!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare some in-town events for downtime scenes. What might the characters see or learn about while engaging in their downtime?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about how a tough combat challenges the characters instead of just worrying if it's tough.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use exotic spells from non-core books and third party publishers as a special type of loot.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie third-party spells to single-use magic items. That way, if its totally broken, you only have to deal with it once.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End at the beginning of a battle so you know you're going to start strong.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Initiative begins the minute one creature commits a hostile act against another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use, re-skin, and tweak existing monsters instead of building your own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Quick monster stats: AC/DC = 12 + 1/2 CR; HP = 15 * CR; Attack / Proficiencies = 3 + 1/2 CR; Damage = 7 (2d6) per level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix up opportunities for exploration, role play, and combat even when dungeon delving.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Pay attention to the skill proficiency selections of the characters so you know what to tug on during the game
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify choices
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Represent legendary resistance in-world. Glowing ioun stones, glyphed teeth, stone obelisks, runed scales, layers of magical protection.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Identify legendary foes so players know what to expect.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Understand how the urgency of the story affects the choices of the characters. Turn that urgency dial accordingly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't worry about having to read up on a room when the character enter it in a dungeon crawl. The flexibility of going anywhere is more important than being perfectly prepared.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use single use or permanent magic items as hooks to explore risky or dangerous situations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prompt individual characters on their thoughts about what to do next.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Players used to playing online often stay silent to avoid talking over one another. Ask individuals for their thoughts and choices.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use random encounter tables to show battles that happened before.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: All non-core books are optional. Choose which books and material to include into your campaign instead of allowing everything and having to exclude stuff. Flavor your campaign by the sources allowed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tailor your campaign's theme with thematic third party material. Kobold Press in particular. Their stuff is awesome.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Scheming NPCs act in their own best interest. Betrayal isn't inevitable.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Go with something cool or fun even if it breaks some realism.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In more open-world adventures or cities, think about the three places the characters might go in three different directions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "Pause for a minute" to break character and, as players, discuss and resolve inter-character conflicts.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the characters see random encounters wandering by and let them decide if they want to engage them or not.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be careful dropping traps and surprise attacks on the character whose player is willing to use them to propel the story forward. Don't regularly punish characters for taking initiative in the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take breaks every ninety minutes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the world through the eyes, backgrounds, and proficiencies of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add monsters designed to eat the characters' favorite save-or-suck spells like Banish, Polymorph, Hypnotic Pattern, or Stunning Strike.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Beware the too-long monologue. Let the characters jump in and punch the monologuing villain.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spells or powers seemingly too good to be true often are. Give them a quick read to see what's being missed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Greater challenges most often come from more monsters but so too does the duration of the battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus on the prep time and materials that bring the most fun to your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use rough abstract battle maps with relative distances when players can't visualize pure theater of the mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask yourself if all the time spent setting up dynamic lighting actually makes your game better.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus your time and attention on the parts of your campaign you love the most.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Not digging what you read in a published adventure? Wish it was something else? Do that instead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use published material as sources of inspiration to fuel your own adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be prepared for the characters to attempt negotiation with every monster you drop on the table even if a fight is what they're really after.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Expand or reduce future battles based on the results of the previous. Did they have an easy time? Beef things up. Did they have a rough time? Drop it down.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reducing monster hit points is the easiest way to tune down the length of combat. Increasing damage is the easiest way to increase danger.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep descriptions down to three sentences. Make them fantastic, useful, and oriented towards the characters' actions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players what they hope for as you come to the close of your campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider the arcs of each character as you come close to the end of your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Waves of combatants is a great way to challenge powerful parties without dumping everything on them at once.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure the story evolves in long combat. Give players the opportunity for exploration and roleplaying even as combat rages on.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Low hit points and high damage make for great minions at high levels.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add 2d6 elemental damage to a monster's attack to boost their threat. Flavor their attacks with the type of element. Dripping acidic claws, necrotic blades, blazing axes, etc.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the world from the characters' point of view.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: A "one year later" montage is a great way to hand a character's arc over to their player at the end of a campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Challenge high-level and high-power characters with waves of enemies in a single battle.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add groups of monsters in big piles the characters can blast or control for fun and profit.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie level progression to specific quests or accomplishments in the story of your game. Articulate them up front. Thanks @mattcolville!
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Leave at least 30 minutes for the end of your campaign after the final battle. Give the players time to breathe and enjoy their victory.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build off what the players bring to the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Improvise multi-success or failure progress clocks to mirror complex situations in the world.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Internalize the mood, theme, and atmosphere of an adventure and campaign as much as the details.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: During your session zero, focus the characters motivations around the theme and drive of the campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put yourself in the shoes of the NPCs and act as they would act.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use a "pause for a minute" voice queue so you or any player can break character for a moment, address any issues, and ensure the game is on the right track.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe the world from the point of view of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep track of the skills and languages each character knows to aid you in describing the world without breaking to ask.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You have what you need. You'll be great.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the players know when it's safe and not safe to split the party.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Remember, it's just a game. Do what you need to do, in or out of character, to keep the game running smoothly.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Consider carefully how you treat the theme of the scene, the adventure, and the campaign. Small changes can have big effects.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: From Shawn Merwin's idea of the "unity of effect" - Everything in a scene should (and does!) reinforce the theme and tone of the adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Check in with your players each session to make sure they're happy with the direction things are going.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Know which clues are vital and be ready to drop them in in many different places.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Share too many secrets instead of too few.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify the theme of your adventure and campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You're campaign's theme counts for about half of a player's engagement with the game. The other half focuses on their character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make things happen. Let things happen.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The moment a player's character receives a fun single-use magic item is the most enjoyable moment. If they hoard it, that's fine.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Describe. Listen. Respond.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Worry less about overpowered single-use magic items. They may unbalance one battle but that makes a remarkable story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify choices.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: First and formost, players want to watch their characters do cool stuff.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Get the scene to the actions and decisions of the characters as fast as you can.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players to describe their characters' new tricks when they level so you know what the players are excited about.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mash up your favorite adventures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players what their characters think of their current situations and views of the road ahead.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Roll random encounters ahead of time and see if they spark your interest.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie random encounters to the rest of the story with well-placed secrets and clues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep an eye on the pacing and feeling of your session and steer it in the right direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Strong starts don't need to be combat. The main theme of the strong start is "something happens".
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep some fun encounters on hand and drop the right one in as needed during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: You don't owe anything to your game preparation. If it's working for your game you're doing it right.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What's the one-word theme of your campaign? Write it down and keep it in front of you while preparing and running your games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the characters in front of you at all times. You never know how how you can draw them into the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Stuck for an idea? Write down 10 ideas as fast as you can and see what your brain comes up with.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Grab the knives the players give you but don't stab too deep or they won't give you another.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What's cool? What's fun? What's funny? What makes sense for the situation?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fun is more important than realism.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build dungeons quickly with a map, some one- to three-word room descriptions with fantastic monuments, and a handful of potential encounters (good and bad).
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Note the players' interest in particular NPCs and double down on them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down NPC names as soon as they're spoken.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End some games early so you have times to ask for stars and wishes. What did each player enjoy so far? What are they hoping for or looking forward to?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Relax and focus on the basics.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Just because a creature has multiattack doesn't mean they have to use it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use NPC personalities that reinforce the themes and feeling of the campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What's the one thing you learned from the last game you ran?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players the option to declare enemies either killed or "knocked out" even with spells or ranged attacks. Give the players agency over the world to decide if such things happened.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down NPC names as soon as they're spoken.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Put yourself in the point of view of the characters and NPCs. What does the world look like to *them*?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Drop friendly or useful NPCs into enemy territory like dungeons or villainous lairs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Listen. Adjust.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let characters take out enemy combatants with good ideas and ability checks instead of just damage. "I pick up and body-slam that bandit into the lake."
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use random tables to shake up the status quo.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Lose yourself in the world and the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take note of who's been quiet. Ask them what their character thinks of the current situation.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Set up an easy and fast system to take notes during the game. Use it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't overstay the welcome of any one scene or situation. Know when to move things along.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Show pictures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: NPC stat blocks are the most reskinnable in the game. Know then and use them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players to fill in details of the world around them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Glance at a monster's defenses and damage output along with its CR to gauge how it might play out when it hits your table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make a checklist of the things you need to run your game. Check it ten minutes before the game begins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Alternate between easy fights and hard fights.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of treasure you can drop in for the right upward beat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be ready for a change in the story's direction when the characters roleplay with important NPCs.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep your toolbox lean and focused on running an awesome game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ride the flow of the story of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tokens printed on photo paper and sealed using a 1" epoxy sticker and a 1" circular adhesive magnet are a great alternative to miniatures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What's the situation? What's the location? What's the goal? Who are the inhabitants?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use handouts to draw players into the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Omit what distracts from the story you share.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep the characters' names in front of you all the time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let the characters get the edge on their villains.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Replace published NPCs with those who matter to the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be liberal awarding partial cover when characters seek it out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: If your game jumped forward 14 months into the future in the middle of a session, would you be ready to keep running?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's really hard to beat the flexibility, portability, and cost of a dry-erase flip mat and some dry-erase markers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Choose tools that help you improvise during the session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Run with scissors.

text: #dnd tip: Keep some generic tokens or miniatures on hand for improvised battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Wrap fantastic locations in the lore of gods old and new.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Offer three options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Draw player in through the skills of their characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Address the quiet player.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of the characters in front of you at all times.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Refine you tools.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players what they enjoyed and want more of.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make boring monsters fantastic in your story and narrative.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify when characters get info from unreliable narrators.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix monster stat blocks.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use tabletop terrain as scene set pieces, not just for combat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Start and end with a bang.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reintroduce NPCs the players know and love, even love to hate.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Show character secrets through dreams and visions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Take a walk and think about the drives and backgrounds of the characters in your game.

text: #dnd tip: Try a small new thing in every session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What's the coolest thing in your next session? Double down on that.

text: #dnd tip: Move quickly to the actions and decisions of the characters.

text: #dnd tip: Build custom magic items for your characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focusing on the characters may be the biggest impact you can have in your game.

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters a headquarters. Let them customize it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch the time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: For some encounters, give players the choice to engage in combat, roleplaying, or skip them completely.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Every scene is an opportunity for the characters to learn something.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Move mysteries forward one clue at a time. Enough to learn something new but not enough to see the whole picture.

text: #dnd tip: Reinforce the theme and feeling of your campaign with each NPC, environment, and worldly description.

text: #dnd tip: Thank your players for taking the time to enjoy a game with you.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill your mind with great books, movies, shows, and games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Find the right music to add atmosphere to your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reflavor animated armor with origins, conditions, and elemental damage.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players respec their characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tailor magic items to the backgrounds and interests of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Quick monster stats: AC / DC = 12 + 1/2 CR; HP = 15 x CR; Attack Bonus / Prof Saves / Prof Skills = 3 + 1/2 CR; damage = 7 x CR

text: #dnd tip: Think about what cool magic items fit the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Peek at the players' character sheets to fuel ways to spotlight their coolest features.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Mix equal parts humor and sinister.

text: #dnd tip: What tools help you best share stories of high adventure with your friends?

author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's easy to get excited with an NPC you love. Don't overblow your monolog.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure characters have meaningful choices in each scene you run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ensure roleplaying scenes give characters useful information.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Who hasn't gotten a magic item recently? Add one they're sure to love.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin monsters into creatures unique for your setting and adventure.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prepare for your big surprise to get blown early. How does your campaign keep moving forward even if the characters know the answer?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What NPC are you most excited to roleplay next session?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reskin monster stat blocks into your own twisted horrors.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Aim for more episodic sessions when you know players can't make it from session to session.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reveal secrets before the players figure them out.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan and prepare scenes you can't wait to run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Move the features of dungeon chambers to the rooms you want them to be in as you play.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down one to three interesting features for each chamber in a dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: It's easy for people to talk over one another when playing online. Interrupt the interrupter and pass it to the original talker, then back to the interrupter.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have a session zero conversation about lag, conversational interruptions, and how you'll deal with it for online games.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: During scenes of rest, ask the characters how they feel about the current situation and what it makes them think about from their past.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to give out vorpal swords. Let them run with scissors.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give knives, just don't take them. Give your characters campaign-breaking items, alliances, and powers.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Strip down your NPCs to those your players can remember.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Instead of sub-systems focus on ability checks, roleplaying, and your facilitation of events.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Make a checklist of the things you need to run your game. Check it before the game begins.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use adhesive book tabs to mark monsters in your monster books and make them easily accessible during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Few tools are as usable and flexible as the humble index card.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use "pause for a minute" as a verbal queue to break character and address situations as players outside of the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Maps or terrain need not just be for combat. Give the players a cool view of the room in which their characters engage in crucial conversations.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Reveal the world and situation through the backgrounds, skills, and proficiencies of the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to end a game early if the timing is right and the situation works better at the beginning of the next game instead of the end of this one.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players early warning to think about their "one year later" montage at the end of a campaign. Should they survive, where might they see their characters one year after the events of the campaign?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Important enemies might not die on the final blow. Let them offer one last bit of NPC interaction before they expire.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Read published adventures. Take the parts you like and reshape them into what you want to run.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down the targets of past foreshadowing so you remember to bring them back into the story later.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't steal the characters' final blow against a big villain by giving it to an NPC or some other external event.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: "Pause for a minute" to make sure the players are all good with the characters finishing off a villain.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify the choices the characters currently face.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add interesting phases to big battles. What new thing happens each round, good or bad?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add one or two interesting environmental features to big battle arenas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give characters interesting options, even at the very end of a campaign.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't spend a lot of time with monsters attacking monsters. Go with the narrative and put the spotlight back on the characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give bosses legendary resistances but clearly delineate them as legendary so players don't waste save or suck spells on them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Follow Level Up Advanced 5e's idea and tie legendary resistances to in-world features like glyphs on a sword or ioun stones floating around one's head.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie spells from third party products to scrolls and magic items to gently introduce new features the players haven't seen before.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Modify and customize published adventures based on the characters the players bring to the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add in fun NPCs and villains into published adventures and campaigns to make them your own.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Keep a list of the players and characters in front of you during your prep and during your game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players for pictures of their characters so all of you have visuals in mind.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think of a published campaign as one arc in a bigger story you're going to put together as the game moves forward.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Limit character creation source material to steer each campaign in an interesting direction.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Bring interesting third party material into your games. There's a world of fantastic options for our D&D game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Review a checklist of what you need to run a great game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce lots of NPCs. Narrow down to the ones the players enjoy the most.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What are the three most interesting features of the city your characters visit?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask your players to describe the interesting features of their headquarters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce NPCs the characters know from their backgrounds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Tie NPCs to faces. Show pictures.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Print NPC face cards four to a page. Cut them out and keep them in front of the players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What characteristics make your next NPC unique? What interests your players?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Adding an extra attack can dramatically and easily boost a monster's threat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: In each session give each character a chance to shine both mechanically and in the story.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What's happening in the background while the characters go about their business?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What forgotten tunnels, sewers, chambers, ruins, and caverns lie beneath your city?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Embrace the quantum ogre. Let the world shift in interesting ways as the characters choose their path.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give boss monsters movement that doesn't provoke opportunity attacks and some extra attacks of their own to make up for the big crosshair on their back.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Balance a large number of characters with a large number of monsters, but expect the battle to go long.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Share observations from the point of view of the characters. What do they see, hear, and know?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters the opportunity to discover traps. Discovered traps are far more rewarding than sprung traps.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Add traps that make sense for the location, not just ones that "challenge" the characters. Walking right through a bunch of low-level traps is a fun way to enjoy a higher-level character.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: The MCDM minion rules are an easy way to run dozens of monsters. Give creatures a trait that, when successfully hit with an attack or failing a saving throw, they die. It's a fast way to get lots of monsters on and off the table.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players meaningful choices when exploring a dungeon.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Address the characters of quiet players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What ten secrets and clues might the characters uncover in your next game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Focus your game around the plotlines you enjoy the most.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Embrace third party material. Expand your selection of campaigns, adventures, monsters, and character options.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What can the characters learn about the activities of the villains behind the scenes?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write and email short flash fiction between games to keep players engaged.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Introduce villains early and often.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Foreshadow villains with annoying heralds.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Don't be afraid to let players know when they've crossed a line you don't want crossed.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Extra attacks dramatically increase a monster's threat.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let characters turn prisoners into turncoats, informants, employees, or good citizens who turn over a new leaf.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players what they look forward to in future sessions.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let players know what story events lead to new levels.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give the characters a home base they can evolve and upgrade as their campaign continues.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players an easy way to travel back to their home base, even from afar. Shadow-roads, elven gateways, ancient portals, glyphed stones of returning.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Clarify what sources you allow for character creation and clarify how to keep track of this in tools like D&D Beyond.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Embrace third party material.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Be wary of a reliance on digital tools. They don't last the hundreds of years a book does.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: What scene excites you to run in your next game?
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players to describe their new character abilities to you and the other players whenever they level.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Note what character abilities excite your players. Build encounters to show them off.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Let fantastic art Inspire NPCs, villains, locations, and whole campaigns.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Change campaigns with your own fantastic ideas.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep and drive campaigns with the goals and quests of your villains.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give mini-bossess double HP and maybe an extra attack to set them apart from the rabble.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Prep with handouts. Pack them with important names, places, and plots.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Plan roughly one scene for every 45 minutes of game time.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Recap previous sessions - either provided by you or your players.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Think about the beat and pacing you want to end with in your session and how you might get there.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Break up long travel with interesting encounters and locations along the way
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Spend the time to design your big knock-down drag-out set piece battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Develop your comfort in improvising smaller situational combat encounters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build a library of re-usable encounter maps for improvised battles.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Build battles that let players show off their cool abilities.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players what combat abilities they want to use. Give them situations to use them.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Have players describe the new capabilities of their characters when they level up. Note it in your character notes.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Give players meaningful choices as often as possible.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Print out art and hand it out during the game.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Use third party campaign worlds as a hub for lots of third party content. Build an entirely new flavor of D&D around it.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: End on a cliffhanger and your strong start is built in.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Ask players what types of magic items they'd like for their characters.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Write down notes right after a session before you forget them all.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Fill travel with interesting situations with choices to make and lore to discover.
author: Michael E. Shea

text: #dnd tip: Watch carefully for players having a poor time from bad luck. Find ways to give them an upward beat.
author: Michael E. Shea
